  >

TITLE: Displaying Component Property in Template (Angular TS)

  selector: 'app-user',
  template: `
    ...
    <p>Framework: {{ favoriteFramework }}</p>
    <label for="framework">
      Favorite Framework:
      <input id="framework" type="text" [(ngModel)]="favoriteFramework" />
    </label>
  `,
})
export class UserComponent {
  favoriteFramework = '';
}
```

TITLE: Creating an Injectable Service in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to create a Calculator service with the @Injectable decorator which makes it available throughout the application with providedIn: 'root'. The service contains a simple add method for calculating the sum of two numbers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/introduction/essentials/dependency-injection.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Injectable} from '@angular/core';

@Injectable({providedIn: 'root'})
export class Calculator {
  add(x: number, y: number) {
    return x + y;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using Signals in Angular Components
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use signals and computed signals within an Angular component. It shows the creation of multiple signals and a computed signal that depends on them, as well as a method to update a signal's value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/introduction/essentials/signals.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({/* ... */})
export class UserProfile {
  isTrial = signal(false);
  isTrialExpired = signal(false);
  showTrialDuration = computed(() => this.isTrial() && !this.isTrialExpired());

  activateTrial() {
    this.isTrial.set(true);
  }
}
```

TITLE: Defining Routes in Angular Application
DESCRIPTION: In the routes.ts file, two routes are defined for the Angular application, linking paths to HomeComponent and DetailsComponent. This requires pre-defined components and the Routes type from Angular.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tutorials/first-app/steps/10-routing/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```

import { Routes } from '@angular/router';
import { HomeComponent } from './home/home.component';
import { DetailsComponent } from './details/details.component';

export const routeConfig: Routes = [
  { path: '', component: HomeComponent },
  { path: 'details', component: DetailsComponent }
];

```

TITLE: Injecting a Service into an Angular Component
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to inject the Calculator service into a Receipt component. It imports the necessary dependencies, uses the inject function to create an instance of the Calculator service, and then uses the service's add method to calculate a total cost displayed in the template.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/introduction/essentials/dependency-injection.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, inject } from '@angular/core';
import { Calculator } from './calculator';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-receipt',
  template: `<h1>The total is {{ totalCost }}</h1>`,
})

export class Receipt {
  private calculator = inject(Calculator);
  totalCost = this.calculator.add(50, 25);
}
```

TITLE: Defining Basic Angular Routes (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to define an array of `Routes` using `@angular/router`. Each route object maps a URL `path` to a `component` to be rendered when the path is matched, and optionally sets the browser `title`. This `routes` array is typically registered with the `RouterModule`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/show-routes-with-outlets.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Routes } from '@angular/router';
import { HomeComponent } from './home/home.component';
import { ProductsComponent } from './products/products.component';

const routes: Routes = [
  {
    path: '',
    component: HomeComponent,
    title: 'Home Page'
  },
  {
    path: 'products',
    component: ProductsComponent,
    title: 'Our Products'
  }
];
```

TITLE: Importing NgIf Directive in Angular Component (TypeScript)

TITLE: Creating and Updating Writable Signals - Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a writable signal using `signal()` and update its value with `.set` and `.update` functions. The snippet shows a counter signal being incremented. Angular signals require no specific dependencies but are used within reactive contexts, updating automatically as their dependencies change. Inputs include the initial counter value, and outputs are the updated values. Limitations include synchronous execution constraints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
const counter = signal(0);

counter.set(2);
counter.update(count => count + 1);
```

TITLE: Implementing @switch Block in Angular HTML
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the syntax of the `@switch` block in Angular HTML templates, used for displaying content based on conditionals. The `@default` case is optional, allowing flexibility in content display when no cases match.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/tools/manual_api_docs/blocks/switch.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```

    Case A.
  }
  @case (caseB) {
    Case B.
  }
  @default {
    Default case.
  }
}
```

  name = 'telephone';
}

TITLE: Creating and Manipulating Signals in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a signal, read its value, and update it using both 'set' and 'update' methods. It showcases the basic operations possible with signals in Angular.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/introduction/essentials/signals.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {signal} from '@angular/core';

// Create a signal with the `signal` function.
const firstName = signal('Morgan');

// Read a signal value by calling itâ€” signals are functions.
console.log(firstName());

// Change the value of this signal by calling its `set` method with a new value.
firstName.set('Jaime');

// You can also use the `update` method to change the value
// based on the previous value.
firstName.update(name => name.toUpperCase());
```

TITLE: Migrating to Standalone Bootstrapping API - Angular - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This set of snippets shows the updated approach using Angular's standalone `bootstrapApplication`. The module class definition is largely minimal, with configuration now set up directly in the bootstrapping call in `main.ts`. Providers and imports are passed using `importProvidersFrom` and other helper functions, like `provideRouter` and `provideAnimations`. All dependencies previously configured in NgModule are now provided at the application root, supporting modular and standalone design. Input: root AppComponent, dependency tokens, modules. Output: bootstrapped Angular app without an NgModule. Limitations: requires Angular version supporting standalone API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/ng-generate/standalone-migration/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// ./app/app.module.ts\nimport {NgModule, InjectionToken} from '@angular/core';\nimport {RouterModule} from '@angular/router';\nimport {BrowserAnimationsModule} from '@angular/platform-browser/animations';\nimport {AppComponent} from './app.component.ts';\nimport {SharedModule} from '../shared/shared.module';\nimport {ImportedInterface} from './some-interface';\nimport {CONFIG} from './config';\n\ninterface NonImportedInterface {\n  foo: any;\n  bar: ImportedInterface;\n}\n\nconst token = new InjectionToken<NonImportedInterface>('token');\n\nexport class ExportedConfigClass {}
```

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// ./app/app.component.ts\n@Component({selector: 'app', template: 'hello'})\nexport class AppComponent {}
```

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// ./main.ts\nimport {platformBrowser, bootstrapApplication} from '@angular/platform-browser';\nimport {InjectionToken, importProvidersFrom} from '@angular/core';\nimport {withEnabledBlockingInitialNavigation, provideRouter} from '@angular/router';\nimport {provideAnimations} from '@angular/platform-browser/animations';\nimport {AppModule, ExportedConfigClass} from './app/app.module';\nimport {AppComponent} from './app/app.component';\nimport {CONFIG} from './app/config';\nimport {SharedModule} from './shared/shared.module';\nimport {ImportedInterface} from './app/some-interface';\n\ninterface NonImportedInterface {\n  foo: any;\n  bar: ImportedInterface;\n}\n\nconst token = new InjectionToken<NonImportedInterface>('token');\n\nbootstrapApplication(AppComponent, {\n  providers: [\n    importProvidersFrom(SharedModule),\n    {provide: token, useValue: {foo: true, bar: {baz: false}}},\n    {provide: CONFIG, useClass: ExportedConfigClass},\n    provideAnimations(),\n    provideRouter([{\n      path: 'shop',\n      loadComponent: () => import('./app/shop/shop.component').then(m => m.ShopComponent)\n    }], withEnabledBlockingInitialNavigation())\n  ]\n}).catch(e => console.error(e));
```

TITLE: Lazy Component Loading with Angular Routes
DESCRIPTION: The snippet illustrates how to implement lazy loading of components, where components are only fetched when the route becomes active. This approach minimizes initial load time by deferring JavaScript loading until necessary.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/define-routes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Routes } from "@angular/router";

export const routes: Routes = [
  // The HomePage and LoginPage components are loaded lazily at the point at which
  // their corresponding routes become active.
  {
    path: 'login',
    loadComponent: () => import('./components/auth/login-page')
  },
  {
    path: ',
    loadComponent: () => import('./components/home/home-page')
  }
]
```

TITLE: Using @defer with 'hydrate on interaction' Trigger (Angular HTML)
DESCRIPTION: This Angular HTML template snippet shows the `@defer` block utilizing the `hydrate on interaction` trigger. Hydration of the `<large-cmp />` is deferred until the user interacts (clicks or presses a key) with the placeholder element. This allows critical content to load first, hydrating interactive elements only when needed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/incremental-hydration.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
@defer (hydrate on interaction) {
  <large-cmp />
} @placeholder {
  <div>Large component placeholder</div>
}
```

TITLE: Implementing HeroService with Dependency Injection in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows a HeroService class that depends on BackendService and Logger services. It demonstrates how to inject and use these dependencies within the service.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/creating-injectable-service.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { inject } from "@angular/core";

export class HeroService {
  private heroes: Hero[] = [];

  private backend = inject(BackendService);
  private logger = inject(Logger);

  async getHeroes() {
    // Fetch
    this.heroes = await this.backend.getAll(Hero);
    // Log
    this.logger.log(`Fetched ${this.heroes.length} heroes.`);
    return this.heroes;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Creating the Main Dynamic Form Container Component in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `DynamicFormComponent` (TypeScript logic and HTML template), which acts as the main container for the dynamic form. It receives the question data (`questions` Input), uses `QuestionControlService` to create the `FormGroup`, and iterates over the questions in the template, rendering each one using the `app-question` component (`DynamicFormQuestionComponent`). It also includes a submit button, conditionally disabled based on form validity, and displays the form payload upon submission.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: HTML
CODE:
```
<div>
  <form (ngSubmit)="onSubmit()" [formGroup]="form">

    <div *ngFor="let question of questions" class="form-row">
      <app-question [question]="question" [form]="form"></app-question>
    </div>

    <div class="form-row">
      <button type="submit" [disabled]="!form.valid">Save</button>
    </div>
  </form>

  <div *ngIf="payLoad" class="form-row">
    <strong>Saved the following values</strong><br>{{payLoad}}
  </div>
</div>

```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Component, Input, OnInit }  from '@angular/core';
import { FormGroup }                 from '@angular/forms';

import { QuestionBase }              from './question-base';
import { QuestionControlService }    from './question-control.service';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-dynamic-form',
  templateUrl: './dynamic-form.component.html',
  providers: [ QuestionControlService ]
})
export class DynamicFormComponent implements OnInit {

  @Input() questions: QuestionBase<string>[] | null = [];
  form!: FormGroup;
  payLoad = '';

  constructor(private qcs: QuestionControlService) {}

  ngOnInit() {
    this.form = this.qcs.toFormGroup(this.questions as QuestionBase<string>[]);
  }

  onSubmit() {
    this.payLoad = JSON.stringify(this.form.getRawValue());
  }
}

```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Relative Programmatic Navigation using router.navigate() and relativeTo in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to perform programmatic navigation relative to the current component's route. It requires injecting both `Router` and `ActivatedRoute`. The `navigate()` method is called with a path array and the `relativeTo` option set to the current `ActivatedRoute`. Examples show navigating to a child/sibling route (`'edit'`) and navigating to the parent route (`'..'`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/navigate-to-routes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Router, ActivatedRoute } from '@angular/router';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-user-detail',
  template: `
    <button (click)="navigateToEdit()">Edit User</button>
    <button (click)="navigateToParent()">Back to List</button>
  `
})
export class UserDetailComponent {
  private route = inject(ActivatedRoute);
  private router = inject(Router);

  constructor() {}

  // Navigate to a sibling route
  navigateToEdit() {
    // From: /users/123
    // To:   /users/123/edit
    this.router.navigate(['edit'], { relativeTo: this.route });
  }

  // Navigate to parent
  navigateToParent() {
    // From: /users/123
    // To:   /users
    this.router.navigate(['..'], { relativeTo: this.route });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Angular @defer Block Syntax Example

  <!-- error template fragment -->

TITLE: Defining Nested Child Routes in Angular (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates configuring child routes using the `children` property within a parent route definition (`settings-component`). Routes defined in the `children` array (`profile`, `security`) are relative to the parent's path, and their associated components (`ProfileComponent`, `SecurityComponent`) are rendered in the parent component's `<router-outlet>`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/show-routes-with-outlets.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
const routes: Routes = [
  {
    path: 'settings-component',
    component: SettingsComponent, // this is the component with the <router-outlet> in the template
    children: [
      {
        path: 'profile', // child route path
        component: ProfileComponent, // child route component that the router renders
      },
      {
        path: 'security',
        component: SecurityComponent, // another child route component that the router renders
      },
    ],
  },
];
```

TITLE: Using @let Variables in Angular Templates (Angular HTML)
DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates the practical application of a variable declared with `@let`. The `user` variable, initialized using the async pipe (`user$ | async`), is subsequently used within an `@if` block to conditionally display user information. Inside the conditional block, properties of the `user` object (`user.name`, `user.photo`, `user.favoriteSnacks`) are accessed for rendering, passed as input to a component (`<user-avatar>`), iterated over using `@for`, and passed to an event handler (`update(user)`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/tools/manual_api_docs/blocks/let.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
@let user = user$ | async;

@if (user) {
  <h1>Hello, {{user.name}}</h1>
  <user-avatar [photo]="user.photo"/>

  <ul>
    @for (snack of user.favoriteSnacks; track snack.id) {
      <li>{{snack.name}}</li>
    }
  </ul>

  <button (click)="update(user)">Update profile</button>
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Two-Way Data Binding with NgModel (HTML)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of `[(ngModel)]` syntax (two-way data binding) on an HTML `<input>` element within an Angular template. It binds the input's value to the `currentItem.name` property in the component. Changes in the input update the property, and changes to the property update the input value. Requires `FormsModule` to be imported in the component.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/overview.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<!-- Example of [(ngModel)] for two-way data binding -->
<div>
  <label for="example-ngModel">[(ngModel)]:</label>
  <input [(ngModel)]="currentItem.name" id="example-ngModel">
  <p>Current item name: {{ currentItem.name }}</p>
</div>
```

TITLE: Deferring Loading with On Hover Trigger in Angular

CODE:

  <article-comments />
} @placeholder (minimum 1s) {
  <p>Placeholder for comments</p>
} @loading (minimum 1s; after 500ms) {
  <p>Loading comments...</p>
} @error {
  <p>Failed to load comments</p>
}
```

TITLE: Using contentChild for Single Result Content Query in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use the contentChild function to query for a single child component in the component's content. It shows how to access the query result in a computed property.

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'custom-toggle',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomToggle {
  text: string;
}

@Component({
  selector: 'custom-expando',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomExpando {
  toggle = contentChild(CustomToggle);
  toggleText = computed(() => this.toggle()?.text);
}

@Component({ 
  /* ... */
  // CustomToggle is used inside CustomExpando as content.  
  template: `
    <custom-expando>
      <custom-toggle>Show</custom-toggle>
    </custom-expando>
  `
})
export class UserProfile { }

TITLE: Testing with Automatic Change Detection Examples
DESCRIPTION: Three test cases that demonstrate how automatic change detection works, including its limitations when updates happen within test cases and how to use fixture.whenStable().
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should display original title', () => {
  // Automatic change detection updates the view with the component's initial title
  expect(h1.textContent).toContain(component.title);
});

it('should still see original title after comp.title change', () => {
  // Changing the component's title directly doesn't update the view
  component.title = 'Test Title';
  expect(h1.textContent).not.toContain('Test Title');
});

it('should display updated title after whenStable', async () => {
  // Changing the component's title directly doesn't update the view
  component.title = 'Test Title';
  await fixture.whenStable(); // wait for the change to be scheduled
  expect(h1.textContent).toContain('Test Title');
});
```

TITLE: Querying with @ViewChildren in Angular Typescript
DESCRIPTION: This example uses the @ViewChildren decorator to access multiple instances of a component from an Angular template. It demonstrates capturing multiple CustomCardAction components using a QueryList and accessing them after view initialization using ngAfterViewInit. The QueryList provides an iterable list of components that can be processed using methods like forEach.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/queries.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'custom-card-action',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomCardAction {
  text: string;
}

@Component({
  selector: 'custom-card',
  template: `
    <custom-card-action>Save</custom-card-action>
    <custom-card-action>Cancel</custom-card-action>
  `,
})
export class CustomCard {
  @ViewChildren(CustomCardAction) actions: QueryList<CustomCardAction>;

  ngAfterViewInit() {
    this.actions.forEach(action => {
      console.log(action.text);
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Template fragment rendering with NgTemplateOutlet in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates using ng-container with NgTemplateOutlet to dynamically render template fragments. The component selects between admin and basic templates based on a condition.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/templates/ng-container.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
@Component({
  template: `
    <h2>Your profile</h2>
    <ng-container [ngTemplateOutlet]="profileTemplate()" />

    <ng-template #admin>This is the admin profile</ng-template>
    <ng-template #basic>This is the basic profile</ng-template>
  `
})
export class UserProfile {
  isAdmin = input(false);
  adminTemplate = viewChild('admin', {read: TemplateRef});
  basicTemplate = viewChild('basic', {read: TemplateRef});
  profileTemplate = computed(() => this.isAdmin() ? this.adminTemplate() : this.basicTemplate());
}
```

TITLE: Defining Validators in Angular Reactive Forms (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates defining validators for a reactive form within the component class using `FormBuilder`. It initializes a `FormGroup` with a `name` `FormControl` that uses built-in synchronous validators (`Validators.required`, `Validators.minLength`) and a custom synchronous validator (`forbiddenNameValidator`). Validators are passed as the second argument to the `FormControl` constructor, potentially as an array for multiple validators. Getter methods for `name` and `alterEgo` are included for easier template access.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/form-validation.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
this.actorForm = this.fb.group({
  name: ['', [Validators.required, Validators.minLength(4), forbiddenNameValidator(/bob/i)]],
  alterEgo: [''],
  power: [this.powers[0], Validators.required]
});
```

TITLE: Visualizing View-to-Model Data Flow in Forms using Mermaid
DESCRIPTION: This mermaid diagram illustrates the data flow from input (view) to model in Angular template-driven forms, highlighting the sequence of events and the interaction of different components like FormControl and NgModel. It requires understanding of Angular form model components like ControlValueAccessor and FormControl.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/overview.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: mermaid
CODE:
```
flowchart TB
    U{User}
    I("&lt;input&gt;")
    CVA(ControlValueAccessor)
    FC(FormControl)
    M(NgModel)
    O(Observers)
    C(Component)
    P(Two-way binding)
    U-->|Types in the input box|I
    I-->|Fires the 'input' event|CVA
    CVA-->|"Calls setValue() on the FormControl"|FC
    FC-.->|Fires a 'valueChanges' event to observers|O
    CVA-->|"Calls viewToModelUpdate()"|M
    M-->|Emits an ngModelChange event|C
    C-->|Updates the value of the two-way bound property|P
```

TITLE: Implementing Browser-Safe Component Logic with afterNextRender in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to safely access browser-specific properties using the afterNextRender lifecycle hook. The component uses ViewChild to reference a DOM element and accesses its scrollHeight property only after rendering in the browser environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/ssr.md#2025-04-22_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, ViewChild, afterNextRender } from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  selector: 'my-cmp',
  template: `<span #content>{{ ... }}</span>`,
})
export class MyComponent {
  @ViewChild('content') contentRef: ElementRef;

  constructor() {
    afterNextRender(() => {
      // Safe to check `scrollHeight` because this will only run in the browser, not the server.
      console.log('content height: ' + this.contentRef.nativeElement.scrollHeight);
    });
  }
}
```

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
```angular-html\n@if (a > b) {\n  {{a}} is greater than {{b}}\n} @else if (b > a) {\n  {{a}} is less than {{b}}\n} @else {\n  {{a}} is equal to {{b}}\n}\n```

TITLE: Defining and Using Inputs in Angular Component - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a comprehensive Angular component utilizing the input utility with generics, transformation functions, and control flow patterns. Includes migration comments for accessor inputs and input property writes, along with several methods to test input accesses, type narrowing, and integration with inheritance types. Dependencies are Angular's Component and Input decorators, and the custom input function. Inputs have various types, with example transformations and access patterns tested through methods and helper functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Component, Input, input} from '@angular/core';

interface Vehicle {}
interface Car extends Vehicle {
  __car: true;
}
interface Audi extends Car {
  __audi: true;
}

@Component({
  selector: 'app-component',
  templateUrl: './template.html',
})
export class AppComponent {
  readonly input = input<string | null>(null);
  readonly bla = input.required<boolean, string | boolean>({ transform: disabledTransform });
  readonly narrowableMultipleTimes = input<Vehicle | null>(null);
  readonly withUndefinedInput = input<string>();
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Your application code writes to the input. This prevents migration.
  @Input() incompatible: string | null = null;

  private _bla: any;
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Accessor inputs cannot be migrated as they are too complex.
  @Input()
  set ngSwitch(newValue: any) {
    this._bla = newValue;
    if (newValue === 0) {
      console.log('test');
    }
  }

  someControlFlowCase() {
    const input = this.input();
    if (input) {
      input.charAt(0);
    }
  }

  moreComplexControlFlowCase() {
    const input = this.input();
    if (!input) {
      return;
    }

    this.doSomething();

    (() => {
      // might be a different input value now?!
      // No! it can't because we don't allow writes to "input"!!.
      console.log(input.substring(0));
    })();
  }

  doSomething() {
    this.incompatible = 'some other value';
  }

  vsd() {
    const input = this.input();
    const narrowableMultipleTimes = this.narrowableMultipleTimes();
    if (!input && narrowableMultipleTimes !== null) {
      return narrowableMultipleTimes;
    }
    return input ? 'eager' : 'lazy';
  }

  allTheSameNoNarrowing() {
    const input = this.input();
    console.log(input);
    console.log(input);
  }

  test() {
    if (this.narrowableMultipleTimes()) {
      console.log();

      const x = () => {
        // @ts-expect-error
        if (isCar(this.narrowableMultipleTimes())) {
        }
      };

      console.log();
      console.log();
      x();
      x();
    }
  }

  extremeNarrowingNested() {
    const narrowableMultipleTimes = this.narrowableMultipleTimes();
    if (narrowableMultipleTimes && isCar(narrowableMultipleTimes)) {
      narrowableMultipleTimes.__car;

      let car = narrowableMultipleTimes;
      let ctx = this;

      function nestedFn() {
        if (isAudi(car)) {
          console.log(car.__audi);
        }
        const narrowableMultipleTimesValue = ctx.narrowableMultipleTimes();
        if (!isCar(narrowableMultipleTimesValue!) || !isAudi(narrowableMultipleTimesValue)) {
          return;
        }

        narrowableMultipleTimesValue.__audi;
      }

      // iife
      (() => {
        if (isAudi(narrowableMultipleTimes)) {
          narrowableMultipleTimes.__audi;
        }
      })();
    }
  }
}

function disabledTransform(bla: string | boolean): boolean {
  return true;

TITLE: Testing HTTP Services with Spies in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to test a data service that uses HttpClient. This example uses spies to mock HttpClient methods and demonstrates testing both successful and error scenarios.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/services.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
let httpClientSpy: jasmine.SpyObj<HttpClient>;
let heroService: HeroService;

beforeEach(() => {
  // TODO: spy on other methods too
  httpClientSpy = jasmine.createSpyObj('HttpClient', ['get']);
  heroService = new HeroService(httpClientSpy);
});

it('should return expected heroes (HttpClient called once)', (done: DoneFn) => {
  const expectedHeroes: Hero[] =
    [{ id: 1, name: 'A' }, { id: 2, name: 'B' }];

  httpClientSpy.get.and.returnValue(asyncData(expectedHeroes));

  heroService.getHeroes().subscribe({
    next: heroes => {
      expect(heroes)
        .withContext('expected heroes')
        .toEqual(expectedHeroes);
      done();
    },
    error: done.fail
  });
  expect(httpClientSpy.get.calls.count())
    .withContext('one call')
    .toBe(1);
});

it('should return an error when the server returns a 404', (done: DoneFn) => {
  const errorResponse = new HttpErrorResponse({
    error: 'test 404 error',
    status: 404, statusText: 'Not Found'
  });

  httpClientSpy.get.and.returnValue(asyncError(errorResponse));

  heroService.getHeroes().subscribe({
    next: heroes => done.fail('expected an error, not heroes'),
    error: error  => {
      expect(error.message).toContain('test 404 error');
      done();
    }
  });
});
```

TITLE: Fetching Data Based on Route Parameter in Angular Component (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Updates the `DetailsComponent` class (`src/app/details/details.component.ts`) to fetch and handle housing location data. It injects `HousingService` alongside `ActivatedRoute`. The constructor now retrieves the `id` from the route parameter, converts it to a number, and then calls `housingService.getHousingLocationById()` with this ID. TITLE: Optimized @for Loop Tracking in Angular Component
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the correct way to implement tracking in an Angular @for loop by using a unique identifier (todo.id) instead of the entire object, which prevents unnecessary DOM recreation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG0956.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  template: `
    <button (click)="toggleAllDone()">All done!</button>
    <ul>
    @for (todo of todos; track todo.id) {
      <li>{{todo.task}}</li>
    }
    </ul>
  `,
})
export class App {
  todos = [
    { id: 0, task: 'understand trackBy', done: false },
    { id: 1, task: 'use proper tracking expression', done: false },
  ];

  toggleAllDone() {
    this.todos = this.todos.map(todo => ({ ...todo, done: true }));
  }
}
```

TITLE: Testing Services with Dependencies in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates various techniques for testing MasterService, including creating a real ValueService, using a fake value, and using a spy. These tests demonstrate different approaches to handling service dependencies in unit tests.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/services.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
describe('MasterService without Angular testing support', () => {
  let masterService: MasterService;

  it('#getValue should return real value from the real service', () => {
    masterService = new MasterService(new ValueService());
    expect(masterService.getValue()).toBe('real value');
  });

  it('#getValue should return faked value from a fakeService', () => {
    masterService = new MasterService({ getValue: () => 'fake value' } as ValueService);
    expect(masterService.getValue()).toBe('fake value');
  });

  it('#getValue should return stubbed value from a spy', () => {
    // create `getValue` spy on an object representing the ValueService
    const valueServiceSpy =
      jasmine.createSpyObj('ValueService', ['getValue']);

    // set the value to return when the `getValue` spy is called.
    const stubValue = 'stub value';
    valueServiceSpy.getValue.and.returnValue(stubValue);

    masterService = new MasterService(valueServiceSpy);

    expect(masterService.getValue())
      .toBe(stubValue, 'service returned stub value');
    expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.count())
      .toBe(1, 'spy method was called once');
    expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.mostRecent().returnValue)
      .toBe(stubValue);
  });
});
```

TITLE: Creating a Component to Render Individual Dynamic Form Questions in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `DynamicFormQuestionComponent` (TypeScript logic and HTML template) responsible for rendering a single question within the dynamic form. The template uses an `ngSwitch` based on the question's `controlType` to display the appropriate HTML input element (textbox or dropdown) and binds it to the corresponding `FormControl` within the parent `FormGroup` using `formControlName`. It also displays validation errors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: HTML
CODE:
```
<div [formGroup]="form">
  <label [attr.for]="question.key">{{question.label}}</label>

  <div [ngSwitch]="question.controlType">

    <input *ngSwitchCase="'textbox'" [formControlName]="question.key"
            [id]="question.key" [type]="question.type">

    <select [id]="question.key" *ngSwitchCase="'dropdown'" [formControlName]="question.key">
      <option *ngFor="let opt of question.options" [value]="opt.key">{{opt.value}}</option>
    </select>

  </div>

  <div class="errorMessage" *ngIf="!isValid">{{question.label}} is required</div>
</div>

```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Component, Input } from '@angular/core';
import { FormGroup }        from '@angular/forms';

import { QuestionBase }     from './question-base';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-question',
  templateUrl: './dynamic-form-question.component.html'
})
export class DynamicFormQuestionComponent {
  @Input() question!: QuestionBase<string>;
  @Input() form!: FormGroup;
  get isValid() { return this.form.controls[this.question.key].valid; }
}

```

TITLE: Displaying Validation Errors in Angular Reactive Forms (HTML)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to display validation error messages in the template for an Angular reactive form. Error messages are conditionally displayed using `*ngIf`, checking the control's state (e.g., `name.invalid`, `name.touched`, `name.dirty`) and specific errors (`name.errors?.required`, `name.errors?.minlength`, `name.errors?.forbiddenName`) accessed via a getter method (`name`) defined in the component class. The native HTML `required` attribute is kept for accessibility.

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<label for="name">Name</label>
<input id="name" class="form-control" formControlName="name" required >

<div *ngIf="name.invalid && (name.dirty || name.touched)" class="alert alert-danger">

  <div *ngIf="name.errors?.['required']">
    Name is required.
  </div>
  <div *ngIf="name.errors?.['minlength']">
    Name must be at least 4 characters long.
  </div>
  <div *ngIf="name.errors?.['forbiddenName']">
    Name cannot be Bob.
  </div>

</div>
```

TITLE: Implementing Equality Checks with Computed Signals and Effects in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Sets up an Angular `signal` named `counter`, a `computed` signal `isEven` derived from `counter`, and an `effect` that logs the parity of `isEven`. This example highlights equality semantics: the effect should only re-run when the boolean value of `isEven` actually changes (from true to false or vice-versa), even if underlying `counter` updates might result in the same computed `isEven` value (e.g., changing `counter` from 1 to 3, where `isEven` remains false). This necessitates value versioning.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
```typescript
const counter = signal(0);
const isEven = computed(() => counter() % 2 === 0);
effect(() => console.log(isEven() ? 'even!' : 'odd!'));
```
```

export function loggingInterceptor(req: HttpRequest<unknown>, next: HttpHandlerFn): Observable<HttpEvent<unknown>> {\n  console.log(req.url);\n  return next(req);\n}

TITLE: Enhancing Directive with Input Property (Angular, TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet adds an @Input-decorated property 'appHighlight' to the directive, allowing the host component to set the highlight color via property binding. It imports Input from '@angular/core'. The directive's logic will now use the bound value for background color. Dependencies: '@angular/core'. Input: property bound color value. Output: color used in highlight logic. Limitation: color must be a valid CSS color.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/attribute-directives.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Directive, ElementRef, HostListener, Input } from '@angular/core';

@Directive({
  selector: '[appHighlight]'
})
export class HighlightDirective {
  @Input() appHighlight: string;

  constructor(private el: ElementRef) {}

  @HostListener('mouseenter') onMouseEnter() {
    this.highlight(this.appHighlight || 'red');
  }

  @HostListener('mouseleave') onMouseLeave() {
    this.highlight('');
  }

  private highlight(color: string) {
    this.el.nativeElement.style.backgroundColor = color;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Search Filter Logic in HomeComponent (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Adds the `filterResults(text: string)` method to the `HomeComponent` class. This method filters the main `housingLocationList` based on a case-insensitive match between the provided `text` and the `city` property of each location. The resulting filtered array is assigned to `filteredLocationList`. If the search text is empty, it resets `filteredLocationList` to show all locations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tutorials/first-app/steps/13-search/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
export class HomeComponent {
  // ...
  filterResults(text: string) {
    if (!text) {
      this.filteredLocationList = this.housingLocationList;
      return;
    }

    this.filteredLocationList = this.housingLocationList.filter(
      housingLocation => housingLocation?.city.toLowerCase().includes(text.toLowerCase())
    );
  }
}
```

];
```

TITLE: Converting Observable/Subscribable to Angular Signal - TypeScript (Initial Value)
DESCRIPTION: Converts an RxJS Observable or Subscribable into an Angular Signal, providing a specific initial value. This value is used until the observable emits. Requires Angular core and RxJS.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/core/rxjs-interop/index.api.md#_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export function toSignal<T, const U extends T>(source: Observable<T> | Subscribable<T>, options: NoInfer<ToSignalOptions<T | U>> & {
    initialValue: U;
    requireSync?: false;
}): Signal<T | U>;
```

TITLE: Testing GET Request with HttpTestingController - Angular - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Tests a GET request to '/api/config' using Angular's HttpTestingController. Depends on a properly configured TestBed with HttpClientTestingModule. Uses expectOne to verify the request method and url, flushes a mock response, and asserts the result. Input is a GET request triggered by ConfigService, and output validates response matching the DEFAULT_CONFIG object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/testing.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
TestBed.configureTestingModule({
  providers: [
    ConfigService,
    provideHttpClient(),
    provideHttpClientTesting(),
  ],
});

const httpTesting = TestBed.inject(HttpTestingController);

// Load `ConfigService` and request the current configuration.
const service = TestBed.inject(ConfigService);
const config$ = this.configService.getConfig<Config>();

// `firstValueFrom` subscribes to the `Observable`, which makes the HTTP request,
// and creates a `Promise` of the response.
const configPromise = firstValueFrom(config$);

// At this point, the request is pending, and we can assert it was made
// via the `HttpTestingController`:
const req = httpTesting.expectOne('/api/config', 'Request to load the configuration');

// We can assert various properties of the request if desired.
expect(req.request.method).toBe('GET');

// Flushing the request causes it to complete, delivering the result.
req.flush(DEFAULT_CONFIG);

// We can then assert that the response was successfully delivered by the `ConfigService`:
expect(await configPromise).toEqual(DEFAULT_CONFIG);

// Finally, we can assert that no other requests were made.
httpTesting.verify();
```

TITLE: Eager Component Loading in Angular Routes
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrating eager loading, this snippet shows how to bind components directly to routes, thus downloading all associated JavaScript in the initial load. This can improve navigation responsiveness but increases initial load times.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/define-routes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Routes } from "@angular/router";
import { HomePage } from "./components/home/home-page"
import { LoginPage } from "./components/auth/login-page"

export const routes: Routes = [
  // HomePage and LoginPage are both directly referenced in this config,
  // so their code is eagerly included in the same JavaScript bundle as this file.
  {
    path: "",
    component: HomePage
  },
  {
    path: "login",
    component: LoginPage
  }
]
```

TITLE: Using ViewContainerRef for Dynamic Component Rendering in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use ViewContainerRef to dynamically create and render a LeafContent component when a button is clicked. The new component is appended as a sibling to the InnerItem component.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/programmatic-rendering.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'leaf-content',
  template: `
    This is the leaf content
  `,
})
export class LeafContent {}

@Component({
  selector: 'outer-container',
  template: `
    <p>This is the start of the outer container</p>
    <inner-item />
    <p>This is the end of the outer container</p>
  `,
})
export class OuterContainer {}

@Component({
  selector: 'inner-item',
  template: `
    <button (click)="loadContent()">Load content</button>
  `,
})
export class InnerItem {
  private viewContainer = inject(ViewContainerRef);

  loadContent() {
    this.viewContainer.createComponent(LeafContent);
  }
}
```

import { Logger } from '../logger.service';

@Injectable({
  providedIn: 'root',
})
export class HeroService {
  private logger = inject(Logger);

  getHeroes() {
    this.logger.log('Getting heroes.');
    return HEROES;
  }
}

        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;

        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<T>>;

TITLE: HttpClient get Method (observe?: 'body', responseType?: 'json', generic)
DESCRIPTION: Performs an HTTP GET request, expecting the response body as a JSON object of a specified generic type T. This is a common overload where 'observe' defaults to 'body' and 'responseType' defaults to 'json'. It returns an Observable of the specified type T.

```
get<T>(url: string, options?: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<T>;
```

TITLE: Implementing ngOnChanges in Angular Component
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to implement ngOnChanges lifecycle hook to track input changes in an Angular component. The code demonstrates how to inspect previous and current values of component inputs using SimpleChanges interface.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/lifecycle.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  /* ... */
})
export class UserProfile {
  @Input() name: string = '';

  ngOnChanges(changes: SimpleChanges) {
    for (const inputName in changes) {
      const inputValues = changes[inputName];
      console.log(`Previous ${inputName} == ${inputValues.previousValue}`);
      console.log(`Current ${inputName} == ${inputValues.currentValue}`);
      console.log(`Is first ${inputName} change == ${inputValues.firstChange}`);
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Ensuring Glitch-Free Execution in Effects - Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows a setup that avoids glitches in reactive sequences using signals and computed properties. Demonstrates how state consistency is maintained to prevent intermediate states during updates. Input changes in `counter` trigger recalculations in `evenOrOdd`. Outputs are glitch-free logs. Angular setups requiring knowledge of reactive principles.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
const counter = signal(0);
const evenOrOdd = computed(() => counter() % 2 === 0 ? 'even' : 'odd');
effect(() => console.log(counter() + ' is ' + evenOrOdd()));

counter.set(1);
```

TITLE: Comparing Shorthand and Long-form Structural Directive Syntax (Angular HTML)
DESCRIPTION: Presents two equivalent ways to apply the `SelectDirective` and a `class` attribute to a `<p>` element. The first uses the shorthand `*select`, while the second uses the explicit `<ng-template>` long-form, demonstrating that attributes like `class` remain on the original host element (`<p>`) after Angular expands the shorthand syntax.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/structural-directives.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
<!-- Shorthand syntax: -->
<p class="data-view" *select="let data from source">The data is: {{data}}</p>

<!-- Long-form syntax: -->
<ng-template select let-data [selectFrom]="source">
  <p class="data-view">The data is: {{data}}</p>
</ng-template>
```

TITLE: Testing HTTP Request Interceptor Function - Angular - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Tests a functional HTTP request interceptor that modifies requests by appending an authentication token header. Requires TestBed configuration with HttpClientTestingModule, importing AuthService, and using withInterceptors for implementation. Helps ensure authentication logic is enforced.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/testing.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export function authInterceptor(request: HttpRequest<unknown>, next: HttpHandlerFn): Observable<HttpEvent<unknown>> {
  const authService = inject(AuthService);

  const clonedRequest = request.clone({
    headers: request.headers.append('X-Authentication-Token', authService.getAuthToken()),
  });
  return next(clonedRequest);
}
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

CODE:

const counter = signal(0);

// The counter is: 1

TITLE: Creating Custom Providers Using InjectionToken in Angular (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to create a custom InjectionToken to inject browser APIs, such as localStorage, into Angular services. It defines an InjectionToken named BROWSER_STORAGE, which is provided in the root injector with a factory returning localStorage, allowing BrowserStorageService to consume this dependency. Key parameters include the token name and the factory function; the service provides get and set wrappers for interacting with localStorage. This pattern enables easy mocking of browser APIs during testing and supports strong typing and dependency inversion.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/di-in-action.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Inject, Injectable, InjectionToken } from '@angular/core';\n\nexport const BROWSER_STORAGE = new InjectionToken<Storage>('Browser Storage', {\n  providedIn: 'root',\n  factory: () => localStorage\n});\n\n@Injectable({\n  providedIn: 'root'\n})\nexport class BrowserStorageService {\n  public storage = inject(BROWSER_STORAGE);\n\n  get(key: string) {\n    return this.storage.getItem(key);\n  }\n\n  set(key: string, value: string) {\n    this.storage.setItem(key, value);\n  }\n}
```

TITLE: Integrating the Dynamic Form Component in the Main Application Component (Angular)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how the root `AppComponent` in Angular integrates the dynamic form. It injects `QuestionService` to get the question data (as an Observable) and uses the async pipe in its template (`app.component.html`, not shown but implied) to pass this data as an input (`[questions]`) to the `<app-dynamic-form>` component instance.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Component }          from '@angular/core';

import { QuestionService }  from './question.service';
import { QuestionBase }     from './question-base';
import { Observable }       from 'rxjs';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  template: `
    <div>
      <h2>Job Application for Heroes</h2>
      <app-dynamic-form [questions]="questions$ | async"></app-dynamic-form>
    </div>
  `,
  providers:  [QuestionService]
})
export class AppComponent {
  questions$: Observable<QuestionBase<any>[]>;

  constructor(service: QuestionService) {
    this.questions$ = service.getQuestions();
  }
}

```

TITLE: Testing Routing Component in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to test a routing component (DashboardComponent) using Angular's router testing harness. It demonstrates setting up the test module with router configuration and writing a test for navigation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_30

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
describe('DashboardComponent tests', () => {
  let fixture: ComponentFixture<DashboardComponent>;
  let harness: RouterTestingHarness;

  beforeEach(async () => {
    await TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      imports: [DashboardComponent],
      providers: [
        provideRouter([{ path: 'heroes/:id', component: HeroDetailComponent }]),
      ],
    }).compileComponents();

    harness = await RouterTestingHarness.create();
    fixture = harness.routeDebugElement.componentInstance;
  });

  it('should navigate to hero details', async () => {
    const heroes = [{ id: 1, name: 'Superwoman' }];
    const heroServiceSpy = TestBed.inject(HeroService) as jasmine.SpyObj<HeroService>;
    heroServiceSpy.getHeroes.and.returnValue(of(heroes));
    fixture.detectChanges();

    await harness.navigateByUrl('/dashboard');
    const dashboardHero = harness.routeNativeElement.querySelector('dashboard-hero');
    dashboardHero.click();
    expect(TestBed.inject(Router).url).toBe('/heroes/1');
  });
});
```

TITLE: Creating a Service to Generate FormGroups Dynamically in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Implements the `QuestionControlService` in Angular using TypeScript. This service dynamically creates an Angular `FormGroup` based on an array of `QuestionBase` objects, initializing each `FormControl` with its value and applying validation rules (like `Validators.required`) if the question metadata specifies it.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Injectable }   from '@angular/core';
import { FormControl, FormGroup, Validators } from '@angular/forms';

import { QuestionBase } from './question-base';

@Injectable()
export class QuestionControlService {
  toFormGroup(questions: QuestionBase<string>[] ) {
    const group: any = {};

    questions.forEach(question => {
      group[question.key] = question.required ? new FormControl(question.value || '', Validators.required)
                                              : new FormControl(question.value || '');
    });
    return new FormGroup(group);
  }
}

```

  /*...*/
})
export class CustomMenuItem {
  text: string;
}

@Component({
  selector: 'custom-menu',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomMenu {
  @ContentChildren(CustomMenuItem) items: QueryList<CustomMenuItem>;

  ngAfterContentInit() {
    this.items.forEach(item => {
      console.log(item.text);
    });
  }
}

@Component({
  selector: 'user-profile',
  template: `
    <custom-menu>
      <custom-menu-item>Cheese</custom-menu-item>
      <custom-menu-item>Tomato</custom-menu-item>
    </custom-menu>
  `
})
export class UserProfile { }
```

import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({

TITLE: Defining HttpClient Post Method Signatures - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines the initial method signatures for `HttpClient.post` in Angular. These overloads cover sending HTTP POST requests with a request body, showing how the return type (`Observable`) varies based on the `observe` option ('body' or 'events') and the `responseType` ('arraybuffer', 'blob', 'text', 'json'). They also include the `transferCache` option specific to POST requests.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/common/http/index.api.md#_snippet_22

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
post(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'arraybuffer';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<ArrayBuffer>; // observe: 'body', arraybuffer response
    post(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'blob';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<Blob>; // observe: 'body', blob response
    post(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'text';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<string>; // observe: 'body', text response
    post(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
```

it('should display hero details when given a valid id', async () => {
  const expectedHero: Hero = { id: 42, name: 'Buzzy' };
  heroServiceSpy.getHero.and.returnValue(of(expectedHero));

  await harness.navigateByUrl('/heroes/42');
  fixture.detectChanges();

  expect(page.nameDisplay.textContent).toBe(expectedHero.name);
});

it('should navigate back to list when given an invalid id', async () => {
  heroServiceSpy.getHero.and.returnValue(
    throwError(() => new Error('HeroService.getHero Error'))
  );

  await harness.navigateByUrl('/heroes/999');
  fixture.detectChanges();

  expect(page.saveBtn).toBeNull();
  expect(TestBed.inject(Router).url).toBe('/heroes/list');
});
```

TITLE: Custom Accessible Progress Bar Implementation in Angular
DESCRIPTION: A complete implementation of an accessible progress bar component with TypeScript and HTML templates. It uses host binding for ARIA attributes and proper role assignment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/best-practices/a11y.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, Input, HostBinding } from '@angular/core';

/**
 * Example progressbar component.
 */
@Component({
  selector: 'app-progress-bar',
  template: '<ng-content></ng-content>',
  standalone: true,
})
export class ProgressBarComponent {
  /** Current value of the progressbar. */
  @Input() value = 0;

  /** ARIA role for progressbar element. */
  @HostBinding('attr.role') role = 'progressbar';

  /** Sets aria valuenow to current value. */
  @HostBinding('attr.aria-valuenow') get ariaValuenow() {
    return this.value;
  }
}

```

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<h2>Progress bar example</h2>

<label for="progress-example">Example Progress</label>
<input
  id="progress-example"
  type="range"
  min="0"
  max="100"
  [(ngModel)]="progress"
/>

<!-- The progressbar element has a label for screen reader users. -->
<app-progress-bar [value]="progress" aria-label="Example of a progress bar">
  {{ progress }}%
</app-progress-bar>

```

TITLE: Defining Angular Component with Input Setter and Coercion - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines an Angular component 'SubmitButton' which uses a private '_disabled' boolean variable with getter and setter. The setter coerces the input value. This pattern is used for ensuring that non-boolean values like an empty string are handled as false.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tools/cli/template-typecheck.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'submit-button',
  template: `
    <div class="wrapper">
      <button [disabled]="disabled">Submit</button>
    </div>
  `,
})
class SubmitButton {
  private _disabled: boolean;

  @Input()
  get disabled(): boolean {
    return this._disabled;
  }

  set disabled(value: boolean) {
    this._disabled = value;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Accessing External Elements in Component Harness
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to access elements outside the component's host element using documentRootLocatorFactory for overlay content.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/creating-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
class MyPopupHarness extends ComponentHarness {
  static hostSelector = 'my-popup';

  /** Gets a `HarnessLoader` whose root element is the popup's content element. */
  async getHarnessLoaderForContent(): Promise<HarnessLoader> {
    const rootLocator = this.documentRootLocatorFactory();
    return rootLocator.harnessLoaderFor('my-popup-content');
  }
}
```

TITLE: HighlightDirective Test Suite
DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive tests for HighlightDirective covering various scenarios including default colors, bound inputs, and DOM manipulation.

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should have three highlighted elements', () => {
    const elements = fixture.debugElement.queryAll(By.directive(HighlightDirective));
    expect(elements.length).toBe(3);
});

it('should color 1st <h2> background "yellow"', () => {
    const bgColor = fixture.nativeElement.querySelector('h2').style.backgroundColor;
    expect(bgColor).toBe('yellow');
});

it('should color 2nd <h2> background w/ default color', () => {
    const h2 = fixture.debugElement.queryAll(By.css('h2'))[1];
    const dir = h2.injector.get(HighlightDirective) as HighlightDirective;
    const bgColor = h2.nativeElement.style.backgroundColor;
    expect(bgColor).toBe(dir.defaultColor);
});
```

TITLE: Logging HTTP Response Events in an Interceptor - Angular HttpClient - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Implements a functional interceptor that inspects all HTTP events in the response Observable and logs the URL and status when the final response is received. Utilizes RxJS's tap operator to perform side effects. Requires Angular HttpClient and RxJS. Expects an outgoing HttpRequest and a next handler. Outputs the observable event stream unmodified, with logging added.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/interceptors.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export function loggingInterceptor(req: HttpRequest<unknown>, next: HttpHandlerFn): Observable<HttpEvent<unknown>> {\n  return next(req).pipe(tap(event => {\n    if (event.type === HttpEventType.Response) {\n      console.log(req.url, 'returned a response with status', event.status);\n    }\n  }));\n}
```

TITLE: Testing Angular @defer blocks with TestBed
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to test @defer blocks using TestBed APIs, configuring manual control of defer states, and stepping through different rendering states during testing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/templates/defer.md#2025-04-22_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
it('should render a defer block in different states', async () => {
  // configures the defer block behavior to start in "paused" state for manual control.
  TestBed.configureTestingModule({deferBlockBehavior: DeferBlockBehavior.Manual});
  @Component({
    // ...
    template: `
      @defer {
        <large-component />
      } @placeholder {
        Placeholder
      } @loading {
        Loading...
      }
    `
  })
  class ComponentA {}
  // Create component fixture.
  const componentFixture = TestBed.createComponent(ComponentA);
  // Retrieve the list of all defer block fixtures and get the first block.
  const deferBlockFixture = (await componentFixture.getDeferBlocks())[0];
  // Renders placeholder state by default.
  expect(componentFixture.nativeElement.innerHTML).toContain('Placeholder');
  // Render loading state and verify rendered output.
  await deferBlockFixture.render(DeferBlockState.Loading);
  expect(componentFixture.nativeElement.innerHTML).toContain('Loading');
  // Render final state and verify the output.
  await deferBlockFixture.render(DeferBlockState.Complete);
  expect(componentFixture.nativeElement.innerHTML).toContain('large works!');
});
```

TITLE: Creating a Custom Validator Factory Function in Angular (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines a custom synchronous validator factory function `forbiddenNameValidator`. This factory accepts a `RegExp` parameter (`nameRe`) and returns a `ValidatorFn`. The returned validator function takes an `AbstractControl` and checks if its value matches the forbidden pattern specified by the regex. If the name is forbidden (test passes), it returns an error object `{ 'forbiddenName': { value: control.value } }`; otherwise (if valid or control has no value), it returns `null`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/form-validation.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
/** A actor's name can't match the given regular expression */
export function forbiddenNameValidator(nameRe: RegExp): ValidatorFn {
  return (control: AbstractControl): ValidationErrors | null => {
    const forbidden = nameRe.test(control.value);
    return forbidden ? {forbiddenName: {value: control.value}} : null;
  };
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Angular Component with i18n Features
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript implementation of an Angular component that works with the i18n template. It includes properties for the logo, wolf count, timestamps, gender selection, and user name that demonstrate various i18n scenarios.

import {Component} from '@angular/core';

  selector: 'app-root',

})
export class AppComponent {
  wolves = 0;
  gender = 'female';
  fly = true;
  logo = 'https://angular.io/assets/images/logos/angular/angular.png';
  heroes: string[] = ['Magneta', 'Celeritas', 'Dynama'];
  inc(i: number) {
    this.wolves = Math.min(5, Math.max(0, this.wolves + i));
  }
  male() {
    this.gender = 'male';
  }
  female() {
    this.gender = 'female';
  }
  other() {
    this.gender = 'other';

  gender2 = 'male';

  // END

TITLE: Defining Dynamic Classes Object for NgClass in Angular Component (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Implements a method `setCurrentClasses` within the Angular component that dynamically creates an object. This object's keys are CSS class names ('saveable', 'modified', 'special'), and their boolean values, derived from other component properties (`canSave`, `isUnchanged`, `isSpecial`), determine whether `NgClass` should add or remove the corresponding class in the template.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/overview.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core';
// ... other imports

@Component({
  // ... component metadata
})
export class AppComponent implements OnInit {
  canSave = true;
  isSpecial = true;
  isUnchanged = true;

  currentClasses: Record<string, boolean> = {};

  ngOnInit() {
    this.setCurrentClasses();
  }

  setCurrentClasses() {
    // CSS classes: added/removed per current state of component properties
    this.currentClasses = {
      'saveable': this.canSave,
      'modified': !this.isUnchanged,
      'special': this.isSpecial
    };
  }

  // ... other component logic
}
```

TITLE: Programmatic Navigation using router.navigate() in Angular Components (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to perform navigation programmatically within an Angular component's TypeScript code. It involves injecting the `Router` service and calling its `navigate()` method with an array of path segments. Examples show standard navigation, navigation with route parameters (`userId`), and navigation with query parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/navigate-to-routes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Router } from '@angular/router';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-dashboard',
  template: `
    <button (click)="navigateToProfile()">View Profile</button>
  `
})
export class AppDashboard {
  private router = inject(Router);

  navigateToProfile() {
    // Standard navigation
    this.router.navigate(['/profile']);

    // With route parameters
    this.router.navigate(['/users', userId]);

    // With query parameters
    this.router.navigate(['/search'], {
      queryParams: { category: 'books', sort: 'price' }
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Enabling Reactive Forms in Angular Components
DESCRIPTION: Imports `ReactiveFormsModule` into `DynamicFormComponent` and `DynamicFormQuestionComponent` to enable the use of reactive form directives like `formGroup`, `formControlName`, etc., which are essential for building dynamic forms.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Component, Input, OnInit }  from '@angular/core';
import { FormGroup }                 from '@angular/forms';

import { QuestionBase }              from './question-base';
import { QuestionControlService }    from './question-control.service';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-dynamic-form',
  templateUrl: './dynamic-form.component.html',
  providers: [ QuestionControlService ]
})
export class DynamicFormComponent implements OnInit {

  @Input() questions: QuestionBase<string>[] | null = [];
  form!: FormGroup;
  payLoad = '';

  constructor(private qcs: QuestionControlService) {}

  ngOnInit() {
    this.form = this.qcs.toFormGroup(this.questions as QuestionBase<string>[]);
  }

  onSubmit() {
    this.payLoad = JSON.stringify(this.form.getRawValue());
  }
}

```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import { Component, Input } from '@angular/core';
import { FormGroup }        from '@angular/forms';

import { QuestionBase }     from './question-base';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-question',
  templateUrl: './dynamic-form-question.component.html'
})
export class DynamicFormQuestionComponent {
  @Input() question!: QuestionBase<string>;
  @Input() form!: FormGroup;
  get isValid() { return this.form.controls[this.question.key].valid; }
}

```

TITLE: Using Class Bindings in Angular Templates
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the preferred approach of using direct class bindings instead of ngClass directive for better readability and performance
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/best-practices/style-guide.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<!-- PREFER -->
<div [class.admin]="isAdmin" [class.dense]="density === 'high'">

<!-- AVOID -->
<div [ngClass]="{admin: isAdmin, dense: density === 'high'}">
```

TITLE: Complete HomeComponent with HousingLocation Integration (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This code shows the final state of the `src/app/home/home.component.ts` file. It includes the necessary imports (`Component`, `CommonModule`, `HousingLocation`), the component decorator (`@Component`), and the `HomeComponent` class definition with the `housingLocation` property typed and initialized with sample data according to the `HousingLocation` interface.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tutorials/first-app/steps/04-interfaces/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common';
import { HousingLocationComponent } from '../housing-location/housing-location.component';
import { HousingLocation } from '../housinglocation';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-home',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [
    CommonModule,
    HousingLocationComponent
  ],
  template: `
    <section>
      <form>
        <input type="text" placeholder="Filter by city">
        <button class="primary" type="button">Search</button>
      </form>
    </section>
    <section class="results">
      <app-housing-location [housingLocation]="housingLocation"></app-housing-location>
    </section>
  `,
  styleUrls: ['./home.component.css'],
})
export class HomeComponent {
  readonly baseUrl = 'https://angular.io/assets/images/tutorials/faa';

  housingLocation: HousingLocation = {
    id: 9999,
    name: 'Test Home',
    city: 'Test city',
    state: 'ST',
    photo: `${this.baseUrl}/example-house.jpg`,
    availableUnits: 99,
    wifi: true,
    laundry: false,
  };
}
```

TITLE: Enabling Debug Tools in Angular - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to enable Angular debug tools by bootstrapping an Angular module and then invoking the `enableDebugTools` method. The tools provide developers with access to additional debugging capabilities via the browser's developer console. It requires the Angular core, platform-browser, and platform-browser-dynamic packages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/contributing-docs/debugging-tips.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {ApplicationRef} from '@angular/core';
import {platformBrowserDynamic} from '@angular/platform-browser-dynamic';
import {enableDebugTools} from '@angular/platform-browser';

platformBrowserDynamic().bootstrapModule(AppModule)
  .then(moduleRef => {
    const applicationRef = moduleRef.injector.get(ApplicationRef);
    const appComponent = applicationRef.components[0];
    enableDebugTools(appComponent);
  })
```

TITLE: Accessing Route Snapshot for Static Route Information - Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to utilize route snapshots to capture static information about the current route, such as path, parameters, and query parameters. ActivatedRouteSnapshot is used, which is imported from '@angular/router'. Snapshots are static and ideal for one-time accesses to route data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/read-route-state.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { ActivatedRoute, ActivatedRouteSnapshot } from '@angular/router';

@Component({ ... })
export class UserProfileComponent {
  readonly userId: string;
  private activatedRoute = inject(ActivatedRoute);

  constructor() {
    // Example URL: https://www.angular.dev/users/123?role=admin&status=active#contact

    // Access route parameters from snapshot
    this.userId = this.route.snapshot.paramMap.get('id');

    // Access multiple route elements
    const snapshot = this.route.snapshot;
    console.log({
      url: snapshot.url,           // https://www.angular.dev
      // Route parameters object: {id: '123'}
      params: snapshot.params,
      // Query parameters object: {role: 'admin', status: 'active'}
      queryParams: snapshot.queryParams,  // Query parameters
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Binding and Event Handling in Angular Template
DESCRIPTION: Defines input handling and event binding within Angular templates using ngModel, demonstrating two-way data binding and click event administration within component properties using signal inputs.

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  template: `
    <input [(ngModel)]="inputA()" />
    <div (click)="inputB = false()">
    </div>
  `,
  host: {
    '(click)': 'inputC = true()',
  },
})
class TwoWayBinding {
  readonly inputA = input('');
  readonly inputB = input(true);
  readonly inputC = input(false);
  readonly inputD = input(false);
}
```

TITLE: Child Component Implementation for Two-way Binding in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Implements the child component side of two-way binding using the model property. Shows how to update the bound value and handle user interactions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/templates/two-way-binding.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Component, model } from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-counter',
  template: `
    <button (click)="updateCount(-1)">-</button>
    <span>{{ count() }}</span>
    <button (click)="updateCount(+1)">+</button>
  `,
})
export class CounterComponent {
  count = model<number>(0);

  updateCount(amount: number): void {
    this.count.update(currentCount => currentCount + amount);
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using manualChangeDetection for Fine-Grained Control in Angular Tests
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the manualChangeDetection function to disable automatic change detection and manually control it during an asynchronous operation. It checks the state of a component while an async action is in progress.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/using-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('checks state while async action is in progress', async () => {
  const buttonHarness = loader.getHarness(MyButtonHarness);
  await manualChangeDetection(async () => {
    await buttonHarness.click();
    fixture.detectChanges();
    // Check expectations while async click operation is in progress.
    expect(isProgressSpinnerVisible()).toBe(true);
    await fixture.whenStable();
    // Check expectations after async click operation complete.
    expect(isProgressSpinnerVisible()).toBe(false);
  });
});
```

TITLE: Using Built-in Pipes in Angular Components

CODE:
```
import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import { CurrencyPipe, DatePipe, TitleCasePipe } from '@angular/common';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  imports: [CurrencyPipe, DatePipe, TitleCasePipe],
  template: `
    <main>
       <!-- Transform the company name to title-case and
       transform the purchasedOn date to a locale-formatted string -->
<h1>Purchases from {{ company | titlecase }} on {{ purchasedOn | date }}</h1>

	    <!-- Transform the amount to a currency-formatted string -->
      <p>Total: {{ amount | currency }}</p>
    </main>
  `,
})
export class ShoppingCartComponent {
  amount = 123.45;
  company = 'acme corporation';
  purchasedOn = '2024-07-08';
}
```

TITLE: Testing Angular Component Interaction in Spec - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript unit test examples using Angular testing utilities, focusing on component input interaction and template references. Demonstrates use of Angular's TestBed, inline test components, and input querying using references in templates. Dependencies: Angular Component and input utilities, TestBed, and NgIf for template logic.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {NgIf} from '@angular/common';
import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';
import {TestBed} from '@angular/core/testing';

import {AppComponent} from '.';

describe('bla', () => {
  it('should work', () => {
    @Component({
      template: `
        <app-component #ref />
        {{ref.input.ok}}
        `,
    })
    class TestCmp {}
    TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      imports: [AppComponent],
    });
    const fixture = TestBed.createComponent(TestCmp);
    fixture.detectChanges();
  });

  it('', () => {
    it('', () => {
      // Define `Ng2Component`
      @Component({
        selector: 'ng2',
        standalone: true,
        template: '<div *ngIf="show()"><ng1A></ng1A> | <ng1B></ng1B></div>',
        imports: [NgIf],
      })
      class Ng2Component {
        show = input<boolean>(false);
      }
    });
  });
});

```
