```
TITLE: HttpClient get Method (observe: 'response', responseType?: 'json')
DESCRIPTION: Performs an HTTP GET request, expecting the response body as a JSON object. The 'observe' option is set to 'response', causing the method to return an Observable of HttpResponse<Object>, providing access to the full response including headers and status. The responseType defaults to 'json'.

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
get(url: string, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<Object>>;
```

TITLE: Implementing a Page Object for Angular Component Testing
DESCRIPTION: This code creates a Page class to encapsulate component DOM manipulation and testing logic for HeroDetailComponent. It provides methods to query elements, check visibility status, and simulate user events like clicking buttons or typing in inputs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_38

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
class Page {
  // get the hero component title
  get title() {
    return this.fixture.nativeElement.querySelector('h2').textContent;
  }

  // get the hero name input box
  get nameInput() {
    return this.fixture.nativeElement.querySelector('input');
  }

  // get the hero name from the input box
  get nameDisplay() {
    return this.nameInput.value;
  }

  get saveBtn() {
    return this.fixture.nativeElement.querySelector('button[type=button]');
  }

  get cancelBtn() {
    return this.fixture.nativeElement.querySelectorAll('button')[1];
  }

  constructor(private fixture: ComponentFixture<HeroDetailComponent>) { }

  //// query for the DOM elements

  // Clicking the buttons doesn't do anything in this faked version
  // In a real app, it would save or cancel and navigate back to the list
  clickSave() {
    this.saveBtn.click();
  }

  clickCancel() {
    this.cancelBtn.click();
  }
}
```

TITLE: Defining and Accessing Route Parameters - Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates defining route parameters in a Routes configuration and accessing them in a component by subscribing to params observable. Route parameters must be defined in the path and accessible within components using ActivatedRoute from '@angular/router'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/read-route-state.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Routes } from '@angular/router';
import { ProductComponent } from './product/product.component';

const routes: Routes = [
  { path: 'product/:id', component: ProductComponent }
];
```

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Component, inject, signal } from '@angular/core';
import { ActivatedRoute } from '@angular/router';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-product-detail',
  template: `<h1>Product Details: {{ productId() }}</h1>`,
})
export class ProductDetailComponent {
  productId = signal('');
  private activatedRoute = inject(ActivatedRoute);

  constructor() {
    // Access route parameters
    this.activatedRoute.params.subscribe((params) => {
      this.productId.set(params['id']);
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Testing HeroDetailComponent with Page Object in Angular
DESCRIPTION: These tests demonstrate using a Page object to simplify component testing. They verify that the component displays the correct hero details, allows editing the hero name, and handles button clicks appropriately.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_40

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should display that hero\'s name', () => {
  expect(page.nameDisplay).toBe(expectedHero.name);
});

it('should navigate when click cancel', () => {
  page.clickCancel();
  expect(page.navigateSpy.calls.any())
    .withContext('router.navigate called')
    .toBe(true);
});

it('should save when click save but not navigate immediately', () => {
  // Get service injected into component and spy on its`saveHero` method.
  // It delegates to fake `HeroService.updateHero` which delivers a safe test result.
  const hds = fixture.debugElement.injector.get(HeroDetailService);
  const saveSpy = spyOn(hds, 'saveHero').and.callThrough();

  page.clickSave();

  expect(saveSpy.calls.any())
    .withContext('HeroDetailService.save called')
    .toBe(true);
  expect(page.navigateSpy.calls.any())
    .withContext('router.navigate not called')
    .toBe(false);
});
```

TITLE: Class-based HTTP Interceptor Implementation - Angular - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines an HTTP interceptor as a class to modify outgoing requests by appending an authentication token. This requires dependency on AuthService and proper TestBed configuration. Inputs involve HTTP requests handled by HttpClient, and outputs are modified requests with additional headers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/testing.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
@Injectable()
export class AuthInterceptor implements HttpInterceptor {
  private authService = inject(AuthService);

  intercept(request: HttpRequest<unknown>, next: HttpHandler): Observable<HttpEvent<unknown>> {
    const clonedRequest = request.clone({
      headers: request.headers.append('X-Authentication-Token', this.authService.getAuthToken()),
    });
    return next.handle(clonedRequest);
  }
}
```

TITLE: Testing Component Inside a Test Host in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set up a test host component to test a DashboardHeroComponent. It shows the configuration of the testing module and the actual test cases.

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
describe('DashboardHeroComponent when tested directly', () => {
  let comp: DashboardHeroComponent;
  let expectedHero: Hero;
  let fixture: ComponentFixture<DashboardHeroComponent>;
  let heroEl: HTMLElement;

  beforeEach(() => {
    expectedHero = { id: 42, name: 'Test Name' };

    TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      imports: [DashboardHeroComponent],
    });

    fixture = TestBed.createComponent(DashboardHeroComponent);
    comp = fixture.componentInstance;
    heroEl = fixture.nativeElement.querySelector('.hero');
    fixture.detectChanges(); // trigger initial data binding
  });

  // tests here
});
```

TITLE: Component with Service Dependency Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Implements a WelcomeComponent that depends on an injected UserService to display personalized welcome messages, demonstrating component-service interaction.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core';
import { UserService } from './user.service';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-welcome',
  template: '<h3 class="welcome"><i>{{welcome}}</i></h3>'
})
export class WelcomeComponent implements OnInit {
  welcome = '';
  constructor(private userService: UserService) { }

  ngOnInit(): void {
    this.welcome = this.userService.isLoggedIn ?
      'Welcome, ' + this.userService.user.name : 'Please log in.';
  }
}
```

TITLE: Creating a Signal from RxJS Observable using toSignal in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the toSignal function to create a signal from an RxJS Observable. It creates a counter signal that updates every second based on an interval Observable.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/ecosystem/rxjs-interop/signals-interop.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import { AsyncPipe } from '@angular/common';
import { interval } from 'rxjs';
import { toSignal } from '@angular/core/rxjs-interop';

@Component({
  template: `{{ counter() }}`,
})
export class Ticker {
  counterObservable = interval(1000);

  // Get a `Signal` representing the `counterObservable`'s value.
  counter = toSignal(this.counterObservable, {initialValue: 0});
}
```

TITLE: Conditional Rendering with NG If in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Explores various conditional rendering strategies in Angular using ngIf directive and @if shorthand along with component properties, ensuring dynamic content rendering based on component state. Inputs are defined using Angularâ€™s signal input.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  template: `
    @if (first()) {
      {{first()}}
    }

    <ng-template [ngIf]="second()">
      {{second()}}
    </ng-template>

    <div *ngIf="third()">
      {{third()}}
    </div>

    <div *ngIf="fourth()">
      {{notTheInput}}
    </div>

    @if (fifth()) {
      {{notTheInput}}
    }
  `,
})
export class MyComp {
  readonly first = input(true);
  readonly second = input(false);
  readonly third = input(true);
  readonly fourth = input(true);
  readonly fifth = input(true);
}
```

TITLE: Correct usage of *ngFor with 'let' keyword in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example shows the correct syntax for an Angular *ngFor expression, with the required `let` keyword present. This properly scopes the item variable and avoids the diagnostic error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/extended-diagnostics/NG8105.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  // The `let` keyword is now present in the `*ngFor` expression,
  // no diagnostic messages are emitted in this case.
  template: `<div *ngFor="let item of items">{{ item }}</div>`,
})
class MyComponent {
  items = [1, 2, 3];
}
```

TITLE: Simulating User Input with dispatchEvent
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to properly simulate user input in tests by setting an input element's value and dispatching an input event to ensure Angular detects the change.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should convert hero name to Title Case', () => {
  // get the name's input and display elements from the DOM
  const hostElement: HTMLElement = fixture.nativeElement;
  const nameInput: HTMLInputElement = hostElement.querySelector('input')!;
  const nameDisplay: HTMLElement = hostElement.querySelector('span')!;

  // simulate user entering a new name into the input box
  nameInput.value = 'quick BROWN  fOx';

  // Dispatch a DOM event so that Angular learns of input value change.
  nameInput.dispatchEvent(new Event('input'));

  // Tell Angular to update the display binding through the title pipe
  fixture.detectChanges();

  expect(nameDisplay.textContent).toBe('Quick Brown  Fox');
});
```

TITLE: Example of Scaling with Change Detection - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: An example illustrating good and bad practices in Angular change detection by avoiding costly computations during UI updates. It demonstrates how avoiding inline computations and precomputing values can enhance performance.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/contributing-docs/debugging-tips.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  template: '<button [enabled]="isEnabled">{{title}}</button>'
})
class FancyButton {
  // GOOD: no computation, just return the value
  isEnabled: boolean;

  // BAD: computes the final value upon request
  _title: String;
  get title(): String { return this._title.trim().toUpperCase(); }
}

        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'blob';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<Blob>>;

```
TITLE: Adding HostListener Event Handlers in Attribute Directive (Angular, TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This directive imports HostListener from '@angular/core' and defines handlers for mouseenter and mouseleave events. When the mouse enters the host element, the background color is set; when it leaves, the highlight is removed. The code uses the @HostListener decorator to listen for user events. Inputs: mouse events. Output: dynamic background color changes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/attribute-directives.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Directive, ElementRef, HostListener } from '@angular/core';

@Directive({
  selector: '[appHighlight]'
})
export class HighlightDirective {
  constructor(private el: ElementRef) {}

  @HostListener('mouseenter') onMouseEnter() {
    this.highlight('yellow');
  }

  @HostListener('mouseleave') onMouseLeave() {
    this.highlight('');
  }

  private highlight(color: string) {
    this.el.nativeElement.style.backgroundColor = color;
  }
}
```

DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to define a `FormGroup` with optional controls using an interface (`LoginForm`) with optional properties (`password?`). SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/typed-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
```ts
interface LoginForm {
  email: FormControl<string>;
  password?: FormControl<string>;
}

const login = new FormGroup<LoginForm>({
  email: new FormControl('', {nonNullable: true}),
  // password is added initially, but can be removed
  password: new FormControl('', {nonNullable: true}), 
});

login.removeControl('password');
```
```

TITLE: Implementing Async Validator Function in TypeScript for Angular Forms
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to correctly implement an asynchronous validator function in Angular. The function 'isTenAsync' checks if the control value is 10 and returns an Observable of ValidationErrors or null, adhering to the AsyncValidatorFn API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG01101.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
export function isTenAsync(control: AbstractControl): 
  Observable<ValidationErrors | null> {
    const v: number = control.value;
    if (v !== 10) {
    // Emit an object with a validation error.
      return of({ 'notTen': true, 'requiredValue': 10 });
    }
    // Emit null, to indicate no error occurred.
    return of(null);
  }
```

TITLE: Correcting Optional Chain Usage with Nullable Type in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the correct usage of the optional chain operator by making the user property nullable. The type is updated to include null, allowing for the safe use of the optional chain operator in the template.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/extended-diagnostics/NG8107.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  // If `user` is nullish, `name` won't be evaluated and the expression will
  // return the nullish value (`null` or `undefined`).
  template: `<div>{{ user?.name }}</div>`,
})
class MyComponent {
  user: { name: string } | null = { name: 'Angelino' };
}
```

TITLE: Utilizing Query Parameters for URL State Management - Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet exhibits how to advance URL state management by utilizing query parameters to manage optional components or UI settings such as sorting options. The router's navigate method and ActivatedRoute's queryParams observable are used within a component to handle URL changes and reactively update the UI.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/routing/read-route-state.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
// Single parameter structure
// /products?category=electronics
router.navigate(['/products'], {
  queryParams: { category: 'electronics' }
});

// Multiple parameters
// /products?category=electronics&sort=price&page=1
router.navigate(['/products'], {
  queryParams: {
    category: 'electronics',
    sort: 'price',
    page: 1
  }
});
```

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { ActivatedRoute, Router } from '@angular/router';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-product-list',
  template: `
    <div>
      <select (change)="updateSort($event)">
        <option value="price">Price</option>
        <option value="name">Name</option>
      </select>
      <!-- Products list -->
    </div>
  `
})
export class ProductListComponent implements OnInit {
  private route = inject(ActivatedRoute);
  private router = inject(Router);

  constructor() {
    // Access query parameters reactively
    this.route.queryParams.subscribe(params => {
      const sort = params['sort'] || 'price';
      const page = Number(params['page']) || 1;
      this.loadProducts(sort, page);
    });
  }

  updateSort(event: Event) {
    const sort = (event.target as HTMLSelectElement).value;
    // Update URL with new query parameter
    this.router.navigate([], {
      queryParams: { sort },
      queryParamsHandling: 'merge' // Preserve other query parameters
    });
  }
}
```

CODE:
```

    setControl<K extends string & keyof TControl>(name: K, control: TControl[K], options?: {
        emitEvent?: boolean;
    }): void;
    // (undocumented)
    setControl(this: FormGroup<{
        [key: string]: AbstractControl<any>;
    }>, name: string, control: AbstractControl, options?: {
        emitEvent?: boolean;
    }): void;
}
```

TITLE: Manually Manage Angular PendingTasks (TypeScript)

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const taskService = inject(PendingTasks);
const taskCleanup = taskService.add();
try {
  await doSomeWorkThatNeedsToBeRendered();
} catch {
  // handle error
} finally {
  taskCleanup();
}
```

TITLE: Lazy-loading Components with NgComponentOutlet in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to lazy-load a component using NgComponentOutlet and a dynamic import. The AdvancedSettings component is loaded and displayed upon clicking a button.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/programmatic-rendering.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  ...,
  template: `
    <section>
      <h2>Basic settings</h2>
      <basic-settings />
    </section>
    <section>
      <h2>Advanced settings</h2>
      <button (click)="loadAdvanced()" *ngIf="!advancedSettings">
        Load advanced settings
      </button>
      <ng-container *ngComponentOutlet="advancedSettings" />
    </section>
  `
})
export class AdminSettings {
  advancedSettings: {new(): AdvancedSettings} | undefined;

  async loadAdvanced() {
    const { AdvancedSettings } = await import('path/to/advanced_settings.js');
    this.advancedSettings = AdvancedSettings;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Testing with Provider Overrides
DESCRIPTION: Test cases that use the overridden HeroDetailService to verify component behavior, including checking if service methods were called with the right parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_59

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should have called `getHero`', () => {
  expect(heroDetailServiceSpy.getHero.calls.count()).toBe(1, 'getHero called once');
});

it('should display stub hero name', () => {
  expect(page.nameDisplay.textContent).toBe(heroDetailServiceSpy.testHero.name);
});

it('should save stub hero change', fakeAsync(() => {
  const origName = heroDetailServiceSpy.testHero.name;
  const newName = 'New Name';

  page.nameInput.value = newName;
  page.nameInput.dispatchEvent(new Event('input')); // tell Angular

  expect(component.hero.name).toBe(newName, 'component hero has new name');
  expect(heroDetailServiceSpy.testHero.name).toBe(origName, 'service hero unchanged before save');

  page.saveBtn.click();
  expect(heroDetailServiceSpy.saveHero.calls.count()).toBe(1, 'saveHero called once');

  tick();  // wait for async save to complete
  expect(heroDetailServiceSpy.testHero.name).toBe(newName, 'service hero has new name after save');
  expect(page.navigateSpy.calls.any()).toBe(true, 'router.navigate called');
}));
```

TITLE: Creating Parameterized Angular Pipe
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to implement a custom pipe that accepts additional parameters for transformation. Includes logic for conditional transformation based on a format parameter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/templates/pipes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
import { Pipe, PipeTransform } from '@angular/core';

@Pipe({
  name: 'myCustomTransformation',
})
export class MyCustomTransformationPipe implements PipeTransform {
  transform(value: string, format: string): string {
    let msg = `My custom transformation of ${value}.`

    if (format === 'uppercase') {
      return msg.toUpperCase()
    } else {
      return msg
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Ensuring Singleton and Transient Dependencies with Angular Injector - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Explains the default singleton policy of Angular's injector and demonstrates ways to achieve transient instances via child injectors or registered factory functions. Dependencies: Angular injector; inputs: requested types or factory functions; outputs: singleton or transient object instances. Constraints include ensuring that child injectors are used only when transient instantiation is desired.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
inj.get(MyClass) === inj.get(MyClass); //always holds
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var child = inj.resolveAndCreateChild([MyClass]);
child.get(MyClass);
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var inj = Injector.resolveAndCreate([
  bind('MyClassFactory').toFactory(dep => () => new MyClass(dep), [SomeDependency])
]);

var factory = inj.get('MyClassFactory');
var instance1 = factory(), instance2 = factory();
// Depends on the implementation of MyClass, but generally holds.
expect(instance1).not.toBe(instance2);
```

TITLE: HttpClient get Method (observe: 'response', responseType?: 'json', generic)
```

get<T>(url: string, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;

        keepalive?: boolean;

    }): Observable<HttpResponse<T>>;

```
TITLE: Providing Multiple Related Dependencies with useClass (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to supply a provider that requires additional dependencies by listing all necessary providers in the module or component. Here, 'UserService' is available for 'EvenBetterLogger', which is used whenever the 'Logger' token is requested. Order is important: dependencies should be listed before providers that consume them.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/dependency-injection-providers.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
[
  UserService, // dependency needed in `EvenBetterLogger`.
  { provide: Logger, useClass: EvenBetterLogger },
]

  ...
})

```
TITLE: Implementing a Web Worker in an Angular Component

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
if (typeof Worker !== 'undefined') {
  // Create a new
  const worker = new Worker(new URL('./app.worker', import.meta.url));
  worker.onmessage = ({ data }) => {
    console.log(`page got message: ${data}`);
  };
  worker.postMessage('hello');
} else {
  // Web workers are not supported in this environment.
  // You should add a fallback so that your program still executes correctly.
}

}

```
TITLE: Modified Angular Template with Enhanced Type Safety - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: An improved Angular component template using '*ngIf' for enhanced type safety, ensuring both 'person' and 'address' are initialized.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tools/cli/aot-compiler.md#2025-04-22_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'my-component',
  template: '<span *ngIf="person &amp;&amp; address"> {{person.name}} lives on {{address.street}} </span>'
})
class MyComponent {
  person?: Person;
  address?: Address;

  setData(person: Person, address: Address) {
    this.person = person;
    this.address = address;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Scope of @let Variables in Angular Templates
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the scoping rules for @let variables in Angular templates, showing how variables are visible in current views and descendants but not in parent views or siblings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/templates/variables.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
@let topLevel = value;

<div>
  @let insideDiv = value;
</div>

{{topLevel}} <!-- Valid -->
{{insideDiv}} <!-- Valid -->

@if (condition) {
  {{topLevel + insideDiv}} <!-- Valid -->

  @let nested = value;

  @if (condition) {
    {{topLevel + insideDiv + nested}} <!-- Valid -->
  }
}

<div *ngIf="condition">
  {{topLevel + insideDiv}} <!-- Valid -->

  @let nestedNgIf = value;

  <div *ngIf="condition">
     {{topLevel + insideDiv + nestedNgIf}} <!-- Valid -->
  </div>
</div>

{{nested}} <!-- Error, not hoisted from @if -->
{{nestedNgIf}} <!-- Error, not hoisted from *ngIf -->
```

TITLE: Providing a Service within a Component Decorator (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines `ChildComponent` which provides its own instance of `FlowerService` using the `providers` array within the `@Component` decorator. It uses `useValue` to provide a specific object `{ emoji: 'ðŸŒ»' }` for the `FlowerService` token. The component also injects `FlowerService`, which will resolve to this component-specific provider.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/hierarchical-dependency-injection.md#2025-04-22_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-child',
  templateUrl: './child.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./child.component.css'],
  // use the providers array to provide a service
  providers: [{ provide: FlowerService, useValue: { emoji: 'ðŸŒ»' } }]
})
export class ChildComponent {
  // inject the service
  flower = inject(FlowerService);
}
```

TITLE: Service Data Access Functions in Angular Service (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This code provides data-fetching methods in the HousingService class: one for retrieving all HousingLocation items and another for obtaining a specific housing location by ID. It assumes the existence of a housingLocationList property. Dependencies: The HousingLocation type must be imported; functions rely on the presence and proper typing of the housingLocationList array. Inputs include an optional ID parameter; outputs are either a HousingLocation object or the array itself. Designed for synchronous access to static data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tutorials/first-app/steps/09-services/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
getAllHousingLocations(): HousingLocation[] {
    return this.housingLocationList;
}

getHousingLocationById(id: number): HousingLocation | undefined {
    return this.housingLocationList.find(housingLocation => housingLocation.id === id);
}
```

TITLE: Creating Component with Page Object in Angular Tests
DESCRIPTION: This utility function creates a HeroDetailComponent for testing and sets up a Page object once the hero data is available. It handles component creation, test hero initialization, and change detection to ensure the component is properly rendered.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_39

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
/** Create the HeroDetailComponent, initialize it, set test variables  */
function createComponent() {
  fixture = TestBed.createComponent(HeroDetailComponent);
  component = fixture.componentInstance;
  page = new Page(fixture);

  // 1st change detection triggers ngOnInit which gets a hero
  fixture.detectChanges();
  return fixture.whenStable().then(() => {
    // 2nd change detection displays the async-fetched hero
    fixture.detectChanges();
  });
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Effect Cleanup in Angular with TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the onCleanup parameter in Angular effects to properly clean up timeouts. The effect creates a timer that logs user information after 1 second, and uses onCleanup to clear the timeout when the effect is destroyed or re-runs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/signals/overview.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
effect((onCleanup) => {
  const user = currentUser();

  const timer = setTimeout(() => {
    console.log(`1 second ago, the user became ${user}`);
  }, 1000);

  onCleanup(() => {
    clearTimeout(timer);
  });
});
```

TITLE: Defining Root-Relative and Current-Relative Paths with RouterLink in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates different ways to define relative navigation paths using `RouterLink`, assuming the current route is `/settings`. Paths without a leading `/` (like `"notifications"`) are relative to the current route, resulting in `/settings/notifications`. Paths starting with `/` (like `"/settings/notifications"` or `"/team/123/user/456"`) are relative to the application root. Also shows embedding dynamic parameters (`teamId`, `userId`) using array syntax.

LANGUAGE: angular-html
CODE:
```
<!-- Navigates to /settings/notifications -->
<a routerLink="notifications">Notifications</a>
<a routerLink="/settings/notifications">Notifications</a>

<!-- Navigates to /team/:teamId/user/:userId -->
<a routerLink="/team/123/user/456">User 456</a>
<a [routerLink]="['/team', teamId, 'user', userId]">Current User</a>â€
```

TITLE: Enabling Event Replay for Angular Hydration (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet demonstrates enabling the Event Replay feature for Angular applications during hydration. It captures and replays user events that occur before hydration is complete. The code uses 'provideClientHydration' with 'withEventReplay' from '@angular/platform-browser'. Required dependencies: '@angular/platform-browser'. Key functionality: Ensures user interactions are not lost during hydration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/hydration.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {provideClientHydration, withEventReplay} from '@angular/platform-browser';

bootstrapApplication(App, {
  providers: [
    provideClientHydration(withEventReplay())
  ]
});
```

TITLE: Focus Management After Navigation in Angular Routing
DESCRIPTION: Example of managing focus after route navigation for better accessibility. This code listens for the NavigationEnd event and sets focus on the main content header.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/best-practices/a11y.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
router.events.pipe(filter(e => e instanceof NavigationEnd)).subscribe(() => {
  const mainHeader = document.querySelector('#main-content-header')
  if (mainHeader) {
    mainHeader.focus();
  }
});
```

CODE:
```
const showCount = signal(false);
const count = signal(0);
const conditionalCount = computed(() => {
  if (showCount()) {
    return `The count is ${count()}.`;
  } else {
    return 'Nothing to see here!';
  }
});
```

TITLE: Implementing Pipe Transform Logic in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Implements the PipeTransform interface for the ReversePipe, providing the core logic in the transform method. This snippet manually reverses the input string value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tutorials/learn-angular/steps/24-create-a-pipe/README.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
export class ReversePipe implements PipeTransform {
    transform(value: string): string {
        let reverse = '';

        for (let i = value.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
            reverse += value[i];
        }

        return reverse;
    }

}
```

TITLE: Including Inputs and Outputs in Host Directives
DESCRIPTION: This code extends the example of using host directives by explicitly declaring which inputs and outputs from the directive should be exposed in the AdminMenu component's public API. This allows consumers to bind inputs and outputs in a template.
```

@Component({
  selector: 'admin-menu',

```
TITLE: Creating Angular Output from RxJS Observable

SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/ecosystem/rxjs-interop/output-interop.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Directive} from '@angular/core';
import {outputFromObservable} from '@angular/core/rxjs-interop';

@Directive({/*...*/})
class Draggable {
  pointerMoves$: Observable<PointerMovements> = listenToPointerMoves();
  
  // Whenever `pointerMoves$` emits, the `pointerMove` event fires.
  pointerMove = outputFromObservable(this.pointerMoves$);
}
```

TITLE: Creating and Injecting Dependencies with Angular Injector - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define classes and configure Angular's DI injector to manage dependencies between them. It creates bindings for `Car` and `Engine`, injects dependencies using the `@Inject` annotation, and shows how to resolve and instantiate registered types. Dependencies: Angular DI module, class definitions for Car and Engine. Inputs are class constructors, outputs are injected instances with their dependencies resolved; errors may occur if bindings are missing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
class Engine {
}

class Car {
  constructor(@Inject(Engine) engine) {
  }
}

var inj = Injector.resolveAndCreate([
  bind(Car).toClass(Car),
  bind(Engine).toClass(Engine)
]);
var car = inj.get(Car);
```

TITLE: Defining Angular Structural Directive Microsyntax Grammar (TypeScript/Syntax)
DESCRIPTION: Presents the formal grammar definition for Angular's structural directive shorthand (microsyntax). This syntax definition outlines the structure involving prefixes, `let` bindings for template variables, key-expression pairs for directive inputs, and `as` clauses for exporting context values under different names, all used within the asterisk (`*`) syntax. Note: This defines syntax rules, not executable code.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/structural-directives.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
*:prefix="( :let | :expression ) (';' | ',')? ( :let | :as | :keyExp )*"
```

TITLE: Using Angular's By Class for Element Selection in Tests
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use Angular's By class to create predicates for selecting elements in component tests. It demonstrates the three static methods: By.all, By.css, and By.directive.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/utility-apis.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// By.css() is the most widely used predicate
let h1 = fixture.debugElement.query(By.css('h1')).nativeElement;

// You can also use the less explicit By.all() predicate
h1 = fixture.debugElement.query(By.all()).nativeElement;

// Support component selection with By.directive
const heroElems = fixture.debugElement.queryAll(By.directive(HeroComponent));
```

TITLE: Defining Components of Angular Structural Directive Microsyntax (TypeScript/Syntax)
DESCRIPTION: Breaks down the structural directive microsyntax grammar into its constituent parts: `as` for assigning a directive's context value to a template variable with a specific name, `keyExp` for binding template expressions to specific directive input properties (mapping `key` to `prefixKey`), and `let` for declaring template local variables bound to context properties (often `$implicit` by default). Note: This describes syntax elements, not executable TypeScript code.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/structural-directives.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
as = :export "as" :local ";"?
keyExp = :key ":"? :expression ("as" :local)? ";"?
let = "let" :local "=" :export ";"?
```

TITLE: HttpClient POST with Response and JSON Generic Type
```

        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<T>>;

```
TITLE: Prompting User for Update in Angular Service Worker
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to prompt the user to update to the latest version of the application when a new version is available. It uses the SwUpdate service to listen for version updates and shows a confirmation dialog to the user.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/ecosystem/service-workers/communications.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Injectable()
export class PromptUpdateService {
  constructor(private swUpdate: SwUpdate) {
    swUpdate.versionUpdates
      .pipe(filter((evt): evt is VersionReadyEvent => evt.type === 'VERSION_READY'))
      .subscribe(evt => {
        if (promptUser(evt)) {
          // Reload the page to update to the latest version
          document.location.reload();
        }
      });
  }
}

function promptUser(evt: VersionReadyEvent): boolean {
  return window.confirm('A new version of the app is available. Would you like to load it?');
}
```

TITLE: Creating a Pulsation Effect with Angular Keyframes
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use `keyframes` within an animation `trigger` to create complex, non-linear effects like a pulsation. Defines styles at specific points (offsets) throughout the animation duration to achieve the desired visual effect.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/transition-and-triggers.md#_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-open-close',
  animations: [
    trigger('openClose', [
      state('open', style({
        height: '200px',
        opacity: 1,
        backgroundColor: 'yellow'
      })),
      state('closed', style({
        height: '100px',
        opacity: 0.8,
        backgroundColor: 'blue'
      })),
      transition('open <=> closed', [
        animate('1s', keyframes([
          style({ opacity: 0.8, offset: 0 }),
          style({ opacity: 0.3, offset: 0.2 }),
          style({ opacity: 0.8, offset: 0.4 }),
          style({ opacity: 0.3, offset: 0.6 }),
          style({ opacity: 0.8, offset: 0.8 }),
          style({ opacity: 1, offset: 1.0 })
        ]))
      ])
    ])
  ],
  template: `
    <button [@openClose]="isOpen ? 'open' : 'closed'" (click)="toggle()">Toggle</button>
  `
})
export class OpenCloseComponent {
  isOpen = true;

  toggle() {
    this.isOpen = !this.isOpen;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing TitleCasePipe in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of a TitleCasePipe that capitalizes the first letter of each word using regular expressions. The pipe extends PipeTransform interface and is decorated with @Pipe metadata.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/pipes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Pipe, PipeTransform } from '@angular/core';

@Pipe({name: 'titlecase', standalone: true})
export class TitleCasePipe implements PipeTransform {
  transform(value: string): string {
    return value.length === 0
      ? ''
      : value.replace(/\w\S*/g, (txt) => {
          return txt[0].toUpperCase() + txt.substring(1).toLowerCase();
        });
  }
}

```

TITLE: Defining Dynamic Styles Object for NgStyle in Angular Component (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Implements a method `setCurrentStyles` within the Angular component. This method creates an object where keys are CSS style properties (like 'font-style', 'font-weight', 'font-size.px') and values are their corresponding settings, determined dynamically based on other component properties (`canSave`, `isUnchanged`, `isSpecial`). This object is intended for use with the `NgStyle` directive.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/directives/overview.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core';
// ... other imports

@Component({
  // ... component metadata
})
export class AppComponent implements OnInit {
  canSave = true;
  isSpecial = true;
  isUnchanged = true;

  currentStyles: Record<string, string | number> = {};

  ngOnInit() {
    this.setCurrentStyles();
  }

  setCurrentStyles() {
    // CSS styles: set per current state of component properties
    this.currentStyles = {
      'font-style': this.canSave ? 'italic' : 'normal',
      'font-weight': !this.isUnchanged ? 'bold' : 'normal',
      'font-size.px': this.isSpecial ? 24 : 12,
    };
  }

  // ... other component logic
}
```

TITLE: Defining FormControl Interface in TypeScript for Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the FormControl interface, which represents an individual form control. It includes methods for getting and setting values, registering change handlers, and resetting the control.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/forms/index.api.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export interface FormControl<TValue = any> extends AbstractControl<TValue> {
    readonly defaultValue: TValue;
    getRawValue(): TValue;
    patchValue(value: TValue, options?: {
        onlySelf?: boolean;
        emitEvent?: boolean;
        emitModelToViewChange?: boolean;
        emitViewToModelChange?: boolean;
    }): void;
    registerOnChange(fn: Function): void;
    registerOnDisabledChange(fn: (isDisabled: boolean) => void): void;
    reset(formState?: TValue | FormControlState<TValue>, options?: {
        onlySelf?: boolean;
        emitEvent?: boolean;
    }): void;
    setValue(value: TValue, options?: {
        onlySelf?: boolean;
        emitEvent?: boolean;
        emitModelToViewChange?: boolean;
        emitViewToModelChange?: boolean;
    }): void;
}
```

TITLE: Receiving Raw and Progress Events with HttpClient in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to subscribe to a stream of raw events during an HTTP request lifecycle, including progress events, by setting 'observe' to 'events'. This is useful for tracking uploads/downloads status of large bodies.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/making-requests.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
http.post('/api/upload', myData, {
  reportProgress: true,
  observe: 'events',
}).subscribe(event => {
  switch (event.type) {
    case HttpEventType.UploadProgress:
      console.log('Uploaded ' + event.loaded + ' out of ' + event.total + ' bytes');
      break;
    case HttpEventType.Response:
      console.log('Finished uploading!');
      break;
  }
});
```

LANGUAGE: angular-ts
CODE:
```
const routes: Routes = [
  { path: '', component: HomeComponent },              // Empty path
  { path: 'users/new', component: NewUserComponent },  // Static, most specific
  { path: 'users/:id', component: UserDetailComponent }, // Dynamic
  { path: 'users', component: UsersComponent },        // Static, less specific
  { path: '**', component: NotFoundComponent }         // Wildcard - always last
];

import { Pipe, PipeTransform } from '@angular/core';

@Pipe({

```
TITLE: Handling Untracked Signaling - Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the use of `untracked()` to read signals without registering them as dependencies for effects. Here, `untrackedCounter` changes do not trigger the effect. Used within Angular to avoid unnecessary reactivity. Requires understanding of reactive context. Inputs are initial values, outputs remain unchanged by effects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
const counter = signal(0);
const untrackedCounter = signal(0);
effect(() => console.log(`counter: ${counter()}, untrackedCounter: ${untracked(untrackedCounter)}`));
// counter: 0, untrackedCounter: 0

untrackedCounter.set(1);
// effect does not rerun because untrackedCounter was untracked 

counter.set(1);
// counter: 1, untrackedCounter: 1
```

```
import { Pipe, PipeTransform } from '@angular/core';

@Pipe({
  name: 'myCustomTransformation',
})
export class MyCustomTransformationPipe implements PipeTransform {
  transform(value: string): string {
    return `My custom transformation of ${value}.`
  }
}
```

TITLE: Breaking Circular References Using forwardRef in Angular Providers (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet exemplifies the use of Angular's forwardRef utility to resolve circular dependencies in provider definitions. The providers array uses provide and useExisting to register a dependency on PARENT_MENU_ITEM, referencing the MenuItem class with forwardRef to defer its evaluation until the class is defined. This approach is essential when the target class is not yet declared due to the file's declaration order, preventing reference errors in complex provider configurations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/di-in-action.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
providers: [\n  {\n    provide: PARENT_MENU_ITEM,\n    useExisting: forwardRef(() => MenuItem),\n  },\n],

  // Angular sanitizes them in data binding, but you can

}

  providers: [],
  bootstrap: [],
})

platformBrowser().bootstrapModule(AppModule);

```
TITLE: Configuring Node.js Server for Angular SSR
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of a Node.js server setup for Angular SSR using Express middleware and the AngularNodeAppEngine.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/ssr.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// server.ts
import { AngularNodeAppEngine, createNodeRequestHandler, writeResponseToNodeResponse } from '@angular/ssr/node';
import express from 'express';

const app = express();
const angularApp = new AngularNodeAppEngine();

app.use('*', (req, res, next) => {
  angularApp
    .handle(req)
    .then(response => {
      if (response) {
        writeResponseToNodeResponse(response, res);
      } else {
        next(); // Pass control to the next middleware
      }
    })
    .catch(next);
});

export const reqHandler = createNodeRequestHandler(app);
```

----------------------------------------
```

```
TITLE: Reading from Node Injector with Feature Callback for Tree-Shaking (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines a function 'readFromNodeInjector' that now accepts a feature function 'readFn' instead of an enum, enabling the function to delegate reading logic via the passed-in callback. The function first checks if the argument is a feature function and calls it; otherwise, it handles matching directives. This design allows the compiler to tree-shake logic for unused features. Prerequisites remain as before, but the function signature and call paradigm are updated.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/TREE_SHAKING.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
function readFromNodeInjector(
    nodeInjector: LInjector, node: LNode, readFn: (injector: Injector) => any) | Type<any>): any {
  if (isFeature(readFn)) {
    return readFn(nodeInjector);
  } 
  const matchingIdx = geIdxOfMatchingDirective(node, readFn);
  if (matchingIdx !== null) {
    return node.view.data[matchingIdx];
  }
  return null;
}
```

TITLE: Testing TitleCasePipe in Isolation
DESCRIPTION: Unit tests for TitleCasePipe using Jasmine to verify its transformation logic. Tests include standard cases, empty strings, and various edge cases to ensure the regular expression works correctly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/pipes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
describe('TitleCasePipe', () => {
  // This pipe is a pure, stateless function so no need for BeforeEach
  const pipe = new TitleCasePipe();

  it('transforms "abc" to "Abc"', () => {
    expect(pipe.transform('abc')).toBe('Abc');
  });

  it('transforms "abc def" to "Abc Def"', () => {
    expect(pipe.transform('abc def')).toBe('Abc Def');
  });

  // ... more tests ...
  it('leaves "Abc Def" unchanged', () => {
    expect(pipe.transform('Abc Def')).toBe('Abc Def');
  });

  it('transforms "abc-def" to "Abc-def"', () => {
    expect(pipe.transform('abc-def')).toBe('Abc-def');
  });

  it('transforms "   abc   def" to "   Abc   Def"', () => {
    expect(pipe.transform('   abc   def')).toBe('   Abc   Def');
  });
});

```

TITLE: Testing Synchronous and Asynchronous Services in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates unit tests for the ValueService, including both synchronous and asynchronous test cases. The tests are written without using Angular testing utilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/services.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
describe('ValueService', () => {
  let service: ValueService;
  beforeEach(() => { service = new ValueService(); });

  it('#getValue should return real value', () => {
    expect(service.getValue()).toBe('real value');
  });

  it('#getObservableValue should return value from observable', (done: DoneFn) => {
    service.getObservableValue().subscribe(value => {
      expect(value).toBe('observable value');
      done();
    });
  });

  it('#getPromiseValue should return value from a promise', (done: DoneFn) => {
    service.getPromiseValue().then(value => {
      expect(value).toBe('promise value');
      done();
    });
  });
});
```

TITLE: Testing TitleCasePipe in Component Context
DESCRIPTION: Integration test that verifies the TitleCasePipe works correctly when applied within an Angular component. This test uses TestBed to create a test component and checks if the pipe transforms the hero name properly in the DOM.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/pipes.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('should convert hero name to Title Case', () => {
  // get the name's input and display elements from the DOM
  const hostElement: HTMLElement = fixture.nativeElement;
  const nameInput: HTMLInputElement = hostElement.querySelector('input')!;
  const nameDisplay: HTMLElement = hostElement.querySelector('span')!;

  // simulate user entering a new name into the input box
  nameInput.value = 'quick BROWN  fOx';

  // Dispatch a DOM event so that Angular learns of input value change.
  nameInput.dispatchEvent(new Event('input'));

  // Tell Angular to update the display binding through the title pipe
  fixture.detectChanges();

  // expect pipe to have capitalized the name
  expect(nameDisplay.textContent).toBe('Quick Brown  Fox');
});


@Component({

})
export class Cmp {}

import {Dir} from './dir';
import {Cmp} from './cmp';

@NgModule({declarations: [Dir, Cmp]})
export class Mod {}

```
TITLE: Angular Component Input Transform Functions
DESCRIPTION: This implementation includes transformation functions for Angular inputs, showcasing how to enforce validations and modify input representations using transform functions, dealing with both synthetic and explicit input types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_23

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Input, input} from '@angular/core';
import {COMPLEX_VAR} from './required-no-explicit-type-extra';

function x(v: string | undefined): string | undefined {
  return v;
}

export class TransformFunctions {
  // We can check this, and expect `as any` due to transform incompatibility.
  // TODO: Notes from signal input migration:
  //  Input type is incompatible with transform. The migration added an `any`
  //  cast. This worked previously because Angular was unable to check transforms.
  readonly withExplicitTypeWorks = input.required<{
    ok: true;
}, string | undefined>({ transform: ((v: string | undefined) => '') as any });

  // This will be a synthetic type because we add `undefined` to `boolean`.
  readonly synthetic1 = input.required<boolean | undefined, string | undefined>({ transform: x });
  // Synthetic as we infer a full type from the initial value. Cannot be checked.
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Input is required, but the migration cannot determine a good type for the
  //  input.
  @Input({required: true, transform: (v: string | undefined) => ''}) synthetic2 = {
    infer: COMPLEX_VAR,
  };
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Harnesses for Composite Components in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create harnesses for composite components, using sub-harnesses for child components and implementing methods for component-specific actions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/creating-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
class MyMenuHarness extends ComponentHarness {
  static hostSelector = 'my-menu';

  protected getPopupHarness = this.locatorFor(MyPopupHarness);

  /** Gets the currently shown menu items (empty list if menu is closed). */
  getItems = this.locatorForAll(MyMenuItemHarness);

  /** Toggles open state of the menu. */
  async toggle() {
    const popupHarness = await this.getPopupHarness();
    return popupHarness.toggle();
  }
}

class MyMenuItemHarness extends ComponentHarness {
  static hostSelector = 'my-menu-item';
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Server Routes in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Code for creating a server route configuration that defines different rendering modes (Client, Prerender, Server) for various application routes. This configuration typically lives in app.routes.server.ts.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/ssr.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// app.routes.server.ts
import { RenderMode, ServerRoute } from '@angular/ssr';

export const serverRoutes: ServerRoute[] = [
  {
    path: '', // This renders the "/" route on the client (CSR)
    renderMode: RenderMode.Client,
  },
  {
    path: 'about', // This page is static, so we prerender it (SSG)
    renderMode: RenderMode.Prerender,
  },
  {
    path: 'profile', // This page requires user-specific data, so we use SSR
    renderMode: RenderMode.Server,
  },
  {
    path: '**', // All other routes will be rendered on the server (SSR)
    renderMode: RenderMode.Server,
  },
];
```

TITLE: Defining Parallel Animations with group() in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the `group()` function within Angular animation transitions (`:enter`, `:leave`) to run multiple animation steps concurrently on the same element, allowing different timing configurations for each property.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/complex-sequences.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-hero-list-groups',
  templateUrl: 'hero-list-groups.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./hero-list-groups.component.css'],
  animations: [
    trigger('flyInOut', [
      state('in', style({ transform: 'translateX(0)' })),
      transition(':enter', [
        group([
          animate('0.3s ease-in', style({ transform: 'translateX(0)' })),
          animate('0.5s ease-in', style({ opacity: 1 }))
        ])
      ]),
      transition(':leave', [
        group([
          animate('0.3s ease-out', style({ transform: 'translateX(100%)' })),
          animate('0.5s ease-out', style({ opacity: 0 }))
        ])
      ])
    ])
  ]
})
```

TITLE: Performing DOM Manipulation After Render in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the afterEveryRender function within a component's constructor to schedule DOM manipulation code to run after Angular has completed rendering. This ensures the DOM is available and stable before attempting operations like focusing an element. It utilizes the nativeElement property of ElementRef and standard DOM query selectors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/dom-apis.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({...})
export class ProfilePhoto {
  constructor() {
    const elementRef = inject(ElementRef);
    afterEveryRender(() => {
      // Focus the first input element in this component.
      elementRef.nativeElement.querySelector('input')?.focus();
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Custom XSRF Cookie/Header Names in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet demonstrates how to customize the XSRF token cookie and header names in Angular's HttpClient using the `withXsrfConfiguration` function. You must provide these custom names within the `provideHttpClient` call. This is typically needed when your backend service doesn't use the default cookie and header names. Ensure your server-side logic corresponds to the custom names for correct functioning.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/http/security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
export const appConfig: ApplicationConfig = {
  providers: [
    provideHttpClient(
      withXsrfConfiguration({
        cookieName: 'CUSTOM_XSRF_TOKEN',
        headerName: 'X-Custom-Xsrf-Header',
      }),
    ),
  ]
};
```

TITLE: Using parallel Function for Simultaneous Property Reading in Angular Tests
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the parallel function to read multiple properties of a component simultaneously. It optimizes change detection checks and works similarly to Promise.all for parallel execution of asynchronous operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/using-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
it('reads properties in parallel', async () => {
  const checkboxHarness = loader.getHarness(MyCheckboxHarness);
  // Read the checked and intermediate properties simultaneously.
  const [checked, indeterminate] = await parallel(() => [
    checkboxHarness.isChecked(),
    checkboxHarness.isIndeterminate()
  ]);
  expect(checked).toBe(false);
  expect(indeterminate).toBe(true);
});
```

----------------------------------------
```

```
TITLE: Using afterNextRender Phases for DOM Manipulation in Angular (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet demonstrates using the `afterNextRender` hook within an Angular component's constructor. It utilizes the `write` phase to potentially update an element's padding style based on `computePadding()` and returns a boolean indicating if a change occurred. The subsequent `read` phase uses this boolean to conditionally read the element's height using `getBoundingClientRect()` only after potential DOM writes have completed, thus minimizing layout thrashing. It injects `ElementRef` to access the native DOM element.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/lifecycle.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
```ts
import {Component, ElementRef, afterNextRender} from '@angular/core';

@Component({...})
export class UserProfile {
  private prevPadding = 0;
  private elementHeight = 0;

  constructor() {
    private elementRef = inject(ElementRef);
    const nativeElement = elementRef.nativeElement;

    afterNextRender({
      // Use the `Write` phase to write to a geometric property.
      write: () => {
        const padding = computePadding();
        const changed = padding !== this.prevPadding;
        if (changed) {
          nativeElement.style.padding = padding;
        }
        return changed; // Communicate whether anything changed to the read phase.
      },

      // Use the `Read` phase to read geometric properties after all writes have occurred.
      read: (didWrite) => {
        if (didWrite) {
          this.elementHeight = nativeElement.getBoundingClientRect().height;
        }
      }
    });
  }
}
```
```

TITLE: Lazily Instantiating and Caching Dependencies using Angular Injector - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: These snippets illustrate how the Angular injector creates and caches object instances on-demand, demonstrating the effect of different retrieval orders on instance creation and cache reuse. No external dependencies beyond the injector, but constructors must be side-effect-free for correct caching behavior. Inputs are requested types, outputs are instances either created or retrieved from cache; improper binding or side-effects can lead to bugs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var car = inj.get(Car); //instantiates both an Engine and a Car
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var engine = inj.get(Engine); //instantiates an Engine
var car = inj.get(Car); //instantiates a Car (reuses Engine)
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var car = inj.get(Car); //instantiates both an Engine and a Car
var engine = inj.get(Engine); //reads the Engine from the cache
```

TITLE: Correcting Angular Component Missing Structural Directive (TypeScript)

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';
import {SelectDirective} from 'my-directives';

@Component({
  // Add `SelectDirective` to the `imports` array to make it available in the template.
  imports: [SelectDirective],
  template: `<p *select="let data from source">{{data}}</p>`,
})
class MyComponent {}
```

TITLE: Animating List Items with Stagger and Query in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This Angular animation trigger defines a transition for elements entering the page. It uses the `query()` function to select child elements with the class 'hero', applies an initial style (transparent, moved up), and then uses `stagger()` to animate each selected element sequentially with a 30ms delay, fading it in and sliding it into place over 0.5 seconds.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/complex-sequences.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
trigger('pageAnimations', [
  transition(':enter', [
    query('.hero', [
      style({ opacity: 0, transform: 'translateY(-100px)' }),
      stagger(30, [
        animate('0.5s cubic-bezier(.35, 0, .25, 1)',
          style({ opacity: 1, transform: 'none' })
        )
      ])
    ], { optional: true })
  ])
])
```

TITLE: Animating Element Entry and Exit (void state) in Angular Animations
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the void state with wildcard transitions (void => * and * => void) to define animations that occur specifically when an element is added to or removed from the DOM, creating enter and leave effects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/transition-and-triggers.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
trigger('heroState', [
  state('inactive', style({
    backgroundColor: '#eee',
    transform: 'scale(1)'
  })),
  state('active', style({
    backgroundColor: '#cfd8dc',
    transform: 'scale(1.1)'
  })),
  transition('void => *', [
    style({ transform: 'translateX(-100%)' }),
    animate('0.5s ease-in')
  ]),
  transition('* => void', [
    animate('0.5s ease-out', style({ transform: 'translateX(100%)' }))
  ])
])

    ],

  // ... other application routes that don't

```
TITLE: Translation Message Retrieval in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to retrieve translation messages in different environments (Closure, non-Closure, and server-side) using compile-time constants and the $localize function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_29

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import '@angular/localize/init';

let MSG_hello;
if (CLOSURE) {
  /**
   * @desc extracted description goes here.
   */
  const MSG_hello_ = goog.getMsg('Hello World!');
  MSG_hello = MSG_hello_;
} else {
  // This would work in non-closure mode, and can work for both browser and SSR use case.
  MSG_hello = $localize`Hello World!`;
}
const MSG_div_attr = ['title', MSG_hello];

class MyComponent {
  static Éµcmp = defineComponent({
    ...,
    template: function(rf: RenderFlags, ctx: MyComponent) {
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Create) {
        i18nAttributes(1, MSG_hello);
        i18nEnd();
      }
    }
  });
}
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/inputs.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({/*...*/})
export class CustomSlider {
  // Declare an input named 'value' with a default value of zero. 
  value = input(0);

  // Create a computed expression that reads the value input
  label = computed(() => `The slider's value is ${this.value()}`); 
}
```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
// @public
export type ValidationErrors = {
    [key: string]: any;
};

export interface Validator {
    registerOnValidatorChange?(fn: () => void): void;
    validate(control: AbstractControl): ValidationErrors | null;
}

export interface ValidatorFn {
    // (undocumented)
    (control: AbstractControl): ValidationErrors | null;
}

```
TITLE: Alternative Testing Approach Without beforeEach in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Presents an alternative testing style that doesn't use beforeEach. This approach uses a setup function to prepare the test environment and destructuring assignment to extract necessary variables.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/services.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
function setup() {
  const valueServiceSpy =
    jasmine.createSpyObj('ValueService', ['getValue']);
  const stubValue = 'stub value';
  const masterService = new MasterService(valueServiceSpy);

  valueServiceSpy.getValue.and.returnValue(stubValue);
  return { masterService, stubValue, valueServiceSpy };
}
```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
it('#getValue should return stubbed value from a spy', () => {
  const { masterService, stubValue, valueServiceSpy } = setup();
  expect(masterService.getValue())
    .toBe(stubValue, 'service returned stub value');
  expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.count())
    .toBe(1, 'spy method was called once');
  expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.mostRecent().returnValue)
    .toBe(stubValue);
});
```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
const { masterService, stubValue, valueServiceSpy } = setup();
```

TITLE: Ternary Operator in Angular Template
DESCRIPTION: An Angular component demonstrating the use of the ternary operator for conditional rendering within a template, leveraging signal inputs to verify conditions and manage string operation outputs based on component state.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_22

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  template: `
    {{ narrowed() ? narrowed().substring(0, 1) : 'Empty' }}
    {{ justChecked() ? 'true' : 'false' }}

    {{ other?.safeRead() ? other.safeRead() : 'Empty' }}
    {{ other?.safeRead2() ? other?.safeRead2() : 'Empty' }}
  `,
})
export class TernaryNarrowing {
  readonly narrowed = input<string>();
  readonly justChecked = input(true);

  other?: OtherComponent;
}

@Component({template: ''})
export class OtherComponent {
  readonly safeRead = input<string>('');
  readonly safeRead2 = input<string>('');
}
```

TITLE: Dynamically Rendering Components with NgComponentOutlet in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use NgComponentOutlet to dynamically render either an AdminBio or StandardBio component based on the user's admin status. It utilizes a method to determine which component to render.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/programmatic-rendering.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({ ... })
export class AdminBio { /* ... */ }

@Component({ ... })
export class StandardBio { /* ... */ }

@Component({
  ...,
  template: `
    <p>Profile for {{user.name}}</p>
    <ng-container *ngComponentOutlet="getBioComponent()" /> `
})
export class CustomDialog {
  @Input() user: User;

  getBioComponent() {
    return this.user.isAdmin ? AdminBio : StandardBio;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Querying with @ContentChild in Angular Typescript
DESCRIPTION: The code demonstrates using @ContentChild to query for a single projected child component in Angular. This pattern is used to access a CustomToggle component within projected content in a CustomExpando component. The ngAfterContentInit lifecycle hook is crucial since the query result becomes available at this point.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/queries.md#2025-04-22_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'custom-toggle',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomToggle {
  text: string;
}

@Component({
  selector: 'custom-expando',
  /*...*/
})
export class CustomExpando {
  @ContentChild(CustomToggle) toggle: CustomToggle;

  ngAfterContentInit() {
    console.log(this.toggle.text);
  }
}

@Component({
  selector: 'user-profile',
  template: `
    <custom-expando>
      <custom-toggle>Show</custom-toggle>
    </custom-expando>
  `
})
export class UserProfile { }

```
TITLE: Implementing User Actions in Angular Component Harness
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to implement methods for user actions and state checks in a component harness, using TestElement interactions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/creating-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
class MyPopupHarness extends ComponentHarness {
  static hostSelector = 'my-popup';

  protected getTriggerElement = this.locatorFor('button');
  protected getContentElement = this.locatorForOptional('.my-popup-content');

  /** Toggles the open state of the popup. */
  async toggle() {
    const trigger = await this.getTriggerElement();
    return trigger.click();
  }

  /** Checks if the popup us open. */
  async isOpen() {
    const content = await this.getContentElement();
    return !!content;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Defining a Base Class for Dynamic Form Questions in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `QuestionBase` abstract class in TypeScript, serving as the foundation for different types of form controls in a dynamic form. It includes common properties like value, key, label, required status, order, control type, type, and options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/forms/dynamic-forms.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export class QuestionBase<T> {
  value: T|undefined;
  key: string;
  label: string;
  required: boolean;
  order: number;
  controlType: string;
  type: string;
  options: {key: string, value: string}[];

  constructor(options: {
      value?: T;
      key?: string;
      label?: string;
      required?: boolean;
      order?: number;
      controlType?: string;
      type?: string;
      options?: {key: string, value: string}[];
    } = {}) {
    this.value = options.value;
    this.key = options.key || '';
    this.label = options.label || '';
    this.required = !!options.required;
    this.order = options.order === undefined ? 1 : options.order;
    this.controlType = options.controlType || '';
    this.type = options.type || '';
    this.options = options.options || [];
  }
}

```

TITLE: Loading Harnesses for Multiple Components in a Test
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to load harnesses for multiple components in a unit test, including components outside the fixture's root element.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/using-component-harnesses.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
let fixture: ComponentFixture<MyDialogButton>;
let loader: HarnessLoader;
let rootLoader: HarnessLoader;

beforeEach(() => {
  fixture = TestBed.createComponent(MyDialogButton);
  loader = TestbedHarnessEnvironment.loader(fixture);
  rootLoader = TestbedHarnessEnvironment.documentRootLoader(fixture);
});

it('loads harnesses', async () => {
  // Load a harness for the bootstrapped component with `harnessForFixture`
  dialogButtonHarness =
      await TestbedHarnessEnvironment.harnessForFixture(fixture, MyDialogButtonHarness);
  // The button element is inside the fixture's root element, so we use `loader`.
  const buttonHarness = await loader.getHarness(MyButtonHarness);
  // Click the button to open the dialog
  await buttonHarness.click();
  // The dialog is appended to `document.body`, outside of the fixture's root element,
  // so we use `rootLoader` in this case.
  const dialogHarness = await rootLoader.getHarness(MyDialogHarness);
  // ... make some assertions
});
```

TITLE: Configuring and Registering the JSAction Event Dispatcher (JavaScript)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a Dispatcher, define application-specific handler logic, and register it with the global EventContract. Imports Dispatcher and registerDispatcher from @angular/core/primitives/event-dispatch. The handleEvent callback receives event details and routes them to user-defined logic, while eventReplayer manages replaying queued user events post-hydration. Expects global window['__ec'] to reference the previously registered EventContract. Dependencies: event contract setup, dispatcher classes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/event-dispatch/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import {Dispatcher, registerDispatcher} from '@angular/core/primitives/event-dispatch';\n\nfunction handleEvent(eventInfoWrapper) {\n  // eventInfoWrapper contains all the information about the event\n  const eventType = eventInfoWrapper.getEventType();\n  const handlerName = eventInfoWrapper.getAction().name;\n  const event = eventInfoWrapper.getEvent();\n\n  // Your application or framework must now decide how to get and call the\n  // appropriate handler.\n  myApp.runHandler(eventType, handlerName, event);\n}\n\nfunction eventReplayer(eventInfoWrappers) {\n  // The dispatcher uses a separate callback for replaying events to allow\n  // control over how the events are replayed. Here we simply handle them like\n  // any other event.\n  for (const eventInfoWrapper of eventInfoWrappers) {\n    handleEvent(eventInfoWrapper);\n  }\n}\n\n// Get the contract that we stashed in the other bundle.\nconst eventContract = window['__ec'];\nconst dispatcher = new Dispatcher(handleEvent, {eventReplayer});\n\n// This will replay any queued events and call handleEvent for each one of them.\nregisterDispatcher(eventContract, dispatcher);\n
```

TITLE: Inefficient @for Loop Tracking in Angular Component
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an Angular component with an inefficient @for loop that uses the entire todo object for tracking, causing unnecessary DOM recreation when the todos array is updated.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG0956.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  template: `
    <button (click)="toggleAllDone()">All done!</button>
    <ul>
    @for (todo of todos; track todo) {
      <li>{{todo.task}}</li>
    }
    </ul>
  `,
})
export class App {
  todos = [
    { id: 0, task: 'understand trackBy', done: false },
    { id: 1, task: 'use proper tracking expression', done: false },
  ];

  toggleAllDone() {
    this.todos = this.todos.map(todo => ({ ...todo, done: true }));
  }
}
```

TITLE: Handling Projectable Nodes with createComponent in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet demonstrates how to provide projectable nodes when creating a component programmatically using Angular's `createComponent` API in version 19. It shows the updated behavior where passing an empty array now renders the default `ng-content` fallback, and how to explicitly prevent this by passing an empty text node instead.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
// The first ng-content will render the default fallback content if present
createComponent(MyComponent. { projectableNodes: [[], [secondNode]] });

// To prevent projecting the default fallback content:
createComponent(MyComponent. { projectableNodes: [[document.createTextNode('')], [secondNode]] });
```

TITLE: Configuring Language Redirection with Apache
DESCRIPTION: This Apache configuration snippet demonstrates setting up redirection for a multi-locale Angular application using `mod_rewrite`. It enables the rewrite engine and defines rules to detect the user's preferred language ('en' or 'fr') from the `Accept-Language` header. If a preferred language is detected and a corresponding directory exists, the user is redirected to that language-specific subdirectory (e.g., `/fr/`). If no preference matches or the directory doesn't exist, it defaults to redirecting to the '/en/' subdirectory.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/i18n/deploy.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: apache
CODE:
```
<VirtualHost *:80>
  ServerName example.com
  DocumentRoot /var/www/example.com

  RewriteEngine On

  # Detect preferred language
  RewriteCond %{HTTP:Accept-Language} ^(en|fr) [NC]
  RewriteRule ^$ /%1/ [L,R=302,NE]

  # Check if the language directory exists
  RewriteCond %{DOCUMENT_ROOT}/%1 -d
  RewriteRule ^$ /%1/ [L,R=302,NE]

  # Default language fallback
  RewriteRule ^$ /en/ [L,R=302,NE]

  <Directory /var/www/example.com>
    Options Indexes FollowSymLinks
    AllowOverride All
    Require all granted
    RewriteEngine On
    # Don't rewrite files or directories
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} -f [OR]
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} -d
    RewriteRule ^ - [L]
    # Rewrite everything else to index.html
    RewriteRule ^ index.html [L]
  </Directory>
</VirtualHost>
