```
TITLE: Defining HttpClient Patch Method Signatures - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines the method signatures for `HttpClient.patch` in Angular. These comprehensive overloads illustrate sending HTTP PATCH requests with a request body. They cover various combinations of `observe` ('body', 'events', 'response') and `responseType` ('arraybuffer', 'blob', 'text', 'json'), showing how the return type (`Observable`) changes to represent the desired response format (body, events stream, or full HTTP response).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/common/http/index.api.md#_snippet_21

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'arraybuffer';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<ArrayBuffer>; // observe: 'body', arraybuffer response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'blob';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<Blob>; // observe: 'body', blob response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'text';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<string>; // observe: 'body', text response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'arraybuffer';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<ArrayBuffer>>; // observe: 'events', arraybuffer response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'blob';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<Blob>>; // observe: 'events', blob response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'text';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<string>>; // observe: 'events', text response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<Object>>; // observe: 'events', json response, default Object
    patch<T>(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<T>>; // observe: 'events', json response, generic T
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'arraybuffer';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<ArrayBuffer>>; // observe: 'response', arraybuffer response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'blob';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<Blob>>; // observe: 'response', blob response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'text';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<string>>; // observe: 'response', text response
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<Object>>; // observe: 'response', json response, default Object
    patch<T>(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'response';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpResponse<T>>; // observe: 'response', json response, generic T
    patch(url: string, body: any | null, options?: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<Object>; // observe: 'body', json response, default Object, options optional
    patch<T>(url: string, body: any | null, options?: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
    }): Observable<T>; // observe: 'body', json response, generic T, options optional
```

TITLE: Testing Services with Mocked Dependencies Using TestBed in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to test a service with dependencies using TestBed. This example uses a spy object to mock the ValueService when testing MasterService.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/services.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
let masterService: MasterService;
let valueServiceSpy: jasmine.SpyObj<ValueService>;

beforeEach(() => {
  const spy = jasmine.createSpyObj('ValueService', ['getValue']);

  TestBed.configureTestingModule({
    // Provide both the service-to-test and its (spy) dependency
    providers: [
      MasterService,
      { provide: ValueService, useValue: spy }
    ]
  });
  // Inject both the service-to-test and its (spy) dependency
  masterService = TestBed.inject(MasterService);
  valueServiceSpy = TestBed.inject(ValueService) as jasmine.SpyObj<ValueService>;
});
```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
it('#getValue should return stubbed value from a spy', () => {
  const stubValue = 'stub value';
  valueServiceSpy.getValue.and.returnValue(stubValue);

  expect(masterService.getValue())
    .toBe(stubValue, 'service returned stub value');
  expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.count())
    .toBe(1, 'spy method was called once');
  expect(valueServiceSpy.getValue.calls.mostRecent().returnValue)
    .toBe(stubValue);
});

  // Using a getter solely to make the property read-only.

```
----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Injector Visibility (Public) in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates setting up parent and child injectors where a dependency (`Engine`) is marked with `Visibility.Public`. This example shows that attempting to resolve a dependency (`Car`) requiring `Engine` via `@Host` from a host child injector will fail because public dependencies at the host are not visible upwards from the host child.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di_advanced.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
class Car {
  constructor(@Host() e: Engine) {}
}

var parentProto = new ProtoInjector([
  new BindingWithVisibility(Engine, Visibility.Public),
  new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)
]);
var parent = new Injector(parentProto);

var hostChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var hostChild = new Injector(hostChildProto, parent, true);

var regularChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var regularChild = new Injector(regularChildProto, parent, false);

hostChild.get(Car); // will throw because public dependencies declared at the host cannot be seen by child injectors
parent.get(Car); // this works
regularChild.get(Car); // this works
```

TITLE: Circular Dependency Example in Angular DI
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates a circular dependency scenario where UserService depends on EmployeeService and vice versa, creating a dependency loop that Angular cannot resolve during instantiation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG0200.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
# Circular Dependency in DI\n\nA cyclic dependency exists when a [dependency of a service](guide/di/hierarchical-dependency-injection) directly or indirectly depends on the service itself. For example, if `UserService` depends on `EmployeeService`, which also depends on `UserService`. Angular will have to instantiate `EmployeeService` to create `UserService`, which depends on `UserService`, itself.
```

TITLE: Transform Incompatible Types in Angular Directive
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates handling of transform incompatible inputs in Angular directives by utilizing input functions. Transformation incompatibility showcasing how strict property initialization is bypassed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_24

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Directive, input} from '@angular/core';

// see: button-base Material.

@Directive()
class TransformIncompatibleTypes {
  // @ts-ignore Simulate `--strictPropertyInitialization=false`.
  // TODO: Notes from signal input migration:
  //  Input type is incompatible with transform. The migration added an `any`
  //  cast. This worked previously because Angular was unable to check transforms.
  readonly disabled = input<boolean, unknown>(undefined, { transform: ((v: unknown) => (v === null ? undefined : !!v)) as any });
}
```

TITLE: HeroDetailService Implementation
DESCRIPTION: The HeroDetailService implementation that delegates to the injected HeroService for remote data access, showing the dependency chain that needs to be considered when testing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/testing/components-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_53

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Injectable()
export class HeroDetailService {
  constructor(private heroService: HeroService) {  }

  // Returns a clone which caller may modify safely
  getHero(id: number | string): Observable<Hero> {
    if (typeof id === 'string') {
      id = parseInt(id as string, 10);
    }
    return this.heroService.getHero(id).pipe(
      map(hero => {
        return hero ? Object.assign({}, hero) : null; // clone or null
      })
    );
  }

  saveHero(hero: Hero): Observable<Hero> {
    return this.heroService.updateHero(hero);
  }
}
```

TITLE: Pre-Written Instruction for Rebase and Squash in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides guidance on performing rebase and squash operations on commits with the use of `git fetch`, `git rebase`, and `git push` commands to maintain commit history cleanliness.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/contributing-docs/saved-issue-replies.md#2025-04-22_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Please rebase and squash your commits. To do this, make sure to `git fetch upstream` to get the latest changes from the angular repository. Then in your branch run `git rebase upstream/main -i` to do an interactive rebase. This should allow you to fixup or drop any unnecessary commits. After you finish the rebase, force push using `git push [origin name] [branch name] --force`.
```

TITLE: Patching Bluebird in Angular Main.ts
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript code showing how to patch Bluebird Promise in an Angular main.ts file. This ensures Bluebird callbacks execute within Angular zones.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/NON-STANDARD-APIS.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
/// <reference types="zone.js" />

bootstrapApplication(AppComponent, appConfig)
  .then(() => {
    import('bluebird').then((Bluebird) => {
      const bluebirdSymbol = Zone.__symbol__('bluebird');
      const patchBluebirdFn = (Zone as any)[bluebirdSymbol];
      patchBluebirdFn(Bluebird.default);
    });
  })
  .catch((err) => console.error(err));
```

TITLE: Configuring Zone.js Module Patching in HTML
DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet demonstrates how to disable specific patches in Zone.js by defining global variables before loading the zone script. It alters the behavior of certain web APIs such as Error, geolocation, and promises by using disabling flags. Dependencies include the Zone.js script file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/MODULE.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<script>
  __Zone_disable_Error = true; // Zone will not patch Error
  __Zone_disable_on_property = true; // Zone will not patch `on` properties such as button.onclick
  __Zone_disable_geolocation = true; // Zone will not patch geolocation API
  __Zone_disable_toString = true; // Zone will not patch Function.prototype.toString
  __Zone_disable_blocking = true; // Zone will not patch alert/prompt/confirm
  __Zone_disable_PromiseRejectionEvent = true; // Zone will not patch PromiseRejectionEventHandler
</script>
<script src="../bundles/zone.umd.js"></script>

    elementInjector: EnvironmentInjector<br>(configured by Angular)<br>has special things like DomSanitizer => providedIn 'platform'
    rootInjector: root EnvironmentInjector<br>(configured by AppConfig)<br>has things for your app => bootstrapApplication(..., AppConfig)
    nullInjector: NullInjector<br>always throws an error unless<br>you use @Optional()

    direction BT
    rootInjector --> elementInjector
    elementInjector --> nullInjector

```
TITLE: Testing Input Value Mutation in Angular Classes - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates mutation of an input object property and use of the input value in a class method for business logic. The input is a shared object and is updated via a dedicated mutation method. Requires Angular's input utility. Focuses on method-based mutation and property updating scenarios.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {input} from '@angular/core';

export class TestCmp {
  readonly shared = input<{
    x: string;
}>({ x: '' });

  bla() {
    const shared = this.shared();
    shared.x = this.doSmth(shared);

    this.doSmth(shared);
  }

  doSmth(v: typeof this.shared()): string {
    return v.x;
  }
}

```

TITLE: Controlling CSS Transition Timing and Easing
DESCRIPTION: Control the duration, delay, and timing function of CSS transitions using properties like `transition-duration`, `transition-delay`, and `transition-timing-function`, or the `transition` shorthand.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/css.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: css
CODE:
```
.box {
  transition-property: transform;
  transition-duration: 0.5s;
  transition-delay: 0.1s;
  transition-timing-function: ease-out;
}

/* Shorthand */

```
TITLE: Defining Angular Core DI Primitives in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the core dependency injection primitives for Angular. It includes functions for managing the current injector, interfaces for injection tokens and injectors, and types for handling 'not found' scenarios in DI operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/core/primitives/di/index.api.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// @public (undocumented)
export function getCurrentInjector(): Injector | undefined | null;

// @public
export interface InjectionToken<T> {
    // (undocumented)
    Éµprov: ÉµÉµInjectableDeclaration<T>;
}

// @public (undocumented)
export interface Injector {
    // (undocumented)
    retrieve<T>(token: InjectionToken<T>, options?: unknown): T | NotFound;
}

// @public
export function isNotFound(e: unknown): e is NotFound;

// @public
export const NOT_FOUND: unique symbol;

// @public
export type NotFound = typeof NOT_FOUND | NotFoundError;

// @public
export class NotFoundError extends Error {
    constructor(message: string);
    // (undocumented)
    readonly name: string;
}

// @public (undocumented)
export function setCurrentInjector(injector: Injector | null | undefined): Injector | undefined | null;

  <#VIEW>

      <#VIEW @Inject(FlowerService, SkipSelf)=>"&#x1F33A;">
        <!-- With SkipSelf, the injector looks to the next injector up the tree (app-root) -->
      </#VIEW>
    </app-child>
  </#VIEW>
</app-root>

   * you can configure some zone flags which can disable zone interception for some
   * asynchronous activities to improve startup performance - use these options only
   * if you know what you are doing as it could result in hard to trace down bugs.
   */
  // __Zone_disable_requestAnimationFrame = true; // disable patch requestAnimationFrame
  // __Zone_disable_on_property = true; // disable patch onProperty such as onclick
  // __zone_symbol__UNPATCHED_EVENTS = ['scroll', 'mousemove']; // disable patch specified eventNames
  /*
   * in Edge developer tools, the addEventListener will also be wrapped by zone.js
   * with the following flag, it will bypass `zone.js` patch for Edge.
   */
  // __Zone_enable_cross_context_check = true;

```
TITLE: TypeScript API Definitions for @angular/elements Package
DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive TypeScript definitions for the @angular/elements package, including the createCustomElement function, NgElement abstract class, and various interfaces for implementing Angular components as custom elements. The file defines the contract between Angular components and the custom elements API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/elements/index.api.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Injector } from '@angular/core';
import { Observable } from 'rxjs';
import { Subscription } from 'rxjs';
import { Type } from '@angular/core';
import { Version } from '@angular/core';

// @public
export function createCustomElement<P>(component: Type<any>, config: NgElementConfig): NgElementConstructor<P>;

// @public
export abstract class NgElement extends HTMLElement {
    abstract attributeChangedCallback(attrName: string, oldValue: string | null, newValue: string, namespace?: string): void;
    abstract connectedCallback(): void;
    abstract disconnectedCallback(): void;
    protected ngElementEventsSubscription: Subscription | null;
    protected abstract ngElementStrategy: NgElementStrategy;
}

// @public
export interface NgElementConfig {
    injector: Injector;
    strategyFactory?: NgElementStrategyFactory;
}

// @public
export interface NgElementConstructor<P> {
    new (injector?: Injector): NgElement & WithProperties<P>;
    readonly observedAttributes: string[];
}

// @public
export interface NgElementStrategy {
    // (undocumented)
    connect(element: HTMLElement): void;
    // (undocumented)
    disconnect(): void;
    // (undocumented)
    events: Observable<NgElementStrategyEvent>;
    // (undocumented)
    getInputValue(propName: string): any;
    // (undocumented)
    setInputValue(propName: string, value: string, transform?: (value: any) => any): void;
}

// @public
export interface NgElementStrategyEvent {
    // (undocumented)
    name: string;
    // (undocumented)
    value: any;
}

// @public
export interface NgElementStrategyFactory {
    create(injector: Injector): NgElementStrategy;
}

// @public (undocumented)
export const VERSION: Version;

// @public
export type WithProperties<P> = {
    [property in keyof P]: P[property];
};
```

TITLE: Tree-Shaking Example with Angular Ivy Directives and Components
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how tree-shaking can break when the compiler lacks selector information for directives. Shows the relationship between Directive, Component, and NgModule declarations and their compiled output.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/STORING_METADATA_IN_D.TS.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Directive({
  selector: '[tooltip]'
})
export class TooltipDirective {
  // ngtsc generates this:
  static Éµdir = ÉµÉµdefineDirective(...);
}

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  template: 'Hello World!'
})
class MyAppComponent {
  // ngtsc generates this:
  static Éµdir = ÉµÉµdefineComponent({
    ...
    directives: [
      // BREAKS TREE-SHAKING!!!
      // TooltipDirective included here because it was declared in the NgModule
      // ngtsc does not know it can be omitted.
      // Only way for ngtsc to know that it can omit TooltipDirective is if it knows
      // its selector and see if the selector matches the current component's template.
      TooltipDirective
    ]
  });
}

@NgModule({
  declarations: [MyAppComponent, TooltipDirective],
  bootstrap: [MyAppComponent],
})
class MyAppModule {
    // ngtsc generates this:
  static Éµmod = ÉµÉµdefineNgModule(...);
}

        observe: 'events';

        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType: 'arraybuffer';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<ArrayBuffer>>;

```
TITLE: Transform Functions with Signal Inputs in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates various signal input transformations including required inputs with transforms, inputs with explicit types, and synthetic types. Includes cases where migration added 'any' casts due to transform incompatibilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_23

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import {Input, input} from '@angular/core';
import {COMPLEX_VAR} from './required-no-explicit-type-extra';

function x(v: string | undefined): string | undefined {
  return v;
}

export class TransformFunctions {
  // We can check this, and expect `as any` due to transform incompatibility.
  // TODO: Notes from signal input migration:
  //  Input type is incompatible with transform. The migration added an `any`
  //  cast. This worked previously because Angular was unable to check transforms.
  readonly withExplicitTypeWorks = input.required<{
    ok: true;
}, string | undefined>({ transform: ((v: string | undefined) => '') as any });

  // This will be a synthetic type because we add `undefined` to `boolean`.
  readonly synthetic1 = input.required<boolean | undefined, string | undefined>({ transform: x });
  // Synthetic as we infer a full type from the initial value. Cannot be checked.
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Input is required, but the migration cannot determine a good type for the
  //  input.
  @Input({required: true, transform: (v: string | undefined) => ''}) synthetic2 = {
    infer: COMPLEX_VAR,
  };
}
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Optional Chain with Non-nullable Type in Angular Template
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example of using the optional chain operator with a non-nullable input in an Angular component. The user property is declared as a non-nullable object, which contradicts the use of the optional chain operator in the template.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/extended-diagnostics/NG8107.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  // Print the user's name safely, even if `user` is `null` or `undefined`.
  template: `<div>User name: {{ user?.name }}</div>`,
})
class MyComponent {
  // `user` is declared as an object which *cannot* be `null` or `undefined`.
  user: { name: string } = { name: 'Angelino' };
}
```

DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the recommended declarative way to register a click handler using the jsaction attribute. There are no dependencies aside from JSAction script setup. The button receives a jsaction attribute that enables centralized event delegation.

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<button id=\"buy_btn\" type=\"button\" jsaction=\"click:confirmPurchase\">\n  Buy now!\n</button>\n
```

TITLE: Defining Angular HttpResourceFn Interface (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines the function signature for the `httpResource` factory. It provides multiple overloads for creating an `HttpResourceRef` based on a reactive URL or a reactive request object, supporting different response types and options like default values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/common/http/index.api.md#_snippet_45

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export interface HttpResourceFn {
    <TResult = unknown>(url: () => string | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, unknown> & {
        defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
    }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
    <TResult = unknown>(url: () => string | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, unknown>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
    <TResult = unknown>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, unknown> & {
        defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
    }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
    <TResult = unknown>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, unknown>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
    arrayBuffer: {
        <TResult = ArrayBuffer>(url: () => string | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, ArrayBuffer> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = ArrayBuffer>(url: () => string | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, ArrayBuffer>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
        <TResult = ArrayBuffer>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, ArrayBuffer> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = ArrayBuffer>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, ArrayBuffer>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
    };
    blob: {
        <TResult = Blob>(url: () => string | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, Blob> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = Blob>(url: () => string | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, Blob>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
        <TResult = Blob>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, Blob> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = Blob>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, Blob>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
    };
    text: {
        <TResult = string>(url: () => string | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, string> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = string>(url: () => string | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, string>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
        <TResult = string>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, string> & {
            defaultValue: NoInfer<TResult>;
        }): HttpResourceRef<TResult>;
        <TResult = string>(request: () => HttpResourceRequest | undefined, options?: HttpResourceOptions<TResult, string>): HttpResourceRef<TResult | undefined>;
    };
}
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Traditional Inline Event Registration (HTML)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the classic pattern of querying a DOM element by ID and registering a click event handler using addEventListener. It highlights the potential pitfall in server-side rendering scenarios: user interactions before full app hydration are ignored. Readers require basic HTML/JavaScript knowledge; dependencies include the existence of an element with id 'buy_btn'. The code assigns an inline event handler that invokes app.confirmPurchase() but only after the handler code has loaded.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/event-dispatch/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<body>\n  <button id=\"buy_btn\" type=\"button\">Buy now!</button>\n  ...\n  <!--\n  There's a window of time between when the button is rendered and the\n  script below reaches the client, either because there's a lot of content\n  streamed in-between, network lag, or the script is asynchronously loaded\n  via a follow-up network request rather than as part of the main document\n  content.\n  ->\n  ...\n  <script>\n    const btn = document.querySelector('#buy_btn');\n    // Until this line is executed, clicking on the button doesn't do\n    // anything. This can be a frustrating user experience.\n    btn.addEventListener('click', () => app.confirmPurchase());\n  </script>\n
```

TITLE: Specifying Animation Timing (Native CSS Keyframes) - CSS

SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/animations/migration.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: CSS
CODE:
```
@keyframes slideIn {
  0% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
  100% { transform: translateX(0); }
}

.element {
  animation-name: slideIn;
  animation-duration: 2s;
  animation-delay: 0.5s;
  animation-timing-function: cubic-bezier(0.175, 0.885, 0.32, 1.275); /* easeOutBack */
  /* Shorthand: animation: slideIn 2s 0.5s cubic-bezier(0.175, 0.885, 0.32, 1.275); */
}
```

TITLE: Liveness and Memory Management in Signals - Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Describes the impact of consumer liveness on memory management and dependency tracking. Demonstrates setting a `computed` signal and how they can be dropped without leaks. Angular relies on understanding reactive and live consumer context. Inputs change signal states; outputs include signal value updates or drops.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/signals/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
const counter = signal(1);

let double = computed(() => counter() * 2);
console.log(double()); // 2
double = null;

counter.set(2);
```

TITLE: Inefficient Injector Creation Pattern in JavaScript

SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di_advanced.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
function createComponentInjector(parent, providers: Binding[]) {
  return parent.resolveAndCreateChild(providers);
}
```

TITLE: Handling Two-Way Data Binding in Angular Component
DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases an Angular component with bindable properties. It uses the Ivy renderer to bind the property 'title' and interpolate text based on the component's 'name' property. Declares two DOM elements and two bindings in its vars section. Requires Angular's decorators and Ivy-specific functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/VIEW_DATA.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  template: `<div title="{{name}}">Hello {{name}}!</div>`
})
class MyApp {
  name = 'World';

  static Éµcmp = ÉµÉµdefineComponent({
    ..., // other component options
    decls: 2, // Two DOM Elements.
    vars: 2,   // Two bindings.
    template: function(rf: RenderFlags, ctx: MyApp) {
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Create) {
        ÉµÉµelementStart(0, 'div');
        ÉµÉµtext(1);
        ÉµÉµelementEnd();
      }
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Update) {
        ÉµÉµproperty('title', ctx.name);
        ÉµÉµadvance();
        ÉµÉµtextInterpolate1('Hello ', ctx.name, '!');
      }
      // other template logic
    }
  });
}
```

TITLE: Creating ng-add Rule Factory Function
DESCRIPTION: This snippet presents a TypeScript file that implements the `ng-add` rule factory for an Angular schematic. The factory function is responsible for executing the enhancements needed during the initial installation of a library, such as adding the `MyLibModule` to the application root. It describes the use of callback functions and external symbol wrapping for generating appropriate import statements.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tools/cli/schematics-for-libraries.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { Rule, SchematicContext, Tree } from '@angular-devkit/schematics';\nimport { addRootImport } from './utils';\n\nexport function ngAdd(options: any): Rule {\n  return (host: Tree, context: SchematicContext) => {\n    context.logger.info('Adding MyLibModule to the root');\n    return addRootImport(host, context, () => \n      `import { MyLibModule } from 'my-lib';`\n    );\n  };\n}
```

TITLE: English Locale Plural Function Implementation in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of the Angular en-US locale's plural function that determines which pluralization category to use for a given number.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/i18n/prepare.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
function plural(n: number): number {
  let i = Math.floor(Math.abs(n)), v = n.toString().replace(/^[^.]*\.?/, '').length;
  if (i === 1 && v === 0) return 1;
  return 5;
}
```

TITLE: Complete Angular Dependency Injection Logic Tree
DESCRIPTION: Detailed illustration of the logical tree showing how viewProviders affects visibility of services, particularly demonstrating the difference between projected content and view children.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/di/hierarchical-dependency-injection.md#2025-04-22_snippet_33

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<app-root @ApplicationConfig
         @Inject(AnimalService) animal=>"&#x1F433;">
  <#VIEW>
    <app-child>
      <#VIEW @Provide(AnimalService="&#x1F436;")
            @Inject(AnimalService=>"&#x1F436;")>
        <!-- ^^using viewProviders means AnimalService is available in <#VIEW>-->
        <p>Emoji from AnimalService: {{animal.emoji}} (&#x1F436;)</p>

        <div class="container">
          <h3>Content projection</h3>
          <app-inspector @Inject(AnimalService) animal=>"&#x1F433;">
            <p>Emoji from AnimalService: {{animal.emoji}} (&#x1F433;)</p>
          </app-inspector>
        </div>

        <app-inspector>
          <#VIEW @Inject(AnimalService) animal=>"&#x1F436;">
            <p>Emoji from AnimalService: {{animal.emoji}} (&#x1F436;)</p>
          </#VIEW>
        </app-inspector>
      </#VIEW>
    </app-child>
  </#VIEW>
</app-root>
```

----------------------------------------
```

```
TITLE: Complete Schematic Rule Implementation (Angular Schematics, TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This code combines the previously described processes into a single schematic rule factory function for generating a service file in the appropriate location of an Angular workspace. The implementation integrates workspace reading, project lookup, template transformation, and rule chaining. Inputs are schematic options; output is a modified Tree with user-specific service generated.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tools/cli/schematics-for-libraries.md#2025-04-22_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
<!-- Content hidden; combines all steps in index.ts. Canonical version synthesizes all above snippets. -->
import { Rule, SchematicContext, Tree, apply, url, applyTemplates, move, chain, mergeWith } from '@angular-devkit/schematics';
import { workspaces } from '@angular-devkit/core';
import { classify, dasherize } from '@angular-devkit/core/src/utils/strings';
import { Schema as MyServiceSchema } from './schema';

export default function(options: MyServiceSchema): Rule {
  return async (tree: Tree, _context: SchematicContext) => {
    const workspaceHost = workspaces.createWorkspaceHost(tree);
    const workspace = await workspaces.readWorkspace('/', workspaceHost);
    const projectName = options.project;
    const project = workspace.projects.get(projectName);
    if (!project) throw new Error('Project not found.');
    const targetPath = options.path || (project.sourceRoot ? `${project.sourceRoot}/${project.projectType}` : '');
    const templateSource = apply(url('./files'), [
      applyTemplates({
        ...options,
        classify,
        dasherize,
      }),
      move(targetPath),
    ]);
    return chain([
      mergeWith(templateSource)
    ])(tree, _context);
  };
}

```

TITLE: Unsupported Computed Enum Member in Metadata - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows TypeScript enum definition with both simple and computed members, and usage in Angular providers. The Angular compiler only supports simple enum initializers in metadata expressions; computed members like \"Blue = \"Blue\".length\" are not supported and will cause an error if referenced in provider configuration. Constraints: Avoid computed values in enums referenced by Angular metadata.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/tools/cli/aot-metadata-errors.md#2025-04-22_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// ERROR
enum Colors {
  Red = 1,
  White,
  Blue = "Blue".length // computed
}

  â€¦
  providers: [
    { provide: BaseColor,   useValue: Colors.White } // ok
    { provide: DangerColor, useValue: Colors.Red }   // ok
    { provide: StrongColor, useValue: Colors.Blue }  // bad
  ]
  â€¦


var listOfResolvingProviders = Injector.resolve([Provider1, Provider2]);

```
TITLE: Configuring Injector Visibility (PublicAndPrivate) in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates setting up injectors where a dependency (`Engine`) is marked with `Visibility.PublicAndPrivate`. In this configuration, the dependency is visible to the parent itself, regular child injectors, and host child injectors resolving via `@Host`, allowing `Car` to be resolved successfully in all three cases.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di_advanced.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
class Car {
  constructor(@Host() e: Engine) {}
}

var parentProto = new ProtoInjector([
  new BindingWithVisibility(Engine, Visibility.PublicAndPrivate),
  new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)
]);
var parent = new Injector(parentProto);

var hostChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var hostChild = new Injector(hostChildProto, parent, true);

var regularChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var regularChild = new Injector(regularChildProto, parent, false);

hostChild.get(Car); // this works
parent.get(Car); // this works
regularChild.get(Car); // this works
```

TITLE: Dependency Resolution Algorithm in Angular Injector - Pseudocode
DESCRIPTION: This pseudocode demonstrates the recursive resolution strategy Angular injectors use when seeking a dependency. The algorithm checks for a key in the current injector, then walks up the parent chain if not found, throwing an error if the dependency cannot be resolved. Dependencies: Injector abstraction, requested key; input is requestedKey and injector context, output is the resolved instance or NoProviderError.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: pseudocode
CODE:
```
// this is pseudocode.
var inj = this;
while (inj) {
  if (inj.hasKey(requestedKey)) {
    return inj.get(requestedKey);
  } else {
    inj = inj.parent;
  }
}
throw new NoProviderError(requestedKey);
```

TITLE: HttpClient get Method (observe: 'events', responseType?: 'json', generic)
DESCRIPTION: Performs an HTTP GET request, expecting the response data as a JSON object of a specified generic type T. The 'observe' option is set to 'events', causing the method to return an Observable of HttpEvent<T>, allowing observation of various request lifecycle events. The responseType defaults to 'json'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/common/http/index.api.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
get<T>(url: string, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        observe: 'events';
        context?: HttpContext;
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;
        reportProgress?: boolean;
        responseType?: 'json';
        withCredentials?: boolean;
        keepalive?: boolean;
        transferCache?: {
            includeHeaders?: string[];
        } | boolean;
    }): Observable<HttpEvent<T>>;
```

TITLE: Defining Angular HttpResourceRef Interface (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Represents a reactive reference to an HTTP resource created by the `httpResource` function. LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export interface HttpResourceRef<T> extends WritableResource<T>, ResourceRef<T> {
    destroy(): void;
    hasValue(): this is HttpResourceRef<Exclude<T, undefined>>;
    readonly headers: Signal<HttpHeaders | undefined>;
    readonly progress: Signal<HttpProgressEvent | undefined>;
    readonly statusCode: Signal<number | undefined>;
}
```

TITLE: Dealing with Shared Incompatible Scopes in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This component and directive interaction ensures that regex patterns are correctly injected and manipulated across various scopes and local contexts within a component, demonstrating handling of incompatible scope scenarios.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Directive, Component, input} from '@angular/core';

@Directive()
class SomeDir {
  readonly bla = input.required<RegExp>();
}

@Component({
  template: ``,
})
export class ScopeMismatchTest {
  eachScopeRedeclared() {
    const regexs: RegExp[] = [];

    if (global.console) {
      const dir: SomeDir = null!;
      regexs.push(dir.bla());
    }

    const dir: SomeDir = null!;
    regexs.push(dir.bla());
  }

  nestedButSharedLocal() {
    const regexs: RegExp[] = [];
    const dir: SomeDir = null!;

    const bla = dir.bla();
    if (global.console) {
      regexs.push(bla);
    }

    regexs.push(bla);
  }

  dir: SomeDir = null!;
  nestedButSharedInClassInstance() {
    const regexs: RegExp[] = [];

    const bla = this.dir.bla();
    if (global.console) {
      regexs.push(bla);
    }

    regexs.push(bla);
  }
}
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Unsupported DOM Node Projection in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows an example that triggers the hydration error by creating DOM nodes outside of Angular's context and attempting to project them into a dynamic component.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG0503.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Component({
  selector: 'dynamic',
  template: `
  <ng-content />
`,
})
class DynamicComponent {
}

@Component({
  selector: 'app',
  template: `<div #target></div>`,
})
class SimpleComponent {
  @ViewChild('target', {read: ViewContainerRef}) vcr!: ViewContainerRef;
  envInjector = inject(EnvironmentInjector);

  ngAfterViewInit() {
    const div = document.createElement('div');
    const p = document.createElement('p');
    // In this test we create DOM nodes outside of Angular context
    // (i.e. not using Angular APIs) and try to content-project them.
    // This is an unsupported pattern and an exception will be thrown.
    const compRef = createComponent(DynamicComponent, {
      environmentInjector: this.envInjector,
      projectableNodes: [[div, p]]
    });
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using Setters and Getters in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates Angular component inputs with setters and getters, showcasing input accessor complexity. It highlights migration issues for accessor inputs not being migrated due to their complexity.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_25

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {Input, input} from '@angular/core';

export class WithSettersAndGetters {
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Accessor inputs cannot be migrated as they are too complex.
  @Input()
  set onlySetter(newValue: any) {
    this._bla = newValue;
    if (newValue === 0) {
      console.log('test');
    }
  }
  private _bla: any;

  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Accessor inputs cannot be migrated as they are too complex.
  @Input()
  get accessor(): string {
    return '';
  }
  set accessor(newValue: string) {
    this._accessor = newValue;
  }
  private _accessor: string = '';

  readonly simpleInput = input.required<string>();
}
```

TITLE: Defining I18nPluralPipe Class (TypeScript)
```

```
TITLE: Configuring Injector Visibility (Private) in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates setting up injectors where a dependency (`Engine`) is marked with `Visibility.Private`. This example shows that a host child injector *can* resolve a dependency (`Car`) requiring `Engine` via `@Host` when `Engine` is private to the parent, but the parent and regular child injectors cannot resolve `Car` because the required `Engine` is private.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/docs/di/di_advanced.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
class Car {
  constructor(@Host() e: Engine) {}
}

var parentProto = new ProtoInjector([
  new BindingWithVisibility(Engine, Visibility.Private),
  new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)
]);
var parent = new Injector(parentProto);

var hostChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var hostChild = new Injector(hostChildProto, parent, true);

var regularChildProto = new ProtoInjector([new BindingWithVisibility(Car, Visibility.Public)]);
var regularChild = new Injector(regularChildProto, parent, false);

hostChild.get(Car); // this works
parent.get(Car); // this throws
regularChild.get(Car); // this throws
```

TITLE: Creating Injector with Explicit Key Usage in JavaScript

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
var ENGINE_KEY = Key.get(Engine);

var inj = Injector.resolveAndCreate([
  bind(ENGINE_KEY).toFactory(() => new TurboEngine()) // no mapping
]);
var engine = inj.get(ENGINE_KEY);  // no mapping

  ...

```
TITLE: Transpiled JavaScript Output for Angular Component
```

    tslib_1.__metadata("design:type", String)

    })

```
TITLE: Component with Getters and Setters in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines a component class with accessor-based inputs (getters and setters) that couldn't be migrated to signal inputs due to their complexity, alongside a simple signal input that could be migrated.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_25

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import {Input, input} from '@angular/core';

export class WithSettersAndGetters {
  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Accessor inputs cannot be migrated as they are too complex.
  @Input()
  set onlySetter(newValue: any) {
    this._bla = newValue;
    if (newValue === 0) {
      console.log('test');
    }
  }
  private _bla: any;

  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  Accessor inputs cannot be migrated as they are too complex.
  @Input()
  get accessor(): string {
    return '';
  }
  set accessor(newValue: string) {
    this._accessor = newValue;
  }
  private _accessor: string = '';

  readonly simpleInput = input.required<string>();
}

```
TITLE: Using a Type Constructor in a TCB for Generic Directives (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how a generated type constructor (`ctor1`) is used within a Type Check Block (TCB) to handle generic directives like `NgFor`. The constructor is called with the input binding (`{ngForOf: this.users}`), allowing TypeScript to infer the correct generic type parameter (e.g., `User` if `this.users` is `User[]`) for the directive instance (`_t1`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  var _t1 = ctor1({ngForOf: this.users});
  // Assuming this.users is User[], then _t1 is inferred as NgFor<User>.
}
```

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
put(url: string, body: any | null, options: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders | Record<string, string | string[]>;
        context?: HttpContext;
        observe?: 'body';
        params?: HttpParams | Record<string, string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string | number | boolean>>;

```
TITLE: Testing Host Bindings with Angular Inputs - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of @HostBinding, @Input, and custom input utility with various host-binding expressions in Angular components. Covers scenarios with nested expressions, shared host bindings, and interleaving of multiple decorators. Requires Angular with Component and Input decorators, and the custom input function. Inputs and host bindings are set for testing host expression parsing, shadowing, and migration compatibility.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_4
```

// tslint:disable

import {Component, Input, HostBinding, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  template: '',
  host: {
    '[id]': 'id()',
    '[nested]': 'nested.id()',
    '[receiverNarrowing]': 'receiverNarrowing ? receiverNarrowing.id()',
    // normal narrowing is irrelevant as we don't type check host bindings.
  },
})
class HostBindingTestCmp {
  readonly id = input('works');

  // for testing nested expressions.
  nested = this;

  declare receiverNarrowing: this | undefined;

  // TODO: Skipped for migration because:
  //  This input is used in combination with `@HostBinding` and migrating would
  //  break.
  @HostBinding('[attr.bla]')
  @Input()
  myInput = 'initial';
}

const SHARED = {
  '(click)': 'id()',
  '(mousedown)': 'id2()',
};

@Component({
  template: '',
  host: SHARED,
})
class HostBindingsShared {
  readonly id = input(false);
}

@Component({
  template: '',
  host: SHARED,
})
class HostBindingsShared2 {
  readonly id = input(false);
  readonly id2 = input(false);

```
TITLE: Type Checking Block for NgIf With Binding Guards

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  // Type of the NgIf directive instance.
  var _t1: NgIf;

  // Binding *ngIf="user != null".
  _t1.ngIf = this.user !== null;

  // Guard generated due to the `ngTemplateGuard_ngIf` declaration by the NgIf directive.
  if (user !== null) {
    // Nested template interpolation `{{user.name}}`.
    // `this.user` here is appropriately narrowed to be non-nullable.
    '' + this.user.name;
  }
}

```
TITLE: Demonstrating Memo Decorator Usage in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive example showcasing the usage of memo decorator with different configurations and explaining its caching behavior across method calls and class instances.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/devtools/projects/ng-devtools/src/lib/vendor/memo-decorator/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import memo from 'memo-decorator';

class Qux {
  @memo()
  foo(a: number) {
    console.log('foo: called');
    return 42;
  }

  @memo({
    resolver: (_) => 1,
  })
  bar(a: number) {
    console.log('bar: called');
    return 42;
  }
}

const a = new Qux();
// Create a new cache entry and associate `1` with the result `42`.
a.foo(1);
// Do not invoke the original method `foo` because there's already a cache
// entry for the key `1` associated with the result of the method.
a.foo(1);
// Invoke the original `foo` because the cache doesn't contain an entry
// for the key `2`.
a.foo(2);

// Invoke `bar` and return the result `42` gotten from the original `bar` implementation.
a.bar(1);
// Does not invoke the original `bar` implementation because of the specified `resolver`
// which is passed to `memo`. For any arguments of the function, the resolver will return
// result `1` which will be used as the key.
a.bar(2);

const b = new Qux();
// Does not invoke the method `foo` because there's already an entry
// in the cache which associates the key `1` to the result `42` from the
// invocation of the method `foo` by the instance `a`.
b.foo(1);

// Outputs:
// foo: called
// foo: called
// bar: called
```

TITLE: Generated Angular Ivy Instructions for i18n (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet displays the TypeScript code generated by the Angular template compiler for the example component with i18n. It includes constants for the i18n messages (`MSG_title`, `MSG_div_attr`, `MSG_div`) containing placeholders (ï¿½...ï¿½), Ivy rendering instructions (`i18nStart`, `i18nEnd`, `i18nAttributes`, `i18nExp`, `i18nApply`, `element`, `template`), and the component's factory function demonstrating how i18n is handled during element creation and updates.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// These i18n messages need to be retrieved from a "localization service", described later.
const MSG_title = 'Hello ï¿½0ï¿½!';
const MSG_div_attr = ['title', MSG_title];
const MSG_div = `ï¿½0ï¿½ is rendered as: ï¿½*3:1ï¿½ï¿½#1:1ï¿½{ï¿½0:1ï¿½, plural,
  =0 {no <b title="none">emails</b>!}
  =1 {one <i>email</i>}
  other {ï¿½0:1ï¿½ <span title="ï¿½0:1ï¿½">emails</span>}
}ï¿½/#1:1ï¿½ï¿½/*3:1ï¿½.`;

function MyComponent_NgIf_Template_0(rf: RenderFlags, ctx: any) {
  if (rf & RenderFlags.Create) {
    i18nStart(0, MSG_div, 1);
      element(1, 'b');
    i18nEnd();
  }
  if (rf & RenderFlags.Update) {
    i18nExp(ctx.count);   // referenced by `ï¿½0:1ï¿½`
    i18nApply(0);
  }
}

class MyComponent {
  static Éµcmp = defineComponent({
    ...,
    template: function(rf: RenderFlags, ctx: MyComponent) {
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Create) {
        elementStart(0, 'div');
          i18nAttributes(1, MSG_div_attr);
          i18nStart(2, MSG_div);
            template(3, MyComponent_NgIf_Template_0, ...);
          i18nEnd();
        elementEnd();
      }
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Update) {
        i18nExp(ctx.name);  // referenced by `ï¿½0ï¿½` in `MSG_title`
        i18nApply(1);             // Updates the `i18n-title` binding
        i18nExp(ctx.count); // referenced by `ï¿½0ï¿½` in `MSG_div`
        i18nApply(2);             // Updates the `<div i18n>...</div>`
      }
    }
  });
}

```
TITLE: Conceptual Rendering Logic for Angular i18n Messages (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This pseudo-code demonstrates the core process of rendering an i18n string. It iterates through parts of the pre-processed i18n message; literal strings are accumulated directly, while numeric indices trigger lookups of bound values from `lViewData`. The accumulated parts are joined, potentially sanitized, and returned as the final string.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
function render18nString(i18nStringParts: string|number) {
  const accumulator:string[] = [];
  i18nStringParts.forEach(part => accumulate(part));
  return accumulatorFlush(sanitizer);

 /**
   * Collect intermediate interpolation values.
   */
  function accumulate(value: string|number): void {
    if (typeof value == 'number') {
      // if the value is a number then look it up in previous `i18nBind` location.
      value = lviewData[bindIndex + value];
    }
    accumulator.push(stringify(value));
  }

  /**
   * Flush final interpolation value.
   */
  function accumulatorFlush(sanitizer: null|((text: string)=>string) = null): string {
    let interpolation = accumulator.join('');
    if (sanitizer != null) {
      interpolation = sanitizer(interpolation);
    }
    accumulator.length = 0;
    return interpolation;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Structure of I18nUpdateOpCodes for Attribute Updates (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Details the internal `I18nUpdateOpCodes` array generated by the `i18nAttributes` instruction, stored in `TView.data`. This structure defines the operations for updating i18n attributes, including a change mask, instruction skip count, literal string parts, binding indices (represented by negative numbers like -1 referencing `lView[bindIndex - 1]`), and the target attribute update operation (element index, attribute name, sanitizer).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const i18nUpdateOpCodes = <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
  // The following OpCodes represent: `<div i18n-title title="Hello ï¿½0ï¿½!">`
  // If `changeMask & 0b1`
  //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
  //        has NOT changed then skip `7` values and start processing next OpCodes.
  0b1, 7,
  // Concatenate `newValue = 'Hello ' + lView[bindIndex-1] + '!';`.
  'Hello ',   // accumulate('Hello ');
  -1,         // accumulate(-1);
  '!',        // accumulate('!');
  // Update attribute: `elementAttribute(0, 'title', accumulatorFlush(null));`
  // NOTE: `null` means don't sanitize
  0 << SHIFT_REF | Attr, 'title', null,
]
```

TITLE: Angular Component and Directive Type References
DESCRIPTION: This code handles component and directive interactions with input requirements and QueryList usage, employing Angular's input handling for both required and optional values. It illustrates Angular's component architecture and input capturing techniques.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_8
```

// tslint:disable

import {Component, Directive, QueryList, input} from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  template: `
    {{label()}}
  `,
})
class Group {
  readonly label = input.required<string>();
}

@Directive()
class Base {
  _items = new QueryList<{
    label: string;
  }>();
}

@Directive({})
class Option extends Base {
  _items = new QueryList<Group>();
}

```
TITLE: Defining Complex Angular Component Metadata with Variables and Functions in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This example shows a more complex Angular component definition where `selector` and `templateUrl` are derived from constants (`FOO_SELECTOR`, `TEMPLATE_BASE`) and a helper function (`getTemplateUrl`). This highlights the need for the Angular compiler (`ngtsc`) to statically evaluate expressions and follow references to determine the final metadata values during compilation. It depends on the `TEMPLATE_BASE` constant and `getTemplateUrl` function defined previously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler/design/architecture.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
```javascript
export const TEMPLATE_BASE = 'templates/';

export function getTemplateUrl(cmp: string): string {
  return TEMPLATE_BASE + cmp + '.html';
}

export const FOO_SELECTOR = 'foo-cmp';
export const FOO_TEMPLATE_URL = getTemplateUrl('foo');

@Component({
  selector: FOO_SELECTOR,
  templateUrl: FOO_TEMPLATE_URL,
})
export class Foo {}
```
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Asynchronous Message Handling in Angular DevTools
DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the potential issue with asynchronous message handling in Angular DevTools, showing how responses from earlier requests might override more recent state updates if not properly prioritized.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/devtools/projects/protocol/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
1. We request the state of the component tree
1. We update the state
1. We request the state of the properties of a particular component

We don't have guarantees that the response of 1. will arrive before the response of 3. Often the response of 1. is larger and might be delivered after 3. In such a case, it may contain the application state prior to the update and override the state update we received from 3.
```

TITLE: Exporting Variables in TypeScript - Before Optimization

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
export let exported = 0;
let notExported = 0;

notExported = exported;

// Would be compiled to
exports.exported = 0;
var notExported = 0;

notExported = exports.exported;
```

TITLE: Querying with Non-Tree-Shakable Enums in Angular (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines a function 'query' enabling Angular queries with various parameters, including a feature enum type. The use of the 'QueryReadType' enumeration in the arguments prevents the TypeScript compiler from tree-shaking unused code paths, potentially increasing bundle size. Dependencies include 'Type', 'QueryReadType', 'QueryList', and internal state such as 'ngDevMode', 'assertPreviousIsParent', and 'currentQuery'. Purpose is to track and manage query instances based on runtime parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/TREE_SHAKING.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export function query<T>(
    predicate: Type<any>| string[], descend?: boolean,
    read?: QueryReadType | Type<T>): QueryList<T> {
  ngDevMode && assertPreviousIsParent();
  const queryList = new QueryList<T>();
  const query = currentQuery || (currentQuery = new LQuery_());
  query.track(queryList, predicate, descend, read);
  return queryList;
}
```

TITLE: Defining Angular HttpResponse Class (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Represents an outgoing HTTP response received by the client after a request completes. It extends `HttpResponseBase`, adds the `body` property for the response payload, includes a `clone` method for creating modified copies, and has a fixed `type` indicating a response event.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/common/http/index.api.md#_snippet_49

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export class HttpResponse<T> extends HttpResponseBase {
    constructor(init?: {
        body?: T | null;
        headers?: HttpHeaders;
        status?: number;
        statusText?: string;
        url?: string;
    });
    readonly body: T | null;
    clone(): HttpResponse<T>;
    clone(update: {
        headers?: HttpHeaders;
        status?: number;
        statusText?: string;
        url?: string;
    }): HttpResponse<T>;
    clone<V>(update: {
        body?: V | null;
        headers?: HttpHeaders;
        status?: number;
        statusText?: string;
        url?: string;
    }): HttpResponse<V>;
    readonly type: HttpEventType.Response;
}
```

TITLE: Define Reactive Node Interface (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: The base interface for all internal reactive nodes (signals, computeds, watches). It contains extensive state for tracking dependencies (producers) and dependents (consumers), dirtiness, versions, debugging names, and reactive behaviors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/core/primitives/signals/index.api.md#_snippet_29

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
export interface ReactiveNode {
    consumerAllowSignalWrites: boolean;
    readonly consumerIsAlwaysLive: boolean;
    consumerMarkedDirty(node: unknown): void;
    consumerOnSignalRead(node: unknown): void;
    debugName?: string;
    dirty: boolean;
    kind: string;
    lastCleanEpoch: Version;
    liveConsumerIndexOfThis: number[] | undefined;
    liveConsumerNode: ReactiveNode[] | undefined;
    nextProducerIndex: number;
    producerIndexOfThis: number[] | undefined;
    producerLastReadVersion: Version[] | undefined;
    producerMustRecompute(node: unknown): boolean;
    producerNode: ReactiveNode[] | undefined;
    producerRecomputeValue(node: unknown): void;
    version: Version;
}
```

TITLE: Visualizing Change Detection for New Inputs to OnPush Component with Mermaid
```

    app[AppComponent] --- header[HeaderComponent];
    app --- main["MainComponent (OnPush)"];
    header --- search[SearchComponent];
    header --- button[ButtonComponent];
    main --- login["LoginComponent (OnPush)"];
    main --- details[DetailsComponent];
    event>Parent passes new input to MainComponent]

class app checkedNode
class header checkedNode
class button checkedNode
class search checkedNode
class main checkedNode
class details checkedNode
class event eventNode

```
TITLE: Defining MockAnimationDriver and MockAnimationPlayer Classes in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines two classes for mocking animations in Angular: MockAnimationDriver implements AnimationDriver interface, and MockAnimationPlayer extends NoopAnimationPlayer. These classes are used for testing animations without actual DOM manipulation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/animations/browser/testing/index.api.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// @public (undocumented)
export class MockAnimationDriver implements AnimationDriver {
    // (undocumented)
    animate(element: any, keyframes: Array<ÉµStyleDataMap>, duration: number, delay: number, easing: string, previousPlayers?: any[]): MockAnimationPlayer;
    // (undocumented)
    computeStyle(element: any, prop: string, defaultValue?: string): string;
    // (undocumented)
    containsElement(elm1: any, elm2: any): boolean;
    // (undocumented)
    getParentElement(element: unknown): unknown;
    // (undocumented)
    static log: AnimationPlayer[];
    // (undocumented)
    query(element: any, selector: string, multi: boolean): any[];
    // (undocumented)
    validateAnimatableStyleProperty(prop: string): boolean;
    // (undocumented)
    validateStyleProperty(prop: string): boolean;
}

// @public (undocumented)
export class MockAnimationPlayer extends NoopAnimationPlayer {
    constructor(element: any, keyframes: Array<ÉµStyleDataMap>, duration: number, delay: number, easing: string, previousPlayers: any[]);
    // (undocumented)
    beforeDestroy(): void;
    // (undocumented)
    currentSnapshot: ÉµStyleDataMap;
    // (undocumented)
    delay: number;
    // (undocumented)
    destroy(): void;
    // (undocumented)
    duration: number;
    // (undocumented)
    easing: string;
    // (undocumented)
    element: any;
    // (undocumented)
    finish(): void;
    // (undocumented)
    hasStarted(): boolean;
    // (undocumented)
    keyframes: Array<ÉµStyleDataMap>;
    // (undocumented)
    play(): void;
    // (undocumented)
    previousPlayers: any[];
    // (undocumented)
    previousStyles: ÉµStyleDataMap;
    // (undocumented)
    reset(): void;
}
```

TITLE: Initializing JSAction EventContract and Handlers (JavaScript)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create and configure an EventContract instance, add event listeners for a provided event type array, and expose the contract globally. This is the main JSAction bootstrapping step, requiring @angular/core/primitives/event-dispatch/src/eventcontract and event_contract_container for imports. Key parameters are the list of event types and the container element (body). Outputs a global window property for later application use; dependencies include document access and Angular primitives. Optionally demonstrates enabling passive event listeners.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/event-dispatch/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import {EventContract} from '@angular/core/primitives/event-dispatch/src/eventcontract';\nimport {EventContractContainer} from '@angular/core/primitives/event-dispatch/src/event_contract_container';\n\n/**\n * The list of event types that you want JSAction to listen for. In Angular,\n * this is dynamically generated at server render time.\n */\nconst EVENTS_TO_LISTEN_TO = ['click', 'keydown', ...];\n\n// Events will be handled by JSAction for all elements under this container\nconst eventContract = new EventContract(\n    new EventContractContainer(document.body));\n\nfor (const eventType of EVENTS_TO_LISTEN_TO) {\n  eventContract.addEvent(eventType);\n}\n\n// Stash the contract somewhere the main application bundle can access.\nwindow['__ec'] = eventContract;\n
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
eventContract.addEvent(eventType, prefixedEventType, /* passive= */ true);\n
```

TITLE: Type Checking Block for NgFor With Context Hints
DESCRIPTION: Shows how the TypeScript code for type checking an NgFor directive is enhanced with context type narrowing when template context hints are applied.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
declare function ctor1(inputs: {ngForOf?: Iterable<T>}): NgFor<T>;

function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  // _t1 is the NgFor directive instance, inferred as NgFor<User>.
  var _t1 = ctor1({ngForOf: this.users});

  // _t2 is the context type for the embedded views created by the NgFor structural directive.
  var _t2: any;

  if (NgFor.ngTemplateContextGuard(_t1, _t2)) {
    // NgFor's ngTemplateContextGuard has narrowed the type of _t2
    // based on the type of _t1 (the NgFor directive itself).
    // Within this `if` block, _t2 is now of type NgForContext<User>.

    // _t3 is the let-user variable within the embedded view.
    // Because _t2 is narrowed, _t3 is now of type User.
    var _t3 = _t2.$implicit;

    // Represents the `{{user.name}}` interpolation within the embedded view.
    '' + _t3.name;
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing an Internal Factory Wrapper in TypeScript for Angular DI
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet defines a `Factory` class used internally by Angular's dependency injection system, as referenced in the `LView` data layout description. It wraps provider factory functions, allowing for lazy instantiation and caching, crucial for the `EXPANDO` mechanism. The `isFactory` function provides an efficient way to check if an object is a `Factory` instance using prototype comparison, and the `resolving` flag helps detect circular dependencies during factory invocation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/VIEW_DATA.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
```TypeScript
class Factory {
  /// Marker set to true during factory invocation to see if we get into recursive loop.
  /// Recursive loop causes an error to be displayed.
  resolving = false;
  constructor(public factory: Function) { }
}
function factory(fn) {
  return new Factory(fn);
}
const FactoryPrototype = Factory.prototype;
function isFactory(obj: any): obj is Factory {
  // See: https://jsperf.com/instanceof-vs-getprototypeof
  return typeof obj === 'object' && Object.getPrototypeOf(obj) === FactoryPrototype;
}
```
```

TITLE: TI18n Data Structure for i18n Processing
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript code showing the TI18n data structure generated by i18nStart. This represents the internal data structure used by Angular to store internationalization instructions for DOM manipulation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const tI18n = <TI18n>{
  vars: 2,                               // Number of slots to allocate in EXPANDO.
  expandoStartIndex: 100,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 100
  create: <I18nMutateOpCodes>[           // Processed by `i18nEnd`
    // Equivalent to:
    //   // Assume expandoIndex = 100;
    //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('');
    //   lView[2].insertBefore(node, lView[3]);
    "", 2 << SHIFT_PARENT | 3 << SHIFT_REF | InsertBefore,
    // Equivalent to:
    //   // Assume expandoIndex = 101;
    //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('.');
    //   lView[0].appendChild(node);
    '.', 2 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
  ],
  update: <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[          // Processed by `i18nApply`
    // Header which consists of change mask and block size.
    // If `changeMask & 0b1`
    //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
    //        has NOT changed then skip `3` values and start processing next OpCodes.
    0b1, 3,
    -1,                 // accumulate(-1);
    'is rendered as: ', // accumulate('is rendered as: ');
    // Flush the concatenated string to text node at position 100.
    100 << SHIFT_REF | Text, // lView[100].textContent = accumulatorFlush();
  ],
  icus: null,
}
```

TITLE: Asserting Valid Loading Input in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript function checks the loading input's validity by comparing it against predefined valid inputs. It ensures that incorrect string inputs or undefined values are properly managed, throwing errors where necessary. Dependencies include Angular core components and AppComponent.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/schematics/migrations/signal-migration/test/golden_best_effort.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// tslint:disable

import {AppComponent} from './index';

function assertValidLoadingInput(dir: AppComponent) {
  const withUndefinedInput = dir.withUndefinedInput();
  if (withUndefinedInput && dir.narrowableMultipleTimes()) {
    throw new Error(``);
  }
  const validInputs = ['auto', 'eager', 'lazy'];
  if (typeof withUndefinedInput === 'string' && !validInputs.includes(withUndefinedInput)) {
    throw new Error();
  }
}
```

TITLE: Reading from Node Injector Using Enum-Based QueryReadType (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Implements a function 'readFromNodeInjector' that inspects the 'read' parameter to determine what kind of reference to return among ElementRef, ViewContainerRef, and TemplateRef. Because the function checks 'read' against 'QueryReadType' enums, all referenced features are retained in the bundle irrespective of actual usage. This approach limits tree-shaking. Dependencies include 'LInjector', 'LNode', 'QueryReadType', and related factory functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/TREE_SHAKING.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
function readFromNodeInjector(
    nodeInjector: LInjector, node: LNode, read: QueryReadType | Type<any>): any {
  if (read === QueryReadType.ElementRef) {
    return getOrCreateElementRef(nodeInjector);
  } 
  if (read === QueryReadType.ViewContainerRef) {
    return getOrCreateContainerRef(nodeInjector);
  }
  if (read === QueryReadType.TemplateRef) {
    return getOrCreateTemplateRef(nodeInjector);
  } 
  const matchingIdx = geIdxOfMatchingDirective(node, read);
  if (matchingIdx !== null) {
    return node.view.data[matchingIdx];
  }
  return null;
}

        template(2, MyComponent_NgIf_NgFor_Template_1, ...);

    i18nEnd();
  }
  ...
}

```
TITLE: Manually Defining Angular Module Injector and Scope Statics - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows a manual approach to defining static properties (Éµinj and ngModuleScope) on the Angular module class, replicating what the Ivy compiler would generate mechanically. Requires angular core utilities and all referenced classes. The Éµinj static is initialized via ÉµÉµdefineInjector, configuring providers and imports, while ngModuleScope lists all declarations, selectors, and module references for the module. Inputs: assigned types and selectors. Output: custom class with Angular-compatible static metadata. Limitations: not all static fields are meaningful pre-compile, and symbolic errors from ÉµÉµdefineInjector may be ignored at runtime during Ivy compilation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler/design/separate_compilation.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

CODE:
```
export class MyModule {
  static Æ–inj = Æ–Æ–defineInjector({
    providers: [{
      provide: Service, useClass: ServiceImpl
    }],
    imports: [CommonModule, UtilityModule]
  });
  static ngModuleScope = [{
    type: MyComponent,
    selector: 'my-comp'
  }, {
    type: MyDirective,
    selector: '[my-dir]'
  }, {
    type: MyPipe,
    name: 'myPipe'
  }, {
    type: UtilityModule,
    isModule: true
  }];
}

```
TITLE: Fixing Function Declaration in Block Scope in Zone.js
DESCRIPTION: Fixes an issue where function declarations were made in block scope, which is not allowed in strict mode. This resolves issues #53 and #54.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
// Original problematic code:
function() {
  if (condition) {
    function foo() {}
  }
}

// Fixed code:
function() {
  var foo;
  if (condition) {
    foo = function() {};
  }
}
