TITLE: Representing Directive Input Bindings in a TCB (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Shows the Type Check Block (TCB) representation for a directive/component input binding. A variable (`_t1`) is declared with the directive's type (`OtherCmp`), and the input binding `[foo]="bar"` is translated into a TypeScript assignment `_t1.foo = this.bar`. This allows TypeScript to check if the type of `this.bar` is assignable to the input property `foo`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  var _t1: OtherCmp = null!;
  _t1.foo = this.bar;
}
```

export class ValueChangeEvent<T> extends ControlEvent<T> {
    constructor(value: T, source: AbstractControl);
    // (undocumented)
    readonly source: AbstractControl;
    // (undocumented)
    readonly value: T;
}
```

    ..., // other component options

    template: function(rf: RenderFlags, ctx: MyApp) {
      if (rf & RenderFlags.Create) {
        ÉµÉµelementStart(0, 'div');
        ÉµÉµtext(1, 'Hello ');
        ÉµÉµelementStart(2, 'b');
        ÉµÉµtext(3, 'World');

TITLE: ICU handling with TI18n data structure in Angular i18n
DESCRIPTION: Complex example showing how ICU expressions are pre-parsed and stored in the TVIEW.data using the TI18n data structure, with detailed OpCodes for create, update, and remove operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const tI18n = <TI18n>{
  vars: 3 + Math.max(4, 3, 3),           // Number of slots to allocate in EXPANDO. (Max of all ICUs + fixed)
  expandoStartIndex: 200,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 200
  create: <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
    // Equivalent to:
    //   // Assume expandoIndex = 200;
    //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createComment('');
    //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
    ICU_MARKER, '', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
  ],
  update: <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
    // The following OpCodes represent: `<b>{count, plural, ... }</b>">`
    // If `changeMask & 0b1`
    //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
    //        has NOT changed then skip `2` values and start processing next OpCodes.
    0b1, 2,
    -1,       // accumulate(-1);
    // Switch ICU: `icuSwitchCase(lView[200 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/, accumulatorFlush());`
    200 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuSwitch,

    // NOTE: the bit mask here is the logical OR of all of the masks in the ICU.
    0b1, 1,
    // Update ICU: `icuUpdateCase(lView[200 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/);`
    // SHIFT_REF: points to: `i18nStart(0, MSG_div, 1);`
    // SHIFT_ICU: is an index into which ICU is being updated. In our example we only have
    //            one ICU so it is 0-th ICU to update.
    200 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuUpdate,
  ],
  icus: [
    <TIcu>{
      cases: [0, 1, 'other'],
      vars: [4, 3, 3],
      expandoStartIndex: 203,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 203
      childIcus: [],
      create: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no <b title="none">emails</b>!}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 203
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('no ');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          'no ', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          // Equivalent to:
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 204
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createElement('b');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          ELEMENT_MARKER, 'b', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          //   const node = lView[204];
          //   node.setAttribute('title', 'none');
          204 << SHIFT_REF | Select, 'title', 'none'
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 205
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('email');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          'email', 204 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
        ],
        // Case: `1`: `{one <i>email</i>}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 203
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('no ');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node, lView[2]);
          'one ', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          // Equivalent to:
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 204
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createElement('b');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          ELEMENT_MARKER, 'i', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 205
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('email');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          'email', 204 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
        ],
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <span title="ï¿½0ï¿½">emails</span>}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 203
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          '', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          // Equivalent to:
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 204
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createComment('span');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          ELEMENT_MARKER, 'span', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
          //   // assume expandoIndex == 205
          //   const node = lView[expandoIndex++] = document.createTextNode('emails');
          //   lView[1].appendChild(node);
          'emails', 204 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
        ]
      ],
      remove: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no <b title="none">emails</b>!}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[203]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 203 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[204]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 204 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
        // Case: `1`: `{one <i>email</i>}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[203]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 203 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[204]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 204 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <span title="ï¿½0ï¿½">emails</span>}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[203]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 203 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
          //   lView[1].remove(lView[204]);
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 204 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ]
      ],
      update: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no <b title="none">emails</b>!}`
        <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
          // no bindings
        ],
        // Case: `1`: `{one <i>email</i>}`
        <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
          // no bindings
        ],
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <span title="ï¿½0ï¿½">emails</span>}`
        <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
          // If `changeMask & 0b1`
          //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
          //        has NOT changed then skip `5` values and start processing next OpCodes.
          0b1, 5,
          -1,   // accumulate(-1);
          ' ',  // accumulate(' ');
          // Update attribute: `lviewData[203].textValue = accumulatorFlush();`
          203 << SHIFT_REF | Text,
          // If `changeMask & 0b1`
          //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
          //        has NOT changed then skip `4` values and start processing next OpCodes.
          0b1, 4,
          // Concatenate `newValue = '' + lView[bindIndex -1];`.
          -1,   // accumulate(-1);
          // Update attribute: `lView[204].setAttribute(204, 'title', 0b1, 2,(null));`
          // NOTE: `null` implies no sanitization.
          204 << SHIFT_REF | Attr, 'title', null
        ]
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Directive with Angular Ivy
DESCRIPTION: Example of directive implementation and transformation in Angular Ivy, showing TypeScript source, compiled JavaScript, and metadata JSON output.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler/design/separate_compilation.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
@Directive({selector: '[my-dir]'})
export class MyDirective {
  @HostBinding('id') dirId = 'some id';
}
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
export class MyDirective {
  constructor() {
    this.dirId = 'some id';
  }

TITLE: Pseudo-Code for Angular's Internal `inject` Function Implementation in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript pseudo-code outlines the logic of Angular's internal `inject` function, tying together concepts from the document. It shows how the function checks the provided token, specifically looking for the `Injector` token identified by the special `provideIn: '__node_injector__'` property (as defined in another snippet) to return a node-bound injector instance. For other tokens, it delegates the lookup to the `lookupTokenInExpando` function, which searches the internal `EXPANDO` data structures based on the rules described.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/VIEW_DATA.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
```typescript
function inject(token: any): any {
  let injectableDef;
  if (typeof token === 'function' && injectableDef = token.Éµprov) {
    const provideIn = injectableDef.provideIn;
   if (provideIn === '__node_injector__') {
      // if we are injecting `Injector` than create a wrapper object around the inject but which
      // is bound to the current node.
      return createInjector();
    }
  }
  return lookupTokenInExpando(token);
}
```
```

TITLE: ICU Internationalization Operation Codes
DESCRIPTION: Detailed implementation of TI18n structure with operation codes for handling ICU expressions. Shows the internal representation with create, update, and ICU case handling instructions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_20

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const tI18n = <TI18n>{
  vars: 0,                               // Number of slots to allocate in EXPANDO. (Max of all ICUs + fixed)
  expandoStartIndex: 200,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 200
  create: <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
    // attributes have no create block
  ],
  update: <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
    // If `changeMask & 0b1`
    //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
    //        has NOT changed then skip `2` values and start processing next OpCodes.
    0b1, 2,
    -1,       // accumulate(-1)
    // Switch ICU: `icuSwitchCase(lView[200 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/, accumulatorFlush());`
    200 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuSwitch,

    // NOTE: the bit mask here is the logical OR of all of the masks in the ICU.
    0b1, 4,
    'You have ',  // accumulate('You have ');

    // Update ICU: `icuUpdateCase(lView[200 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/);`
    // SHIFT_REF: points to: `i18nStart(0, MSG_div, 1);`
    // SHIFT_ICU: is an index into which ICU is being updated. In our example we only have
    //            one ICU so it is 0-th ICU to update.
    200 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuUpdate,

    '.',  // accumulate('.');

    // Update attribute: `elementAttribute(1, 'title', accumulatorFlush(null));`
    // NOTE: `null` means don't sanitize
    1 << SHIFT_REF | Attr, 'title', null,
  ],
  icus: [
    <TIcu>{
      cases: [0, 1, 'other'],
      vars: [0, 0, 0],
      expandoStartIndex: 200,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 200
      childIcus: [],
      create: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
        // Case: `1`: `{one email}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
      ],
      remove: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
        // Case: `1`: `{one email}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[ ]
      ],
      update: [
        // Case: `0`: `{no emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          // If `changeMask & -1` // always true
          //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
          //        has NOT changed then skip `1` values and start processing next OpCodes.
          -1, 1,
          'no emails',  // accumulate('no emails');
        ]
        // Case: `1`: `{one email}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          // If `changeMask & -1` // always true
          //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
          //        has NOT changed then skip `1` values and start processing next OpCodes.
          -1, 1,
          'one email',  // accumulate('no emails');
        ]
        // Case: `"other"`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ emails}`
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
          // If `changeMask & -1` // always true
          //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
          //        has NOT changed then skip `1` values and start processing next OpCodes.
          -1, 2,
          -1,        // accumulate(lView[bindIndex-1]);
          'emails',  // accumulate('no emails');
         ]
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Language Redirection with Nginx
DESCRIPTION: This Nginx configuration example demonstrates how to serve a multi-locale Angular application. It sets up a map based on the `Accept-Language` HTTP header to determine the user's preferred language ('en' or 'fr'), defaulting to 'en'. It then uses this mapped language to rewrite the request URL to the corresponding language subdirectory (e.g., `/fr/`) if the header is present and the language is supported. A server block listens on port 80, defines the root directory, and includes standard file serving configurations along with the language-based rewrite rule.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/i18n/deploy.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: nginx
CODE:
```
map $http_accept_language $accept_language {
  ~*^en en;
  ~*^fr fr;
  default en;
}

server {
  listen 80;
  listen [::]:80;
  server_name example.com;
  root /var/www/example.com;
  index index.html index.htm;

  # Redirect based on the preferred language
  if ($http_accept_language ~* ^(en|fr)) {
    set $accept_language $1;
  }
  if ($accept_language ~ (en|fr)) {
    rewrite ^/$ /$accept_language/ permanent;
  }

  location / {
    try_files $uri $uri/ /index.html;
  }

  location ~ \.(js|css|png|jpg|gif|svg|eot|ttf|woff|woff2)$ {
    expires 1y;
    add_header Cache-Control "public, max-age=31536000, immutable";
  }
}
```

TITLE: Internal Data Structure for Nested ICUs in Angular TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Defines the internal TI18n data structure used to represent nested ICUs, including creation, update, and removal OpCodes for different cases.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_28

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const tI18n = <TI18n>{
  vars: 2,                               // Number of slots to allocate in EXPANDO.
  expandoStartIndex: 100,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 100
  create: <I18nMutateOpCodes>[           // Processed by `i18nEnd`
  ],
  update: <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[          // Processed by `i18nApply`
    // The following OpCodes represent: `<b>{count, plural, ... }</b>">`
    // If `changeMask & 0b1`
    //        has changed then execute update OpCodes.
    //        has NOT changed then skip `2` values and start processing next OpCodes.
    0b1, 2,
    -1,       // accumulate(-1);
    // Switch ICU: `icuSwitchCase(lView[100 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/, accumulatorFlush());`
    100 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuSwitch,

    // NOTE: the bit mask here is the logical OR of all of the masks in the ICU.
    0b1, 1,
    // Update ICU: `icuUpdateCase(lView[100 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/);`
    // SHIFT_REF: points to: `i18nStart(0, MSG_div, 1);`
    // SHIFT_ICU: is an index into which ICU is being updated. In our example we only have
    //            one ICU so it is 0-th ICU to update.
    100 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuUpdate,
  ],
  icus: [
    <TIcu>{                                  // {ï¿½0ï¿½, plural, =0 {zero} other {ï¿½0ï¿½ <!--subICU-->}}
      cases: [0, 'other'],
      childIcus: [[1]],                      // pointer to child ICUs. Needed to properly clean up.
      vars: [1, 2],
      expandoStartIndex: 100,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 100
      create: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `0`: `{zero}`
          'zero ', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,  // Expando location: 100
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `other`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <!--subICU-->}`
          '', 1 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,       // Expando location: 100
          ICU_MARKER, '', 0 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,    // Expando location: 101
        ],
      ],
      remove: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `0`: `{zero}`
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 100 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `other`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <!--subICU-->}`
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 100 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
          1 << SHIFT_PARENT | 101 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
      ],
      update: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `0`: `{zero}`
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                         // Case: `other`: `{ï¿½0ï¿½ <!--subICU-->}`
          0b1, 3,
          -2, ' ', 100 << SHIFT_REF | Text,           // Case: `ï¿½0ï¿½ `
          0b10, 5,
          -1,
          // Switch ICU: `icuSwitchCase(lView[101 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/, accumulatorFlush());`
          101 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuSwitch,

          // NOTE: the bit mask here is the logical OR of all of the masks int the ICU.
          0b10, 1,
          // Update ICU: `icuUpdateCase(lView[101 /*SHIFT_REF*/], 0 /*SHIFT_ICU*/);`
          101 << SHIFT_REF | 0 << SHIFT_ICU | IcuUpdate,
        ],
      ]
    },
    <TIcu>{                                  // {ï¿½1ï¿½, select, cat {cats} dog {dogs} other {animals} }
      cases: ['cat', 'dog', 'other'],
      vars: [1, 1, 1],
      expandoStartIndex: 102,                // Assume in this example EXPANDO starts at 102. (parent ICU 100 + max(1, 2))
      childIcus: [],
      create: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `cat`: `{cats}`
          'cats', 101 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,    // Expando location: 102; 101 is location of comment/anchor
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `doc`: `docs`
          'cats', 101 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,    // Expando location: 102; 101 is location of comment/anchor
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `other`: `animals`
          'animals', 101 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild, // Expando location: 102; 101 is location of comment/anchor
        ],
      ]
      remove: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `cat`: `{cats}`
          101 << SHIFT_PARENT | 102 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `doc`: `docs`
          101 << SHIFT_PARENT | 102 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `other`: `animals`
          101 << SHIFT_PARENT | 102 << SHIFT_REF | Remove,
        ],
      ],
      update: [
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `cat`: `{cats}`
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `doc`: `docs`
        ],
        <I18nMutateOpCodes>[                            // Case: `other`: `animals`
        ],
      ]
    }
  ],
}
```

TITLE: Define Watch Interface (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Defines the interface for a watch node. It includes the internal `[SIGNAL]` property and methods to clean up its side effect (`cleanup`), destroy the watch entirely (`destroy`), notify it of changes (`notify`), and run the effect (`run`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/goldens/public-api/core/primitives/signals/index.api.md#_snippet_46

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
export interface Watch {
    [SIGNAL]: WatchNode;
    cleanup(): void;
    destroy(): void;
    notify(): void;
    run(): void;
}
```

    // (undocumented)

TITLE: Circular Type Reference Problem in TCB Generation
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how a naive implementation of TCB would create an invalid circular reference in the generated TypeScript code for a template with a self-referential binding.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_24

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
declare function ctor1<T>(inputs: {in?: T}): GenericCmp<T>;

function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  // Not legal: cannot refer to t1 (ref) before its declaration.
  var t1 = ctor1({in: t1.value});

  t1.in = t1.value;
}
```

TITLE: Describing JSAction Attribute Syntax Rules (EBNF)
DESCRIPTION: Defines, in EBNF format, the allowed syntax for the jsaction attribute value. It enforces a structured mapping from event types to handler names, supporting semicolon-delimited multiple bindings, optional event type (defaulting to click), and exclusion of certain special characters. This snippet serves as a formal grammar reference for developers generating or parsing jsaction attributes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/event-dispatch/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: ebnf
CODE:
```
; JSAction attribute syntax in ENBF format\njsaction-attr-value   = binding, { \";\", jsaction-attr-value }\n\nbinding               = [ event-type, \":\" ], event-handler\n\nevent-type            = { white space characters }, [valid-name], { white space characters }\nevent-handler         = { white space characters }, [valid-name], { white space characters }\n\nvalid-name            = { valid-char }\n\nvalid-char            = character - invalid-name-chars\ninvalid-name-chars    = \":\" | \",\" | \":\"\n
```

TITLE: Registering Event Handlers with JSAction Attribute (HTML)
DESCRIPTION: This succinct snippet shows an HTML button element utilizing the jsaction attribute for a click event. This requires the presence of the global event delegation infrastructure set up in prior snippets.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/primitives/event-dispatch/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<button type=\"button\" jsaction=\"click:handleClick\">Buy now!</button>\n
```

TITLE: Cutting and Publishing zone.js Release using Git, Bazel, and NPM
DESCRIPTION: A sequence of shell commands to perform the final steps of a `zone.js` release after the preparatory PR is merged. It fetches updates, checks out the main branch, reinstalls dependencies, determines the version and tag from `package.json`, finds the specific merge commit SHA for the release, checks out that SHA, logs into the specified npm registry, publishes the package using Bazel with release configuration, tags the commit in git, and pushes the tag to the upstream remote. Requires `git`, `node`, `npm`, `yarn`, `bazel`, and appropriate repository/registry permissions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/DEVELOPER.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
```
git fetch upstream
git checkout upstream/main
rm -rf node_modules && yarn install
export VERSION=`(node -e "console.log(require('./packages/zone.js/package.json').version)")`
export TAG="zone.js-${VERSION}"
export SHA=`git log upstream/main --oneline -n 1000 | grep "release: cut the ${TAG} release" | cut -f 1 -d " "`
echo "Releasing '$VERSION' which will be tagged as '$TAG' from SHA '$SHA'."
git checkout ${SHA}
npm login --registry https://wombat-dressing-room.appspot.com
yarn bazel -- run --config=release -- //packages/zone.js:npm_package.publish --access public --tag latest
git tag ${TAG} ${SHA}
git push upstream ${TAG}
```
```

TITLE: Preparing zone.js Release PR: Versioning and Changelog Generation
DESCRIPTION: A sequence of shell commands to prepare a release Pull Request for `zone.js`. It cleans and reinstalls dependencies, determines the previous and new version numbers using `git tag` and `npm version`, sets environment variables (`PREVIOUS_ZONE_TAG`, `VERSION`, `TAG`), and generates the changelog using `yarn gulp changelog:zonejs`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/DEVELOPER.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
```
rm -rf node_modules && yarn install
export PREVIOUS_ZONE_TAG=`git tag -l 'zone.js-0.15.*' | tail -n1`
export VERSION=`(cd packages/zone.js; npm version patch --no-git-tag-version)`
export VERSION=${VERSION#v}
export TAG="zone.js-${VERSION}"
echo "Releasing zone.js version ${TAG}. Last release was ${PREVIOUS_ZONE_TAG}."
yarn gulp changelog:zonejs
```
```

TITLE: Circular Reference Resolution in TCB Generation
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of the circular fallback mechanism that breaks reference cycles by generating placeholder types for components without using input bindings, then using these placeholders in the actual type inference.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_25

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
declare function ctor1<T>(inputs: {in?: T}): GenericCmp<T>;

function tcb(this: SomeCmp): void {
  // Generated to break the cycle for `ref` - infers a placeholder
  // type for the component without using any of its input bindings.
  var t1 = ctor1(null!);

  // Infer the real type of the component using the `t1` placeholder
  // type for `ref`.
  var t2 = ctor1({in: t1.value});

  // Check the binding to [in] using the real type of `ref`.
  t2.in = t2.value;
}
```

TITLE: Visualizing Angular Lifecycle Hook Execution Order During Initialization (Mermaid)
DESCRIPTION: This Mermaid diagram illustrates the sequence in which Angular lifecycle hooks are executed when a component is first initialized. It shows the flow starting from the `constructor`, proceeding through change detection phases (`ngOnChanges`, `ngOnInit`, `ngDoCheck`, `ngAfterContentInit`, `ngAfterContentChecked`, `ngAfterViewInit`, `ngAfterViewChecked`), and concluding with rendering (`afterRender`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/guide/components/lifecycle.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: mermaid
CODE:
```
```mermaid
graph TD;
id[constructor]-->CHANGE;
subgraph CHANGE [Change detection]
direction TB
ngOnChanges-->ngOnInit;
ngOnInit-->ngDoCheck;
ngDoCheck-->ngAfterContentInit;
ngDoCheck-->ngAfterViewInit
ngAfterContentInit-->ngAfterContentChecked
ngAfterViewInit-->ngAfterViewChecked
end
CHANGE--Rendering-->afterRender
```
```

TITLE: Angular Migration Documentation Cards Structure
DESCRIPTION: HTML structure using custom docs-card-container and docs-card components to display various migration options available in Angular. Each card contains information about a specific migration path with title, link and description.

LANGUAGE: HTML
CODE:
```
<docs-card-container>
  <docs-card title="Standalone" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/standalone">
    Standalone components provide a simplified way to build Angular applications. Standalone components specify their dependencies directly instead of getting them through NgModules.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Control Flow Syntax" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/control-flow">
    Built-in Control Flow Syntax allows you to use more ergonomic syntax which is close to JavaScript and has better type checking. It replaces the need to import `CommonModule` to use functionality like `*ngFor`, `*ngIf` and `*ngSwitch`.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="inject() Function" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/inject-function">
    Angular's `inject` function offers more accurate types and better compatibility with standard decorators, compared to constructor-based injection.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Lazy-loaded routes" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/route-lazy-loading">
    Convert eagerly loaded component routes to lazy loaded ones. This allows the build process to split production bundles into smaller chunks, to load less JavaScript at initial page load.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="New `input()` API" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/signal-inputs">
    Convert existing `@Input` fields to the new signal input API that is now production ready.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="New `output()` function" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/outputs">
    Convert existing `@Output` custom events to the new output function that is now production ready.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Queries as signal" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/signal-queries">
    Convert existing decorator query fields to the improved signal queries API. The API is now production ready.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Cleanup unused imports" link="Try it now" href="reference/migrations/cleanup-unused-imports">
    Clean up unused imports in your project.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Self-closing tags" link="Migrate now" href="reference/migrations/self-closing-tags">
    Convert component templates to use self-closing tags where possible.
  </docs-card>
</docs-card-container>
```

TITLE: Angular Module Metadata Representation - JSON
DESCRIPTION: Provides the metadata representation of the Angular module used by Angular's AOT compiler and tooling, following the Angular package format convention. The 'metadata' section lists classes, their static properties (such as Æ–inj and ngModuleScope), and symbol references for module declarations. Inputs include dependencies such as MyComponent, MyDirective, MyPipe, and UtilityModule. Outputs are used for dependency resolution and module linkage during compilation. Accurate JSON schema is critical for successful tooling and Ivy transformation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/compiler/design/separate_compilation.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: JSON
CODE:
```
{
  "__symbolic": "module",
  "version": 4,
  "metadata": {
    "MyModule": {
      "__symbolic": "class",
      "statics": {
        "Æ–inj": {},
        "ngModuleScope": [
          {
            "type": {
              "__symbolic": "reference",
              "module": "./my.component",
              "name": "MyComponent"
            },
            "selector": "my-comp"
          },
          {
            "type": {
              "__symbolic": "reference",
              "module": "./my.directive",
              "name": "MyDirective"
            },
            "selector": "[my-dir]"
          },
          {
            "type": {
              "__symbolic": "reference",
              "module": "./my.pipe",
              "name": "MyPipe"
            },
            "name": "myPipe",
            "isPipe": true
          },
          {
            "type": {
              "__symbolic": "reference",
              "module": "./utility.module",
              "name": "UtilityModule"
            },
            "isModule": true
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Generated Angular Ivy Code for i18n Attribute Handling (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the Ivy instructions generated within the `RenderFlags.Create` block for handling i18n attributes. The `elementStart` instruction creates the element, and `i18nAttributes` is called immediately after, passing the target instruction index (1) and an array containing attribute-message pairs (`MSG_div_attr`), to set up the translation and update logic for the specified attributes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const MSG_title = 'Hello ï¿½0ï¿½!';
const MSG_div_attr = ['title', MSG_title];
elementStart(0, 'div');
i18nAttributes(1, MSG_div_attr);
```

TITLE: Documenting Angular Hydration Benchmark Structure
DESCRIPTION: Describes the folder structure and purpose of Angular's hydration benchmark setup. The benchmark compares DOM node matching performance between standard rendering and hydration approaches using a large table component.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/modules/benchmarks/src/hydration/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
# Hydration benchmark

This folder contains hydration benchmark that tests the process of matching DOM nodes at runtime.

There are 2 folders in this benchmark:

* `baseline` - renders a component without hydration, we use it as a baseline
* `main` - the same code as the `baseline`, but Angular uses hydration and matches existing DOM nodes instead of creating new ones

The benchmarks are based on `largetable` benchmarks.
```

TITLE: Computing EXPANDO positions for i18n operations in Angular
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how the i18nStart instruction generates OpCodes for creation and update, with details on how the EXPANDO index references are computed and managed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/render3/i18n/i18n.md#2025-04-22_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const tI18n = <TI18n>{
  vars: 1,
  expandoStartIndex: 100, // Retrieved from `tView.blueprint.length` at i18nStart invocation.
  create: <I18nMutateOpCodes>[
    // let expandoIndex = this.expandoStartIndex;   // Initialize

    // const node = document.createTextNode('');
    // if (first_execution_for_tview) {
    //   ngDevMode && assertEquals(tView.blueprint.length, expandoIndex);
    //   tView.blueprint.push(null);
    //   ngDevMode && assertEquals(lView.length, expandoIndex);
    //   lView.push(node);
    // } else {
    //   lView[expandoIndex] = node; // save expandoIndex == 100;
    // }
    // lView[0].appendChild(node);
    // expandoIndex++;
    "", 0 << SHIFT_PARENT | AppendChild,
  ],
  update: <I18nUpdateOpCodes>[
    0b1, 3,
    'Hello ', -1, '!',
    // The `100` position refers to empty text node created above.
    100 << SHIFT_REF | Text,
  ],
}
```

TITLE: Rendering Future Work Cards in Angular HTML
DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet uses a custom 'docs-card-container' component to display multiple 'docs-card' elements. Each card represents a different area of future work or exploration for the Angular framework, including titles and brief descriptions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/roadmap.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<docs-card-container>
  <docs-card title="Signal Forms" href="">
  We plan to analyze existing feedback about Angular forms and design a solution which addresses developers' requirements and uses Signals for management of reactive state.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Selectorless" href="">
  To reduce boilerplate and improve the ergonomics of standalone components we are now designing a solution that will make selectors optional. To use a component or directive you'll be able to import it and directly use it in a component's template.

  We're still in early stages of planning selectorless. We'll share a request for comments when we have an early design and we're ready for next steps.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Exploration of streamed server-side rendering" href="">
  Over the past few releases we've been working on making Angular's server-side rendering story more robust. On our priority list is to explore streamed server-side rendering for zoneless application.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Investigation for authoring format improvements" href="">
  Based on our developer surveys' results we saw there are opportunities for improving the ergonomics of the component authoring format. The first step of the process will be to gather requirements and understand the problem space in advanced to an RFC. We'll share updates as we make progress. High priority in the future work will be backward compatibility and interoperability.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Improve TestBed" href="">
  Based on feedback over the years and the recent updates in Angular's runtime, we'll evaluate TestBed to identify opportunities to improve developer experience and reduce boilerplate when developing unit tests.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Incremental adoption" href="">
  Angular has been lacking the tools and the flexibility to add interactivity to a multi-page app or embed an Angular component inside of an existing app built with a different framework.

  As part of this project, we'll explore the requirement space of cross framework interop and our build tooling offering to make this use case possible.
  </docs-card>
</docs-card-container>
```

TITLE: Using Bluebird with Zone.js in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript code showing how to use Bluebird Promise with Zone.js in a Node.js environment. This demonstrates running Bluebird Promise within a specific zone.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/zone.js/NON-STANDARD-APIS.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
require('zone.js');
const Bluebird = require('bluebird');
require('zone.js/plugins/zone-bluebird');

const bluebirdSymbol = Zone.__symbol__('bluebird');
const patchBluebirdFn = (Zone as any)[bluebirdSymbol];
patchBluebirdFn(Bluebird);

Zone.current
  .fork({
    name: 'bluebird',
  })
  .run(() => {
    Bluebird.resolve(1).then((result) => {
      console.log('result ', result, 'Zone', Zone.current.name);
    });
  });
```

    main --- details[DetailsComponent];
    event>Event] --- login

class header checkedNode
class button checkedNode
class search checkedNode
class login checkedNode
class main checkedNode
class details checkedNode

TITLE: Pre-Written Response for Non-Reproducible Issues in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This response is employed when the team cannot reproduce the report issue with the provided information, prompting for a minimal reproduction. It advises users to create a new issue if the problem persists.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/contributing-docs/saved-issue-replies.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
I'm sorry but we can't reproduce the problem you are reporting. We require that reported issues have a minimal reproduction that showcases the problem.

If the problem still exists in your application, please [open a new issue](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/new/choose) and follow the instructions in the issue template that include info on how to create a reproduction using our template.
```

TITLE: Press Kit Container Structure in Markdown
DESCRIPTION: Custom docs-card-container markup for displaying Angular logo assets and brand guidelines with downloadable resources.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/press-kit.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
<docs-card-container>
  <docs-card title="Angular logos" href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1IgcAwLDVZUz8ycnFa7T4_H6B4V4LhYUQ?usp=sharing" link="Download from Google Drive">
    ![Angular wordmark gradient logo](assets/images/press-kit/angular_wordmark_gradient.png "Angular wordmark gradient logo")
    ![Angular wordmark white logo](assets/images/press-kit/angular_wordmark_white.png "Angular wordmark white logo")
    ![Angular wordmark black logo](assets/images/press-kit/angular_wordmark_black.png "Angular wordmark black logo")
    Black and white are the default color variations and should be used in most circumstances. A gradient version of the icon and lockup is available in both static and animated formats and can be used in cases where a color icon is required.
  </docs-card>
  <docs-card title="Brand guidelines" href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1gD5-kamfribnib6TH4-aqVZxjYaDZlCg?usp=drive_link" link="Download from Google Drive">
    ![Angular animated gradient logo](assets/images/press-kit/angular_icon_gradient.gif "Angular animated gradient logo")
    Our brand guidelines folders contain the design files, guidance and community examples for how the brand can be adapted.
    Read more about adapting the logo in the section below.
  </docs-card>
</docs-card-container>
```

TITLE: Creating a Navigation Pill Row in Angular Documentation
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to create a row of navigation pills in Angular documentation using the docs-pill-row component. The example includes two docs-pill elements with href attributes pointing to '#pill-row' and 'Link' as the display text.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/shared-docs/pipeline/guides/testing/docs-pill-row/docs-pill-row.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<docs-pill-row>
  <docs-pill href="#pill-row" title="Link"/>
  <docs-pill href="#pill-row" title="Link"/>
</docs-pill-row>
```

TITLE: Sequence Diagram with Mermaid
DESCRIPTION: A sequence diagram created with Mermaid showing a conversation between Alice and John. Demonstrates the flow of messages between two entities.

LANGUAGE: mermaid
CODE:
```
  sequenceDiagram
      Alice->>+John: Hello John, how are you?
      Alice->>+John: John, can you hear me?
      John-->>-Alice: Hi Alice, I can hear you!
      John-->>-Alice: I feel great!
```

TITLE: Describing Child Query Result Error in Angular
DESCRIPTION: This markdown snippet explains the error that occurs when a required child query result is accessed before it's available or when a query has no matches. It details the timing of content and view query result calculations and provides guidance on when these results become accessible.
SOURCE: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/adev/src/content/reference/errors/NG0951.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
# Child query result is required but no value is available.

Required child query (`contentChild.required` or `viewChild.required`) result was accessed before query results were calculated or query has no matches.

This can happen in two distinct situations:
* query results were accessed before a given query could collect results;
* a query was executed but didn't match any nodes and has no results as a consequence.

Content queries and view queries each calculate their results at different points in time:
* `contentChild` results are available after a _host_ view (template where a directive declaring a query is used) is created;
* `viewChild` results are available after a template of a component declaring a query is created.

Accessing query results before they're available results in the error described on this page. Most notably, query results are _never_ available in a constructor of the component or directive declaring a query.

## Fixing the error

`contentChild` query results can be accessed in the `AfterContentChecked` lifecycle hook, or later.
`viewChild` query results can be accessed in the `AfterViewChecked` lifecycle hook, or later.

Make sure that a required query matches at least one node and has results at all. You can verify this by accessing query results in the lifecycle hooks listed above.
```
